Result: General-purpose VLMs show potential for clear, interpretable outputs from blood report images; performance is encouraging but varies by model, and evaluation on a small dataset limits generalizability.

Conclusion: General-purpose VLMs can support patient-facing preliminary blood report analysis, but robust validation on larger, diverse datasets and rigorous clinical safety checks are needed before deployment.

Abstract: The reliable analysis of blood reports is important for health knowledge, but
individuals often struggle with interpretation, leading to anxiety and
overlooked issues. We explore the potential of general-purpose Vision-Language
Models (VLMs) to address this challenge by automatically analyzing blood report
images. We conduct a comparative evaluation of three VLMs: Qwen-VL-Max, Gemini
2.5 Pro, and Llama 4 Maverick, determining their performance on a dataset of
100 diverse blood report images. Each model was prompted with clinically
relevant questions adapted to each blood report. The answers were then
processed using Sentence-BERT to compare and evaluate how closely the models
responded. The findings suggest that general-purpose VLMs are a practical and
promising technology for developing patient-facing tools for preliminary blood
report analysis. Their ability to provide clear interpretations directly from
images can improve health literacy and reduce the limitations to understanding
complex medical information. This work establishes a foundation for the future
development of reliable and accessible AI-assisted healthcare applications.
While results are encouraging, they should be interpreted cautiously given the
limited dataset size.

</details>


### [83] [TinyDef-DETR:An Enhanced DETR Detector for UAV Power Line Defect Detection](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06035)
*Jiaming Cui*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: DETR-based TinyDef-DETR for UAV small-defect detection in power grids, featuring stride-free downsampling, edge-aware features, dual-domain multi-scale attention, and a small-object-focused regression loss; achieves strong small-object performance with modest overhead and generalizes to other datasets.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Detecting tiny, ambiguous defects on transmission lines in UAV imagery is hard due to lost details from downsampling, weak boundary cues in lightweight backbones, and insufficient global-local context fusion.

Method: Introduce a stride-free space-to-depth module for lossless downsampling; edge-enhanced convolution for boundary-aware feature extraction; cross-stage dual-domain multi-scale attention to fuse global and local cues; Focaler-Wise-SIoU regression loss to improve small object localization.

Result: On the CSG-ADCD dataset, TinyDef-DETR significantly improves precision and recall, with notable gains on small-object subsets and modest computational overhead; generalizes to VisDrone benchmark.

Conclusion: A combination of detail-preserving downsampling, edge-sensitive representations, dual-domain attention, and difficulty-adaptive regression provides an efficient solution for UAV-based small-defect inspection in power grids.

Abstract: Automated inspection of transmission lines using UAVs is hindered by the
difficulty of detecting small and ambiguous defects against complex
backgrounds. Conventional detectors often suffer from detail loss due to
strided downsampling, weak boundary sensitivity in lightweight backbones, and
insufficient integration of global context with local cues. To address these
challenges, we propose TinyDef-DETR, a DETR-based framework designed for
small-defect detection. The method introduces a stride-free space-to-depth
module for lossless downsampling, an edge-enhanced convolution for
boundary-aware feature extraction, a cross-stage dual-domain multi-scale
attention module to jointly capture global and local information, and a
Focaler-Wise-SIoU regression loss to improve localization of small objects.
Experiments conducted on the CSG-ADCD dataset demonstrate that TinyDef-DETR
achieves substantial improvements in both precision and recall compared to
competitive baselines, with particularly notable gains on small-object subsets,
while incurring only modest computational overhead. Further validation on the
VisDrone benchmark confirms the generalization capability of the proposed
approach. Overall, the results indicate that integrating detail-preserving
downsampling, edge-sensitive representations, dual-domain attention, and
difficulty-adaptive regression provides a practical and efficient solution for
UAV-based small-defect inspection in power grids.

</details>


### [84] [BranchGRPO: Stable and Efficient GRPO with Structured Branching in Diffusion Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06040)
*Yuming Li,Yikai Wang,Yuying Zhu,Zhongyu Zhao,Ming Lu,Qi She,Shanghang Zhang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: BranchGRPO introduces a branch sampling policy to accelerate SDE-based alignment of image/video generative models, using shared-prefix computation, a tree-based advantage estimator with dense rewards, and pruning of low-reward paths. It yields substantial compute savings and improved alignment.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current alignment of image/video generative models relies on expensive on-policy rollouts, excessive SDE sampling steps, and sparse rewards, leading to high compute costs and unstable training. There is a need for more efficient, diverse exploration methods that maintain or improve alignment quality.

Method: BranchGRPO updates the sampling process with a branch sampling policy that shares computation across common prefixes, and prunes low-reward paths and redundant depths. It introduces a tree-based advantage estimator that incorporates dense process-level rewards and employs pruning strategies to exploit path and depth redundancy, accelerating convergence and enhancing exploration diversity.

Result: Empirical results show BranchGRPO improves alignment scores by 16% over strong baselines and cuts training time by 50%, while maintaining or improving exploration diversity.

Conclusion: BranchGRPO provides substantial compute savings and improved alignment performance for image and video preference alignment tasks, thanks to branch-based sampling, a tree-based advantage estimator, and effective pruning of redundant paths.

Abstract: Recent advancements in aligning image and video generative models via GRPO
have achieved remarkable gains in enhancing human preference alignment.
However, these methods still face high computational costs from on-policy
rollouts and excessive SDE sampling steps, as well as training instability due
to sparse rewards. In this paper, we propose BranchGRPO, a novel method that
introduces a branch sampling policy updating the SDE sampling process. By
sharing computation across common prefixes and pruning low-reward paths and
redundant depths, BranchGRPO substantially lowers the per-update compute cost
while maintaining or improving exploration diversity. This work makes three
main contributions: (1) a branch sampling scheme that reduces rollout and
training cost; (2) a tree-based advantage estimator incorporating dense
process-level rewards; and (3) pruning strategies exploiting path and depth
redundancy to accelerate convergence and boost performance. Experiments on
image and video preference alignment show that BranchGRPO improves alignment
scores by 16% over strong baselines, while cutting training time by 50%.

</details>


### [85] [Multi-Stage Graph Neural Networks for Data-Driven Prediction of Natural Convection in Enclosed Cavities](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06041)
*Mohammad Ahangarkiasari,Hassan Pouraria*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A hierarchical, multi-stage GNN with pooling/unpooling captures global-to-local heat-transfer interactions in irregular CFD meshes, outperforming SOTA GNN baselines on a new natural-convection dataset.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To overcome CFD's high computational cost and reliance on expert physics by learning from data, addressing long-range dependencies and irregular mesh handling that challenge conventional GNNs.

Method: A novel multi-stage GNN architecture using hierarchical pooling and unpooling to progressively model global-to-local interactions across multiple spatial scales. Evaluated on a CFD dataset of natural convection in rectangular cavities with varying aspect ratios (bottom hot, top cold, vertical walls adiabatic).

Result: The model achieves higher predictive accuracy, improved training efficiency, and reduced long-term error accumulation compared with state-of-the-art GNN baselines.

Conclusion: The multi-stage GNN approach is promising for modeling complex heat transfer in mesh-based fluid dynamics and can accelerate design iterations in CFD.

Abstract: Buoyancy-driven heat transfer in closed cavities serves as a canonical
testbed for thermal design High-fidelity CFD modelling yields accurate thermal
field solutions, yet its reliance on expert-crafted physics models, fine
meshes, and intensive computation limits rapid iteration. Recent developments
in data-driven modeling, especially Graph Neural Networks (GNNs), offer new
alternatives for learning thermal-fluid behavior directly from simulation data,
particularly on irregular mesh structures. However, conventional GNNs often
struggle to capture long-range dependencies in high-resolution graph
structures. To overcome this limitation, we propose a novel multi-stage GNN
architecture that leverages hierarchical pooling and unpooling operations to
progressively model global-to-local interactions across multiple spatial
scales. We evaluate the proposed model on our newly developed CFD dataset
simulating natural convection within a rectangular cavities with varying aspect
ratios where the bottom wall is isothermal hot, the top wall is isothermal
cold, and the two vertical walls are adiabatic. Experimental results
demonstrate that the proposed model achieves higher predictive accuracy,
improved training efficiency, and reduced long-term error accumulation compared
to state-of-the-art (SOTA) GNN baselines. These findings underscore the
potential of the proposed multi-stage GNN approach for modeling complex heat
transfer in mesh-based fluid dynamics simulations.

</details>


### [86] [Home-made Diffusion Model from Scratch to Hatch](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06068)
*Shih-Ying Yeh*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: HDM is a diffusion model optimized for training and inference on consumer-grade hardware, achieving 1024x1024 quality with low training cost (~$535–$620 on four RTX5090 GPUs) using the Cross-U-Transformer (XUT) and a practical training recipe that enables smaller models to exhibit emergent capabilities.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Democratize high-quality text-to-image generation by reducing computational barriers, showing that smaller architectures with novel design can rival larger, resource-intensive models.

Method: Introduce Cross-U-Transformer (XUT), a U-shaped transformer with cross-attention in skip connections; propose a training recipe including TREAD acceleration, a shifted square crop strategy for efficient arbitrary aspect-ratio training, and progressive resolution scaling; demonstrate with small 343M-parameter models that yield high-quality results and emergent capabilities such as intuitive camera control; train/infer on four RTX5090 GPUs.

Result: Competitive 1024x1024 generation quality at very low training cost, and clear evidence that smaller models with careful architecture can deliver strong performance and emergent features, challenging the notion that large compute is essential for high-quality T2I.

Conclusion: Proposes a new scaling paradigm for diffusion models focused on training efficiency and accessibility, offering a viable path for individuals and small teams to democratize high-quality text-to-image generation without large-scale compute.

Abstract: We introduce Home-made Diffusion Model (HDM), an efficient yet powerful
text-to-image diffusion model optimized for training (and inferring) on
consumer-grade hardware. HDM achieves competitive 1024x1024 generation quality
while maintaining a remarkably low training cost of $535-620 using four RTX5090
GPUs, representing a significant reduction in computational requirements
compared to traditional approaches. Our key contributions include: (1)
Cross-U-Transformer (XUT), a novel U-shape transformer, Cross-U-Transformer
(XUT), that employs cross-attention for skip connections, providing superior
feature integration that leads to remarkable compositional consistency; (2) a
comprehensive training recipe that incorporates TREAD acceleration, a novel
shifted square crop strategy for efficient arbitrary aspect-ratio training, and
progressive resolution scaling; and (3) an empirical demonstration that smaller
models (343M parameters) with carefully crafted architectures can achieve
high-quality results and emergent capabilities, such as intuitive camera
control. Our work provides an alternative paradigm of scaling, demonstrating a
viable path toward democratizing high-quality text-to-image generation for
individual researchers and smaller organizations with limited computational
resources.

</details>


### [87] [High-Quality Tomographic Image Reconstruction Integrating Neural Networks and Mathematical Optimization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06082)
*Anuraag Mishra,Andrea Gilch,Benjamin Apeleo Zubiri,Jan Rolfes,Frauke Liers*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Neural-network–guided optimization improves edge preservation and material homogeneity in projection-based nano- and microtomography by predicting edges in subimages and constraining reconstructions with these priors while remaining data-consistent.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address blurriness and artifacts in tomographic reconstructions of specimens with homogeneous phases separated by sharp interfaces; leverage learned edge information to enforce sharp boundaries while preserving quantitative fidelity.

Method: Train a neural network to detect edges within subpictures; integrate predictions into a mathematical optimization framework that biases solutions toward the learned edges but can still be driven by raw projection data; use priors on homogeneity and sharp edges to suppress blur and artifacts.

Result: Demonstrated significant enhancements in interface sharpness and material homogeneity on experimental datasets compared with benchmark algorithms.

Conclusion: The approach effectively combines learned edge priors with data fidelity to produce higher-quality tomographic reconstructions, showcasing potential for advancing imaging techniques; future work could explore robustness, generalization, and scalability.

Abstract: In this work, we develop a novel technique for reconstructing images from
projection-based nano- and microtomography. Our contribution focuses on
enhancing reconstruction quality, particularly for specimen composed of
homogeneous material phases connected by sharp edges. This is accomplished by
training a neural network to identify edges within subpictures. The trained
network is then integrated into a mathematical optimization model, to reduce
artifacts from previous reconstructions. To this end, the optimization approach
favors solutions according to the learned predictions, however may also
determine alternative solutions if these are strongly supported by the raw
data. Hence, our technique successfully incorporates knowledge about the
homogeneity and presence of sharp edges in the sample and thereby eliminates
blurriness. Our results on experimental datasets show significant enhancements
in interface sharpness and material homogeneity compared to benchmark
algorithms. Thus, our technique produces high-quality reconstructions,
showcasing its potential for advancing tomographic imaging techniques.

</details>


### [88] [MedSeqFT: Sequential Fine-tuning Foundation Models for 3D Medical Image Segmentation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06096)
*Yiwen Ye,Yicheng Wu,Xiangde Luo,He Zhang,Ziyang Chen,Ting Dang,Yanning Zhang,Yong Xia*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Sequential fine-tuning with MDS sample selection and LoRA-based K&G RFT improves knowledge retention and transfer for multi-task 3D medical image segmentation, achieving average Dice gains (~3.0%) and better performance on unseen tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To overcome parallel fine-tuning's isolation of tasks and multi-task fine-tuning's need for all datasets and difficulty with incremental task addition, by preserving pre-training knowledge while adapting to new tasks.

Method: Two core components: (1) Maximum Data Similarity (MDS) selection to choose downstream samples representative of the pre-training distribution; (2) Knowledge and Generalization Retention Fine-Tuning (K&G RFT), a LoRA-based knowledge distillation approach that balances task-specific adaptation with retention of pre-trained knowledge—applied in a sequential fine-tuning pipeline across 3D segmentation tasks.

Result: MedSeqFT consistently outperforms state-of-the-art fine-tuning strategies across two multi-task datasets covering ten 3D segmentation tasks, with an average Dice improvement of 3.0%. Unseen tasks (COVID-19-20 and Kidney) show enhanced transferability, especially for tumor segmentation. Analyses of loss landscapes and parameter variations support robustness. Code will be released.

Conclusion: Sequential fine-tuning with MDS and K&G RFT is an effective, knowledge-retentive paradigm for adapting foundation models to evolving clinical tasks in medical image segmentation.

Abstract: Foundation models have become a promising paradigm for advancing medical
image analysis, particularly for segmentation tasks where downstream
applications often emerge sequentially. Existing fine-tuning strategies,
however, remain limited: parallel fine-tuning isolates tasks and fails to
exploit shared knowledge, while multi-task fine-tuning requires simultaneous
access to all datasets and struggles with incremental task integration. To
address these challenges, we propose MedSeqFT, a sequential fine-tuning
framework that progressively adapts pre-trained models to new tasks while
refining their representational capacity. MedSeqFT introduces two core
components: (1) Maximum Data Similarity (MDS) selection, which identifies
downstream samples most representative of the original pre-training
distribution to preserve general knowledge, and (2) Knowledge and
Generalization Retention Fine-Tuning (K&G RFT), a LoRA-based knowledge
distillation scheme that balances task-specific adaptation with the retention
of pre-trained knowledge. Extensive experiments on two multi-task datasets
covering ten 3D segmentation tasks demonstrate that MedSeqFT consistently
outperforms state-of-the-art fine-tuning strategies, yielding substantial
performance gains (e.g., an average Dice improvement of 3.0%). Furthermore,
evaluations on two unseen tasks (COVID-19-20 and Kidney) verify that MedSeqFT
enhances transferability, particularly for tumor segmentation. Visual analyses
of loss landscapes and parameter variations further highlight the robustness of
MedSeqFT. These results establish sequential fine-tuning as an effective,
knowledge-retentive paradigm for adapting foundation models to evolving
clinical tasks. Code will be released.

</details>


### [89] [PathoHR: Hierarchical Reasoning for Vision-Language Models in Pathology](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06105)
*Yating Huang,Ziyan Huang,Lintao Xiang,Qijun Yang,Hujun Yin*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A new pathology-focused benchmark PathoHR-Bench reveals limitations of current vision-language models in hierarchical and compositional reasoning for pathology, and a specialized VL training scheme yields state-of-the-art results on PathoHR-Bench and six other datasets.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Pathology images have high structural similarity and subtle variations; interpreting structured pathology reports requires complex cross-modal reasoning; existing vision-language models struggle to capture this in clinical settings.

Method: 1) Introduce PathoHR-Bench to evaluate hierarchical semantic understanding and compositional reasoning in pathology VL tasks. 2) Develop a pathology-specific VL training scheme that creates enhanced and perturbed samples for multimodal contrastive learning.

Result: Existing VL models fail to model intricate cross-modal relationships; the proposed method achieves state-of-the-art performance on PathoHR-Bench and six additional pathology datasets.

Conclusion: This work advances pathology-aware vision-language modeling and cross-modal reasoning, showing improved representation and performance across pathology datasets with potential clinical applicability.

Abstract: Accurate analysis of pathological images is essential for automated tumor
diagnosis but remains challenging due to high structural similarity and subtle
morphological variations in tissue images. Current vision-language (VL) models
often struggle to capture the complex reasoning required for interpreting
structured pathological reports. To address these limitations, we propose
PathoHR-Bench, a novel benchmark designed to evaluate VL models' abilities in
hierarchical semantic understanding and compositional reasoning within the
pathology domain. Results of this benchmark reveal that existing VL models fail
to effectively model intricate cross-modal relationships, hence limiting their
applicability in clinical setting. To overcome this, we further introduce a
pathology-specific VL training scheme that generates enhanced and perturbed
samples for multimodal contrastive learning. Experimental evaluations
demonstrate that our approach achieves state-of-the-art performance on
PathoHR-Bench and six additional pathology datasets, highlighting its
effectiveness in fine-grained pathology representation.

</details>


### [90] [CARDIE: clustering algorithm on relevant descriptors for image enhancement](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06116)
*Giulia Bonino,Luca Alberto Rizzo*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Unsupervised color/luminance clustering (CARDIE) yields image groups that align with enhancement tasks better than semantic clusters, enabling improved dataset resampling for tone mapping and denoising.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing image clustering emphasizes semantic categories, which may not capture color/brightness variations relevant to image enhancement. A clustering approach tailored to enhancement-relevant features could improve downstream enhancement algorithms.

Method: Introduce CARDIE, an unsupervised clustering algorithm using color and luminosity features to group images by enhancement-relevant content. Propose a metric to quantify how image enhancement algorithms affect luminance distribution and local variance. Demonstrate that CARDIE clusters correlate better with enhancement effects than semantic-based clusters and show that CARDIE-based resampling improves tone mapping and denoising performance. Release code publicly.

Result: CARDIE produces clusters more correlated with enhancement outcomes than those based on semantic attributes. Using CARDIE-driven resampling of training data for tone mapping and denoising improves algorithm performance. Code is released on GitHub to enable reproducibility.

Conclusion: Unsupervised, enhancement-focused clustering of images in color/luminance space yields more task-relevant groups and a practical method for improving image enhancement pipelines via targeted dataset resampling.

Abstract: Automatic image clustering is a cornerstone of computer vision, yet its
application to image enhancement remains limited, primarily due to the
difficulty of defining clusters that are meaningful for this specific task. To
address this issue, we introduce CARDIE, an unsupervised algorithm that
clusters images based on their color and luminosity content. In addition, we
introduce a method to quantify the impact of image enhancement algorithms on
luminance distribution and local variance. Using this method, we demonstrate
that CARDIE produces clusters more relevant to image enhancement than those
derived from semantic image attributes. Furthermore, we demonstrate that CARDIE
clusters can be leveraged to resample image enhancement datasets, leading to
improved performance for tone mapping and denoising algorithms. To encourage
adoption and ensure reproducibility, we publicly release CARDIE code on our
GitHub.

</details>


### [91] [SpecSwin3D: Generating Hyperspectral Imagery from Multispectral Data via Transformer Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06122)
*Tang Sui,Songxi Yang,Qunying Huang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: SpecSwin3D uses a transformer to generate hyperspectral imagery from multispectral inputs, with cascade training and optimized band sequencing to improve spatial-spectral fidelity; achieves state-of-the-art metrics and enables downstream tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Addresses the fundamental trade-off between spatial and spectral resolution in MS/Hyperspectral data and the limitations of prior methods in jointly preserving spatial detail and spectral fidelity.

Method: Proposes SpecSwin3D, a 3D shifted-window transformer that takes five multispectral bands and reconstructs 224 hyperspectral bands at the same resolution; introduces cascade training to gradually expand spectral range; designs an optimized band sequence that repeats and orders input bands to capture pairwise relations.

Result: Quantitative metrics: PSNR 35.82 dB, SAM 2.40 degrees, SSIM 0.96; outperforms baseline MHF-Net by +5.6 dB PSNR and halves ERGAS; validates usefulness on land use classification and burnt area segmentation.

Conclusion: SpecSwin3D effectively preserves spatial and spectral quality and demonstrates practical applicability; cascade training and band sequencing contribute to learning stability and fidelity; potential for broader remote sensing tasks.

Abstract: Multispectral and hyperspectral imagery are widely used in agriculture,
environmental monitoring, and urban planning due to their complementary spatial
and spectral characteristics. A fundamental trade-off persists: multispectral
imagery offers high spatial but limited spectral resolution, while
hyperspectral imagery provides rich spectra at lower spatial resolution. Prior
hyperspectral generation approaches (e.g., pan-sharpening variants, matrix
factorization, CNNs) often struggle to jointly preserve spatial detail and
spectral fidelity. In response, we propose SpecSwin3D, a transformer-based
model that generates hyperspectral imagery from multispectral inputs while
preserving both spatial and spectral quality. Specifically, SpecSwin3D takes
five multispectral bands as input and reconstructs 224 hyperspectral bands at
the same spatial resolution. In addition, we observe that reconstruction errors
grow for hyperspectral bands spectrally distant from the input bands. To
address this, we introduce a cascade training strategy that progressively
expands the spectral range to stabilize learning and improve fidelity.
Moreover, we design an optimized band sequence that strategically repeats and
orders the five selected multispectral bands to better capture pairwise
relations within a 3D shifted-window transformer framework. Quantitatively, our
model achieves a PSNR of 35.82 dB, SAM of 2.40{\deg}, and SSIM of 0.96,
outperforming the baseline MHF-Net by +5.6 dB in PSNR and reducing ERGAS by
more than half. Beyond reconstruction, we further demonstrate the practical
value of SpecSwin3D on two downstream tasks, including land use classification
and burnt area segmentation.

</details>


### [92] [RetinaGuard: Obfuscating Retinal Age in Fundus Images for Biometric Privacy Preserving](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06142)
*Zhengquan Luo,Chi Liu,Dongfu Xiao,Zhen Yu,Yueye Wang,Tianqing Zhu*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: RetinaGuard—a privacy-preserving framework that obfuscates retinal age prediction from fundus images using feature-level GAN masking and multi-encoder knowledge distillation, preserving diagnostic utility while blocking biometric leakage; extendable to other biomarkers.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Retinal age inferred from fundus images can indicate systemic risks and mortality, creating privacy risks of biometric data leakage from medical images; there is a need to prevent sensitive biomarker inference without harming clinical usefulness.

Method: A feature-level generative adversarial masking mechanism obscures retinal age in fundus images. It employs a multiple-to-one knowledge distillation strategy combining a retinal foundation model and diverse surrogate age encoders to defend against black-box age predictors.

Result: RetinaGuard successfully obfuscates retinal age predictions with minimal degradation to image quality and preservation of pathological features; adaptable to other biomarkers.

Conclusion: The framework provides a practical privacy-preserving solution for medical imaging biometrics, offering universal defense against age-predictors and extending to other biomarkers.

Abstract: The integration of AI with medical images enables the extraction of implicit
image-derived biomarkers for a precise health assessment. Recently, retinal
age, a biomarker predicted from fundus images, is a proven predictor of
systemic disease risks, behavioral patterns, aging trajectory and even
mortality. However, the capability to infer such sensitive biometric data
raises significant privacy risks, where unauthorized use of fundus images could
lead to bioinformation leakage, breaching individual privacy. In response, we
formulate a new research problem of biometric privacy associated with medical
images and propose RetinaGuard, a novel privacy-enhancing framework that
employs a feature-level generative adversarial masking mechanism to obscure
retinal age while preserving image visual quality and disease diagnostic
utility. The framework further utilizes a novel multiple-to-one knowledge
distillation strategy incorporating a retinal foundation model and diverse
surrogate age encoders to enable a universal defense against black-box age
prediction models. Comprehensive evaluations confirm that RetinaGuard
successfully obfuscates retinal age prediction with minimal impact on image
quality and pathological feature representation. RetinaGuard is also flexible
for extension to other medical image derived biomarkers. RetinaGuard is also
flexible for extension to other medical image biomarkers.

</details>


### [93] [UniVerse-1: Unified Audio-Video Generation via Stitching of Experts](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06155)
*Duomin Wang,Wei Zuo,Aojie Li,Ling-Hao Chen,Xinyao Liao,Deyu Zhou,Zixin Yin,Xili Dai,Daxin Jiang,Gang Yu*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: UniVerse-1 is a unified audio-video generator that stitches pre-trained video and music models to produce coordinated AV content, using an online annotation pipeline for alignment, finetuned on ~7.6k hours, and paired with Verse-Bench for evaluation; code and model are publicly released.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Overcoming training inefficiency and misalignment in joint audio-video generation by reusing strong pre-trained specialists and avoiding scratch training, while ensuring accurate temporal alignment between audio (ambient sounds and speech) and video.

Method: Use a stitching-of-experts (SoE) approach to deeply fuse blocks from pre-trained video and music generators; implement an online annotation pipeline that generates training labels during training to ensure proper ambient and speech alignment; finetune on ~7,600 hours of audio-video data; introduce Verse-Bench for systematic evaluation; publicly release model and code.

Result: The model yields well-coordinated ambient sound generation and strong speech alignment, approaching state-of-the-art performance and narrowing the gap to Veo3 on AV generation tasks; evaluation is supported by the Verse-Bench benchmark.

Conclusion: UniVerse-1, along with Verse-Bench and public release, aims to accelerate AV generation research by leveraging existing specialized models and ensuring precise temporal annotations, enabling more efficient training and potentially better coordination between audio and video.

Abstract: We introduce UniVerse-1, a unified, Veo-3-like model capable of
simultaneously generating coordinated audio and video. To enhance training
efficiency, we bypass training from scratch and instead employ a stitching of
experts (SoE) technique. This approach deeply fuses the corresponding blocks of
pre-trained video and music generation experts models, thereby fully leveraging
their foundational capabilities. To ensure accurate annotations and temporal
alignment for both ambient sounds and speech with video content, we developed
an online annotation pipeline that processes the required training data and
generates labels during training process. This strategy circumvents the
performance degradation often caused by misalignment text-based annotations.
Through the synergy of these techniques, our model, after being finetuned on
approximately 7,600 hours of audio-video data, produces results with
well-coordinated audio-visuals for ambient sounds generation and strong
alignment for speech generation. To systematically evaluate our proposed
method, we introduce Verse-Bench, a new benchmark dataset. In an effort to
advance research in audio-video generation and to close the performance gap
with state-of-the-art models such as Veo3, we make our model and code publicly
available. We hope this contribution will benefit the broader research
community. Project page: https://dorniwang.github.io/UniVerse-1/.

</details>


### [94] [UNO: Unifying One-stage Video Scene Graph Generation via Object-Centric Visual Representation Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06165)
*Huy Le,Nhat Chung,Tung Kieu,Jingkang Yang,Ngan Le*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: UNO is a single-stage, unified object-centric VidSGG framework that jointly handles box-level and pixel-level tasks using extended slot attention, temporal consistency, and dynamic triplet prediction, achieving competitive results with improved efficiency.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To unify coarse- and fine-grained VidSGG into a single architecture, reducing task-specific design and training complexity while enhancing generalization and efficiency.

Method: Extend slot attention to decompose features into object and relation slots; introduce object temporal consistency learning across frames without explicit tracking; implement dynamic triplet prediction linking relation slots to object pairs to model evolving interactions; train end-to-end in a single-stage framework with shared parameters.

Result: Competitive performance on standard box-level and pixel-level VidSGG benchmarks; improved efficiency due to single-stage, unified design and reduced task-specific modules.

Conclusion: A unified, single-stage object-centric approach is viable for multi-granularity VidSGG, with temporal consistency and dynamic relation modeling enabling robust cross-task generalization.

Abstract: Video Scene Graph Generation (VidSGG) aims to represent dynamic visual
content by detecting objects and modeling their temporal interactions as
structured graphs. Prior studies typically target either coarse-grained
box-level or fine-grained panoptic pixel-level VidSGG, often requiring
task-specific architectures and multi-stage training pipelines. In this paper,
we present UNO (UNified Object-centric VidSGG), a single-stage, unified
framework that jointly addresses both tasks within an end-to-end architecture.
UNO is designed to minimize task-specific modifications and maximize parameter
sharing, enabling generalization across different levels of visual granularity.
The core of UNO is an extended slot attention mechanism that decomposes visual
features into object and relation slots. To ensure robust temporal modeling, we
introduce object temporal consistency learning, which enforces consistent
object representations across frames without relying on explicit tracking
modules. Additionally, a dynamic triplet prediction module links relation slots
to corresponding object pairs, capturing evolving interactions over time. We
evaluate UNO on standard box-level and pixel-level VidSGG benchmarks. Results
demonstrate that UNO not only achieves competitive performance across both
tasks but also offers improved efficiency through a unified, object-centric
design.

</details>


### [95] [AI-Based Applied Innovation for Fracture Detection in X-rays Using Custom CNN and Transfer Learning Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06228)
*Amna Hassan,Ilsa Afzaal,Nouman Muneeb,Aneeqa Batool,Hamail Noor*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A lightweight CNN detects fractures in X-ray images with high accuracy on the FracAtlas dataset, outperforming transfer learning baselines in this setup. Emphasizes potential for low-resource settings, but results may be affected by class imbalance and dataset limitations; external validation is needed for clinical translation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Fracture localization/detection on X-rays is a critical need in low-resource settings where access to expert radiology is limited; AI can reduce costs, radiation exposure, and dependency on specialized interpretation.

Method: Developed a custom CNN for fracture detection on X-ray images and benchmarked it against transfer learning models (EfficientNetB0, MobileNetV2, ResNet50) using the FracAtlas dataset (4,083 radiographs). Evaluated using accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score.

Result: Custom CNN achieved 95.96% accuracy, 0.94 precision, 0.88 recall, and 0.91 F1-score on FracAtlas. Transfer learning models performed poorly in this setup, though interpretation is tempered by class imbalance and data limitations.

Conclusion: Lightweight CNNs show promise for automated fracture detection in X-rays, but fair benchmarking, diverse datasets, and external validation are essential for clinical translation.

Abstract: Bone fractures present a major global health challenge, often resulting in
pain, reduced mobility, and productivity loss, particularly in low-resource
settings where access to expert radiology services is limited. Conventional
imaging methods suffer from high costs, radiation exposure, and dependency on
specialized interpretation. To address this, we developed an AI-based solution
for automated fracture detection from X-ray images using a custom Convolutional
Neural Network (CNN) and benchmarked it against transfer learning models
including EfficientNetB0, MobileNetV2, and ResNet50. Training was conducted on
the publicly available FracAtlas dataset, comprising 4,083 anonymized
musculoskeletal radiographs. The custom CNN achieved 95.96% accuracy, 0.94
precision, 0.88 recall, and an F1-score of 0.91 on the FracAtlas dataset.
Although transfer learning models (EfficientNetB0, MobileNetV2, ResNet50)
performed poorly in this specific setup, these results should be interpreted in
light of class imbalance and data set limitations. This work highlights the
promise of lightweight CNNs for detecting fractures in X-rays and underscores
the importance of fair benchmarking, diverse datasets, and external validation
for clinical translation

</details>


### [96] [Exploring Light-Weight Object Recognition for Real-Time Document Detection](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06246)
*Lucas Wojcik,Luiz Coelho,Roger Granada,David Menotti*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: An efficient, real-time document detection/rectification pipeline tailored for OCR: adapt a lightweight detector (IWPOD-Net) to NBID synthetic IDs, augment data, and validate cross-dataset with MIDV; shows smaller, faster models can achieve competitive OCR quality without perfect rectification; code released.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Bridge the gap between high accuracy and real-time efficiency in document detection/rectification for OCR-based information retrieval; existing work focuses on large models or efficiency, but real-time pipelines for document rectification are underexplored.

Method: Adapt IWPOD-Net (license plate detector) for document corner detection on NBID synthetic ID cards; apply data augmentation; perform cross-dataset validation with MIDV; compare with state-of-the-art object recognition and skew estimation methods; rectify detected documents, run OCR, and evaluate OCR results using a Levenshtein-based metric.

Result: The proposed model is smaller and more efficient than current state-of-the-art methods while achieving competitive OCR quality; perfect rectification is not required to attain strong OCR performance; cross-dataset validation helps identify optimal configuration; code is released.

Conclusion: A lightweight, real-time document detection/rectification pipeline can deliver competitive OCR performance with reduced computational cost, demonstrating the viability of efficient models for practical automatic information retrieval from visual documents.

Abstract: Object Recognition and Document Skew Estimation have come a long way in terms
of performance and efficiency. New models follow one of two directions:
improving performance using larger models, and improving efficiency using
smaller models. However, real-time document detection and rectification is a
niche that is largely unexplored by the literature, yet it remains a vital step
for automatic information retrieval from visual documents. In this work, we
strive towards an efficient document detection pipeline that is satisfactory in
terms of Optical Character Recognition (OCR) retrieval and faster than other
available solutions. We adapt IWPOD-Net, a license plate detection network, and
train it for detection on NBID, a synthetic ID card dataset. We experiment with
data augmentation and cross-dataset validation with MIDV (another synthetic ID
and passport document dataset) to find the optimal scenario for the model.
Other methods from both the Object Recognition and Skew Estimation
state-of-the-art are evaluated for comparison with our approach. We use each
method to detect and rectify the document, which is then read by an OCR system.
The OCR output is then evaluated using a novel OCR quality metric based on the
Levenshtein distance. Since the end goal is to improve automatic information
retrieval, we use the overall OCR quality as a performance metric. We observe
that with a promising model, document rectification does not have to be perfect
to attain state-of-the-art performance scores. We show that our model is
smaller and more efficient than current state-of-the-art solutions while
retaining a competitive OCR quality metric. All code is available at
https://github.com/BOVIFOCR/iwpod-doc-corners.git

</details>


### [97] [Spatial Reasoning with Vision-Language Models in Ego-Centric Multi-View Scenes](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06266)
*Mohsen Gholami,Ahmad Rezaei,Zhou Weimin,Yong Zhang,Mohammad Akbari*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Proposes Ego3D-Bench for ego-centric, multi-view outdoor spatial reasoning of VLMs and Ego3D-VLM post-training to enhance 3D spatial understanding; reports improvements and a noticeable gap to human performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current VLMs struggle with 3D spatial relations in real-world, ego-centric multi-view data; need benchmarks and methods to close the gap.

Method: Construct Ego3D-Bench with 8,600+ QA pairs from ego-centric outdoor multi-view data; benchmark 16 SOTA VLMs; propose Ego3D-VLM post-training that builds a cognitive map from estimated global 3D coordinates; modular augmentation to existing VLMs.

Result: Humans outperform VLMs; Ego3D-VLM yields 12% average improvement on multi-choice QA and 56% on absolute distance estimation; dataset and method are modular.

Conclusion: Ego3D-Bench and Ego3D-VLM advance toward human-level 3D spatial understanding in real-world, multi-view settings and provide tools to bridge the gap.

Abstract: Understanding 3D spatial relationships remains a major limitation of current
Vision-Language Models (VLMs). Prior work has addressed this issue by creating
spatial question-answering (QA) datasets based on single images or indoor
videos. However, real-world embodied AI agents such as robots and self-driving
cars typically rely on ego-centric, multi-view observations. To this end, we
introduce Ego3D-Bench, a new benchmark designed to evaluate the spatial
reasoning abilities of VLMs using ego-centric, multi-view outdoor data.
Ego3D-Bench comprises over 8,600 QA pairs, created with significant involvement
from human annotators to ensure quality and diversity. We benchmark 16 SOTA
VLMs, including GPT-4o, Gemini1.5-Pro, InternVL3, and Qwen2.5-VL. Our results
reveal a notable performance gap between human level scores and VLM
performance, highlighting that current VLMs still fall short of human level
spatial understanding. To bridge this gap, we propose Ego3D-VLM, a
post-training framework that enhances 3D spatial reasoning of VLMs. Ego3D-VLM
generates cognitive map based on estimated global 3D coordinates, resulting in
12% average improvement on multi-choice QA and 56% average improvement on
absolute distance estimation. Ego3D-VLM is modular and can be integrated with
any existing VLM. Together, Ego3D-Bench and Ego3D-VLM offer valuable tools for
advancing toward human level spatial understanding in real-world, multi-view
environments.

</details>


### [98] [AI-driven Remote Facial Skin Hydration and TEWL Assessment from Selfie Images: A Systematic Solution](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06282)
*Cecelia Soh,Rizhao Cai,Monalisha Paul,Dennis Sng,Alex Kot*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A transformer-based framework to estimate skin hydration and TEWL from selfies, addressing data imbalance with symmetric-based contrastive regularization; first remote assessment of skin barrier without physical instruments.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Skin barrier integrity is crucial; SH and TEWL are key indicators; traditional measures require clinic instruments; need accessible remote monitoring for health and skincare.

Method: Data collection for SH/TEWL; preprocessing; Skin-Prior Adaptive Vision Transformer for SH/TEWL regression; symmetric-based contrastive regularization to mitigate annotation imbalance.

Result: Experiments show the approach can predict SH/TEWL from selfie images; the regularization reduces model bias due to imbalance; provides first demonstration of remote skin assessment without physical measurements.

Conclusion: This work bridges computer vision and dermatology, enabling AI-driven accessible skin analysis; potential for broader real-world applications in personal care and health monitoring.

Abstract: Skin health and disease resistance are closely linked to the skin barrier
function, which protects against environmental factors and water loss. Two key
physiological indicators can quantitatively represent this barrier function:
skin hydration (SH) and trans-epidermal water loss (TEWL). Measurement of SH
and TEWL is valuable for the public to monitor skin conditions regularly,
diagnose dermatological issues, and personalize their skincare regimens.
However, these measurements are not easily accessible to general users unless
they visit a dermatology clinic with specialized instruments. To tackle this
problem, we propose a systematic solution to estimate SH and TEWL from selfie
facial images remotely with smartphones. Our solution encompasses multiple
stages, including SH/TEWL data collection, data preprocessing, and formulating
a novel Skin-Prior Adaptive Vision Transformer model for SH/TEWL regression.
Through experiments, we identified the annotation imbalance of the SH/TEWL data
and proposed a symmetric-based contrastive regularization to reduce the model
bias due to the imbalance effectively. This work is the first study to explore
skin assessment from selfie facial images without physical measurements. It
bridges the gap between computer vision and skin care research, enabling
AI-driven accessible skin analysis for broader real-world applications.

</details>


### [99] [Prototype-Aware Multimodal Alignment for Open-Vocabulary Visual Grounding](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06291)
*Jiangnan Xie,Xiaolong Zheng,Liang Zheng*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A prototype-aware, multimodal framework (PAML) for visual grounding that improves open-vocabulary recognition by aligning vision-language representations, discriminative visual encoding, and semantic prototypes, using a multi-stage decoder; achieves state-of-the-art results in open-vocabulary VG and competitive performance in standard VG.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Open-vocabulary VG suffers from misalignment between visual and linguistic modalities, insufficient cross-modal feature fusion, and underutilization of semantic prototype information; current transformer-based methods excel in standard scenes but struggle with novel object categories during testing.

Method: 1) Use ALBEF to establish robust cross-modal alignment during initial feature encoding. 2) Visual Discriminative Feature Encoder enhances salience of object representations while suppressing irrelevant visual context. 3) Prototype discovering and inheriting mechanism extracts and aggregates multi-neighbor semantic prototypes to facilitate open-vocabulary recognition. 4) Multi-stage Decoder enables comprehensive multimodal integration and final bounding box regression. 5) Validation on five benchmark datasets demonstrates competitive standard VG performance and state-of-the-art open-vocabulary VG. Code available at the provided GitHub link.

Result: Competitive performance in standard scene; state-of-the-art results in open-vocabulary scene across five benchmarks; code released.

Conclusion: PAML addresses the key challenges of cross-modal alignment, feature fusion, and semantic prototype utilization, improving open-vocabulary visual grounding and showing strong potential for generalization and future enhancement.

Abstract: Visual Grounding (VG) aims to utilize given natural language queries to
locate specific target objects within images. While current transformer-based
approaches demonstrate strong localization performance in standard scene (i.e,
scenarios without any novel objects), they exhibit notable limitations in
open-vocabulary scene (i.e, both familiar and novel object categories during
testing). These limitations primarily stem from three key factors: (1)
imperfect alignment between visual and linguistic modalities, (2) insufficient
cross-modal feature fusion, and (3) ineffective utilization of semantic
prototype information. To overcome these challenges, we present Prototype-Aware
Multimodal Learning (PAML), an innovative framework that systematically
addresses these issues through several key components: First, we leverage ALBEF
to establish robust cross-modal alignment during initial feature encoding.
Subsequently, our Visual Discriminative Feature Encoder selectively enhances
salient object representations while suppressing irrelevant visual context. The
framework then incorporates a novel prototype discovering and inheriting
mechanism that extracts and aggregates multi-neighbor semantic prototypes to
facilitate open-vocabulary recognition. These enriched features undergo
comprehensive multimodal integration through our Multi-stage Decoder before
final bounding box regression. Extensive experiments across five benchmark
datasets validate our approach, showing competitive performance in standard
scene while achieving state-of-the-art results in open-vocabulary scene. Our
code is available at https://github.com/plankXie/PAML.

</details>


### [100] [Video-based Generalized Category Discovery via Memory-Guided Consistency-Aware Contrastive Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06306)
*Zhang Jing,Pu Nan,Xie Yu Xiang,Guo Yanming,Lu Qianqi,Zou Shiwei,Yan Jie,Chen Yan*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Proposes Video-GCD, a video extension of Generalized Category Discovery, and MCCL—a memory-guided, consistency-aware contrastive learning framework with CACL and MGRE—to exploit temporal-spatial cues; introduces a new Video-GCD benchmark and reports strong improvements over image-based GCD baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Generalized Category Discovery (GCD) has focused on static images. Videos offer rich temporal information but present open-world discovery challenges. The work aims to leverage temporal dynamics to improve novel-category discovery in videos.

Method: MCCL框架 with two components: (1) Consistency-Aware Contrastive Learning (CACL): uses multiperspective temporal features to estimate consistency scores among unlabeled instances and weights the contrastive loss accordingly. (2) Memory-Guided Representation Enhancement (MGRE): employs a dual-level memory buffer storing both feature-level and logit-level representations to provide global context, improving intra-class compactness and inter-class separability; forms a feedback loop between representation learning and consistency modeling.

Result: New Video-GCD benchmark created, including action recognition and bird classification datasets. Extensive experiments show the proposed MCCL method substantially outperforms competitive image-based GCD methods adapted to video, demonstrating the value of temporal information for discovering novel categories in video data.

Conclusion: Temporal information is crucial for Video-GCD. The MCCL framework effectively leverages temporal cues via CACL and MGRE, and the mutual reinforcement between consistency modeling and representation learning yields strong performance; the authors will release code.

Abstract: Generalized Category Discovery (GCD) is an emerging and challenging
open-world problem that has garnered increasing attention in recent years. Most
existing GCD methods focus on discovering categories in static images. However,
relying solely on static visual content is often insufficient to reliably
discover novel categories. To bridge this gap, we extend the GCD problem to the
video domain and introduce a new setting, termed Video-GCD. Thus, effectively
integrating multi-perspective information across time is crucial for accurate
Video-GCD. To tackle this challenge, we propose a novel Memory-guided
Consistency-aware Contrastive Learning (MCCL) framework, which explicitly
captures temporal-spatial cues and incorporates them into contrastive learning
through a consistency-guided voting mechanism. MCCL consists of two core
components: Consistency-Aware Contrastive Learning(CACL) and Memory-Guided
Representation Enhancement (MGRE). CACL exploits multiperspective temporal
features to estimate consistency scores between unlabeled instances, which are
then used to weight the contrastive loss accordingly. MGRE introduces a
dual-level memory buffer that maintains both feature-level and logit-level
representations, providing global context to enhance intra-class compactness
and inter-class separability. This in turn refines the consistency estimation
in CACL, forming a mutually reinforcing feedback loop between representation
learning and consistency modeling. To facilitate a comprehensive evaluation, we
construct a new and challenging Video-GCD benchmark, which includes action
recognition and bird classification video datasets. Extensive experiments
demonstrate that our method significantly outperforms competitive GCD
approaches adapted from image-based settings, highlighting the importance of
temporal information for discovering novel categories in videos. The code will
be publicly available.

</details>


### [101] [Text4Seg++: Advancing Image Segmentation via Generative Language Modeling](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06321)
*Mengcheng Lan,Chaofeng Chen,Jiaxing Xu,Zongrui Li,Yiping Ke,Xudong Jiang,Yingchen Yu,Yunqing Zhao,Song Bai*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Text-driven segmentation for Multimodal LLMs using semantic descriptors. From image-wise patch-aligned descriptors to box-wise semantic bricks, enhanced by Row-wise Run-Length Encoding (R-RLE). The Text4Seg framework (and its refinement Text4Seg++) achieves state-of-the-art results on natural and remote sensing data without task-specific fine-tuning, while improving efficiency and maintaining compatibility with existing LLM backbones.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Integrating image segmentation into Multimodal LLMs remains challenging due to reliance on additional decoders and separate segmentation heads. A unified, text-based representation—casting segmentation as text generation—promises simplicity, scalability, and seamless integration with language models.

Method: Introduce semantic descriptors that map each image patch to a text label. Start with image-wise descriptors aligned to patches and employ Row-wise Run-Length Encoding (R-RLE) to compress repeated sequences, reducing descriptor length by 74% and speeding up inference by 3x. Build Text4Seg around this representation. Further develop box-wise descriptors using bounding boxes and structured tokens called semantic bricks, enabling a next-brick prediction objective in Text4Seg++.

Result: Text4Seg achieves strong segmentation across diverse vision tasks without task-specific fine-tuning. Text4Seg++ consistently outperforms state-of-the-art models on natural and remote sensing datasets, with efficiency gains (less text, faster inference) and full compatibility with existing MLLM backbones.

Conclusion: Text-driven image segmentation within MLLMs is effective, scalable, and generalizable. The proposed semantic-descriptor framework (image-wise and box-wise) offers a compact, efficient, and high-performing alternative to decoder-heavy segmentation approaches, evidencing broad applicability across domains.

Abstract: Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) have shown exceptional capabilities
in vision-language tasks. However, effectively integrating image segmentation
into these models remains a significant challenge. In this work, we propose a
novel text-as-mask paradigm that casts image segmentation as a text generation
problem, eliminating the need for additional decoders and significantly
simplifying the segmentation process. Our key innovation is semantic
descriptors, a new textual representation of segmentation masks where each
image patch is mapped to its corresponding text label. We first introduce
image-wise semantic descriptors, a patch-aligned textual representation of
segmentation masks that integrates naturally into the language modeling
pipeline. To enhance efficiency, we introduce the Row-wise Run-Length Encoding
(R-RLE), which compresses redundant text sequences, reducing the length of
semantic descriptors by 74% and accelerating inference by $3\times$, without
compromising performance. Building upon this, our initial framework Text4Seg
achieves strong segmentation performance across a wide range of vision tasks.
To further improve granularity and compactness, we propose box-wise semantic
descriptors, which localizes regions of interest using bounding boxes and
represents region masks via structured mask tokens called semantic bricks. This
leads to our refined model, Text4Seg++, which formulates segmentation as a
next-brick prediction task, combining precision, scalability, and generative
efficiency. Comprehensive experiments on natural and remote sensing datasets
show that Text4Seg++ consistently outperforms state-of-the-art models across
diverse benchmarks without any task-specific fine-tuning, while remaining
compatible with existing MLLM backbones. Our work highlights the effectiveness,
scalability, and generalizability of text-driven image segmentation within the
MLLM framework.

</details>


### [102] [Towards scalable organ level 3D plant segmentation: Bridging the data algorithm computing gap](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06329)
*Ruiming Du,Guangxun Zhai,Tian Qiu,Yu Jiang*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A comprehensive survey and benchmarking framework for 3D plant segmentation, addressing data scarcity, model adaptation, and benchmark standardization, with findings favoring sparse convolutions, transformers, and sim-to-real data strategies.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To advance 3D plant phenotyping by enabling accurate, scalable segmentation of plant point clouds through data-efficient learning and reproducible benchmarks.

Method: Systematically review existing 3D plant datasets in general 3D segmentation contexts; summarize deep learning methods for point cloud semantic and instance segmentation; introduce Plant Segmentation Studio (PSS) as an open-source, reproducible benchmarking framework; perform extensive quantitative experiments to compare networks and sim-to-real strategies.

Result: Sparse convolutional backbones and transformer-based instance segmentation are effective for plant point clouds; synthetic data generation and augmentation support sim-to-real learning, reducing annotation needs; PSS enables reproducible benchmarking; data and code are released (GitHub).

Conclusion: The work bridges algorithmic advances and practical deployment in 3D plant phenotyping, providing a usable toolkit and a roadmap for data-efficient, generalizable segmentation approaches.

Abstract: The precise characterization of plant morphology provides valuable insights
into plant environment interactions and genetic evolution. A key technology for
extracting this information is 3D segmentation, which delineates individual
plant organs from complex point clouds. Despite significant progress in general
3D computer vision domains, the adoption of 3D segmentation for plant
phenotyping remains limited by three major challenges: i) the scarcity of
large-scale annotated datasets, ii) technical difficulties in adapting advanced
deep neural networks to plant point clouds, and iii) the lack of standardized
benchmarks and evaluation protocols tailored to plant science. This review
systematically addresses these barriers by: i) providing an overview of
existing 3D plant datasets in the context of general 3D segmentation domains,
ii) systematically summarizing deep learning-based methods for point cloud
semantic and instance segmentation, iii) introducing Plant Segmentation Studio
(PSS), an open-source framework for reproducible benchmarking, and iv)
conducting extensive quantitative experiments to evaluate representative
networks and sim-to-real learning strategies. Our findings highlight the
efficacy of sparse convolutional backbones and transformer-based instance
segmentation, while also emphasizing the complementary role of modeling-based
and augmentation-based synthetic data generation for sim-to-real learning in
reducing annotation demands. In general, this study bridges the gap between
algorithmic advances and practical deployment, providing immediate tools for
researchers and a roadmap for developing data-efficient and generalizable deep
learning solutions in 3D plant phenotyping. Data and code are available at
https://github.com/perrydoremi/PlantSegStudio.

</details>


### [103] [Quantitative Currency Evaluation in Low-Resource Settings through Pattern Analysis to Assist Visually Impaired Users](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06331)
*Md Sultanul Islam Ovi,Mainul Hossain,Md Badsha Biswas*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Unified, lightweight currency evaluation framework combining denomination classification (Custom_CNN), damage quantification via UCDI, and counterfeit detection through template matching, validated on 82k images with real-time on-device performance.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address usability and authenticity assessment gaps in currency recognition, especially in low-resource settings with visually impaired users and offline validation, and to handle degradation and forgery not covered by existing denomination classifiers.

Method: Three modules: lightweight CNN for denomination; Unified Currency Damage Index (UCDI) combining binary mask loss, chromatic distortion, and structural feature loss for damage assessment; feature-based template matching for counterfeit detection; dataset of 82k annotated images (clean, damaged, counterfeit); aims for real-time on-device inference.

Result: Custom_CNN achieves high classification performance with low parameter count; UCDI provides a continuous usability score; counterfeit detection robust across varied imaging conditions; framework enables accurate, interpretable, compact currency evaluation suitable for constrained environments.

Conclusion: A cohesive, on-device framework that unifies usability, damage, and authenticity assessment for currency, enabling inclusive, real-world deployment in low-resource settings.

Abstract: Currency recognition systems often overlook usability and authenticity
assessment, especially in low-resource environments where visually impaired
users and offline validation are common. While existing methods focus on
denomination classification, they typically ignore physical degradation and
forgery, limiting their applicability in real-world conditions. This paper
presents a unified framework for currency evaluation that integrates three
modules: denomination classification using lightweight CNN models, damage
quantification through a novel Unified Currency Damage Index (UCDI), and
counterfeit detection using feature-based template matching. The dataset
consists of over 82,000 annotated images spanning clean, damaged, and
counterfeit notes. Our Custom_CNN model achieves high classification
performance with low parameter count. The UCDI metric provides a continuous
usability score based on binary mask loss, chromatic distortion, and structural
feature loss. The counterfeit detection module demonstrates reliable
identification of forged notes across varied imaging conditions. The framework
supports real-time, on-device inference and addresses key deployment challenges
in constrained environments. Results show that accurate, interpretable, and
compact solutions can support inclusive currency evaluation in practical
settings.

</details>


### [104] [Harnessing Object Grounding for Time-Sensitive Video Understanding](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06335)
*Tz-Ying Wu,Sharath Nittur Sridhar,Subarna Tripathi*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: GO-Tokenizer adds a lightweight, compact object encoding to video-LLMs to improve time-sensitive video understanding without inflating prompts.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Time-sensitive video understanding (TSV) tasks can benefit from grounding within frames by objects; while describing objects in text helps, it increases token length and introduces noise.

Method: Introduce GO-Tokenizer which uses off-the-shelf object detectors to encode compact object information on the fly for Video-LLMs; pretrained with GO-Tokenizer and evaluated on LITA, across tasks such as temporal localization and dense captioning.

Result: GO-Tokenizer-based pretraining outperforms vanilla Video-LLMs and approaches using textual object descriptions, with results generalizing across models, datasets, and tasks.

Conclusion: Grounded object encoding via GO-Tokenizer improves TSV in Video-LLMs by providing compact, robust object information, reducing prompt length and noise while enhancing performance across tasks and models.

Abstract: We propose to improve the time-sensitive video understanding (TSV) capability
of video large language models (Video-LLMs) with grounded objects (GO). We
hypothesize that TSV tasks can benefit from GO within frames, which is
supported by our preliminary experiments on LITA, a state-of-the-art Video-LLM
for reasoning temporal localization. While augmenting prompts with textual
description of these object annotations improves the performance of LITA, it
also introduces extra token length and susceptibility to the noise in object
level information. To address this, we propose GO-Tokenizer, a lightweight
add-on module for Video-LLMs leveraging off-the-shelf object detectors to
encode compact object information on the fly. Experimental results demonstrate
that pretraining with GO-Tokenizer outperforms the vanilla Video-LLM and its
counterpart utilizing textual description of objects in the prompt. The gain
generalizes across different models, datasets and video understanding tasks
such as reasoning temporal localization and dense captioning.

</details>


### [105] [Multi View Slot Attention Using Paraphrased Texts For Face Anti-Spoofing](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06336)
*Jeongmin Yu,Susang Kim,Kisu Lee,Taekyoung Kwon,Won-Yong Shin,Ha Young Kim*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A CLIP-based face anti-spoofing method MVP-FAS uses two modules, MVS and MTPA, to exploit patch embeddings and multiple paraphrased texts for better cross-domain generalization.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing CLIP-based FAS methods underutilize patch embedding tokens and rely on a single text prompt per class, limiting detection of spoofing cues and domain generalization.

Method: MVP-FAS introduces Multi-View Slot attention (MVS) to extract local spatial details and global context from patch embeddings using multiple paraphrased texts; and Multi-Text Patch Alignment (MTPA) to align image patches with multiple text representations, enhancing semantic robustness and reducing dependence on domain-specific text.

Result: Extensive experiments show MVP-FAS achieves superior generalization, outperforming prior state-of-the-art methods on cross-domain face anti-spoofing datasets.

Conclusion: MVP-FAS effectively leverages CLIP patch tokens and paraphrased text prompts to improve cross-domain FAS performance, with available code at the provided repository.

Abstract: Recent face anti-spoofing (FAS) methods have shown remarkable cross-domain
performance by employing vision-language models like CLIP. However, existing
CLIP-based FAS models do not fully exploit CLIP's patch embedding tokens,
failing to detect critical spoofing clues. Moreover, these models rely on a
single text prompt per class (e.g., 'live' or 'fake'), which limits
generalization. To address these issues, we propose MVP-FAS, a novel framework
incorporating two key modules: Multi-View Slot attention (MVS) and Multi-Text
Patch Alignment (MTPA). Both modules utilize multiple paraphrased texts to
generate generalized features and reduce dependence on domain-specific text.
MVS extracts local detailed spatial features and global context from patch
embeddings by leveraging diverse texts with multiple perspectives. MTPA aligns
patches with multiple text representations to improve semantic robustness.
Extensive experiments demonstrate that MVP-FAS achieves superior generalization
performance, outperforming previous state-of-the-art methods on cross-domain
datasets. Code: https://github.com/Elune001/MVP-FAS.

</details>


### [106] [A Multi-Modal Deep Learning Framework for Colorectal Pathology Diagnosis: Integrating Histological and Colonoscopy Data in a Pilot Study](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06351)
*Krithik Ramesh,Ritvik Koneru*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A pilot unified CNN pipeline (ResNet-50) classifies both histology slides (PathMNIST) and colonoscopy frames (HyperKvasir) in a single network, using class-balancing, augmentation, and calibration to improve colorectal disease diagnosis; claims interpretability and reproducibility.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Colorectal diseases require fast, accurate diagnosis. Traditional pipelines rely on separate histology and colonoscopy analyses, which can introduce variability and inefficiency. A unified approach could streamline workflow and reduce diagnostic inconsistencies.

Method: A single CNN (ResNet-50) architecture employed with class-balancing learning, robust augmentation, and calibration. The model is trained on static histology images from PathMNIST and colonoscopy frames from HyperKvasir, aiming to handle multiple diagnostic modalities within one pipeline.

Result: Demonstrates a unified, interpretable, and reproducible diagnostic pipeline that combines multiple diagnostic modalities (histology and colonoscopy) to aid colorectal disease detection.

Conclusion: A unified deep learning pipeline for colorectal diagnostics that integrates histology and endoscopy data can streamline workflows, potentially reducing variability and improving speed and accuracy in disease detection.

Abstract: Colorectal diseases, including inflammatory conditions and neoplasms, require
quick, accurate care to be effectively treated. Traditional diagnostic
pipelines require extensive preparation and rely on separate, individual
evaluations on histological images and colonoscopy footage, introducing
possible variability and inefficiencies. This pilot study proposes a unified
deep learning network that uses convolutional neural networks (CN N s) to
classify both histopathological slides and colonoscopy video frames in one
pipeline. The pipeline integrates class-balancing learning, robust
augmentation, and calibration methods to ensure accurate results. Static colon
histology images were taken from the PathMNIST dataset, and the lower
gastrointestinal (colonoscopy) videos were drawn from the HyperKvasir dataset.
The CNN architecture used was ResNet-50. This study demonstrates an
interpretable and reproducible diagnostic pipeline that unifies multiple
diagnostic modalities to advance and ease the detection of colorectal diseases.

</details>


### [107] [MRD-LiNet: A Novel Lightweight Hybrid CNN with Gradient-Guided Unlearning for Improved Drought Stress Identification](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06367)
*Aswini Kumar Patra,Lingaraj Sahoo*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: A lightweight hybrid CNN for drought stress detection from aerial potato-field images, featuring a 15x reduction in trainable parameters and a gradient-norm-based unlearning mechanism, achieving competitive accuracy suitable for resource-limited precision agriculture.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Drought stress detection is crucial for crop management, but traditional CNNs/ViTs are parameter-heavy and ill-suited for resource-constrained, real-time settings; thus there is a need for efficient models and adaptable learning via targeted data removal.

Method: Develop a lightweight hybrid CNN inspired by ResNet, DenseNet, and MobileNet to substantially reduce trainable parameters (about 15-fold) while maintaining accuracy. Introduce a gradient-norm-based influence function-based machine unlearning to selectively remove the influence of specific training data, enabling adaptability. Evaluated on an aerial image dataset of potato fields with expert-annotated healthy and drought-stressed regions.

Result: Achieves high accuracy with substantially lower computational costs, notably a 15x reduction in trainable parameters compared to conventional CNNs/ViTs, demonstrated on the potato-field aerial dataset.

Conclusion: Proposes a practical, scalable, and adaptive solution for drought stress monitoring in precision agriculture, particularly suitable for resource-constrained environments.

Abstract: Drought stress is a major threat to global crop productivity, making its
early and precise detection essential for sustainable agricultural management.
Traditional approaches, though useful, are often time-consuming and
labor-intensive, which has motivated the adoption of deep learning methods. In
recent years, Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) and Vision Transformer
architectures have been widely explored for drought stress identification;
however, these models generally rely on a large number of trainable parameters,
restricting their use in resource-limited and real-time agricultural settings.
To address this challenge, we propose a novel lightweight hybrid CNN framework
inspired by ResNet, DenseNet, and MobileNet architectures. The framework
achieves a remarkable 15-fold reduction in trainable parameters compared to
conventional CNN and Vision Transformer models, while maintaining competitive
accuracy. In addition, we introduce a machine unlearning mechanism based on a
gradient norm-based influence function, which enables targeted removal of
specific training data influence, thereby improving model adaptability. The
method was evaluated on an aerial image dataset of potato fields with
expert-annotated healthy and drought-stressed regions. Experimental results
show that our framework achieves high accuracy while substantially lowering
computational costs. These findings highlight its potential as a practical,
scalable, and adaptive solution for drought stress monitoring in precision
agriculture, particularly under resource-constrained conditions.

</details>


### [108] [Your Super Resolution Model is not Enough for Tackling Real-World Scenarios](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06387)
*Dongsik Yoon,Jongeun Kim*

Main category: cs.CV

TL;DR: Plug-in Scale-Aware Attention Module (SAAM) enables arbitrary-scale SR for fixed-scale models with lightweight scale-adaptive feature extraction/upsampling, SimAM guidance, and gradient variance loss, and integrates with backbones like SCNet, HiT-SR, OverNet to deliver robust multi-scale upscaling with low overhead.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: SR models trained for fixed scale factors often fail to generalize to unseen integer/non-integer scales, hindering real-world deployment. A lightweight, plug-in solution that enables arbitrary-scale SR without retraining large backbones is needed.

Method: Introduce SAAM as a plug-in module that provides scale-aware feature extraction and upsampling. It uses the SimAM (a lightweight attention mechanism) for guidance and adds a gradient variance loss to sharpen details. The module is designed to retrofit existing SR backbones (e.g., SCNet, HiT-SR, OverNet) to handle arbitrary-scale factors (both integer and non-integer).

Result: SAAM achieves competitive or superior performance across a wide range of both integer and non-integer scales, with minimal additional computational overhead, validated on standard SR benchmarks.

Conclusion: SAAM offers a practical, plug-in solution for real-world arbitrary-scale SR by enabling scale-awareness in fixed-scale SR models, maintaining efficiency while improving robustness across diverse scale factors.

Abstract: Despite remarkable progress in Single Image Super-Resolution (SISR),
traditional models often struggle to generalize across varying scale factors,
limiting their real-world applicability. To address this, we propose a plug-in
Scale-Aware Attention Module (SAAM) designed to retrofit modern fixed-scale SR
models with the ability to perform arbitrary-scale SR. SAAM employs
lightweight, scale-adaptive feature extraction and upsampling, incorporating
the Simple parameter-free Attention Module (SimAM) for efficient guidance and
gradient variance loss to enhance sharpness in image details. Our method
integrates seamlessly into multiple state-of-the-art SR backbones (e.g., SCNet,
HiT-SR, OverNet), delivering competitive or superior performance across a wide
range of integer and non-integer scale factors. Extensive experiments on
benchmark datasets demonstrate that our approach enables robust multi-scale
upscaling with minimal computational overhead, offering a practical solution
for real-world scenarios.

</details>
