shopping, wearables, and voice, yet it remains challenged by sparse
interactions, fast content churn, and heterogeneous textual signals. We present
RecMind, an LLM-enhanced graph recommender that treats the language model as a
preference prior rather than a monolithic ranker. A frozen LLM equipped with
lightweight adapters produces text-conditioned user/item embeddings from
titles, attributes, and reviews; a LightGCN backbone learns collaborative
embeddings from the user-item graph. We align the two views with a symmetric
contrastive objective and fuse them via intra-layer gating, allowing language
to dominate in cold/long-tail regimes and graph structure to stabilize rankings
elsewhere. On Yelp and Amazon-Electronics, RecMind attains the best results on
all eight reported metrics, with relative improvements up to +4.53\%
(Recall@40) and +4.01\% (NDCG@40) over strong baselines. Ablations confirm both
the necessity of cross-view alignment and the advantage of gating over late
fusion and LLM-only variants.

</details>


### [218] [A Spatio-Temporal Graph Neural Networks Approach for Predicting Silent Data Corruption inducing Circuit-Level Faults](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06289)
*Shaoqi Wei,Senling Wang,Hiroshi Kai,Yoshinobu Higami,Ruijun Ma,Tianming Ni,Xiaoqing Wen,Hiroshi Takahashi*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: ST-GCN model on gate-level netlists predicts multi-cycle fault impact probabilities quickly with high accuracy, delivering 10x speedups and enabling scalable SoC risk assessment and test-point optimization.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: SDEs from time-zero defects and aging threaten safety-critical systems; functional testing is costly; need fast, accurate long-cycle fault impact predictions for risk assessment and test planning.

Method: Model gate-level netlists as spatio-temporal graphs; use dedicated spatial and temporal encoders in a unified ST-GCN to predict multi-cycle FIPs; accepts features from testability metrics or fault simulation; performance evaluated on ISCAS-89; includes test-point selection study; scales to SoC-level and EDA workflows.

Result: >10x simulation time reduction; MAE 0.024 for 5-cycle predictions; robust accuracy; observation-point selection by predicted FIPs improves detection of long-cycle hard faults.

Conclusion: ST-GCN offers fast, accurate FIP prediction, enabling efficient risk assessment and test strategy optimization for SDE-prone circuits and integration into EDA pipelines.

Abstract: Silent Data Errors (SDEs) from time-zero defects and aging degrade
safety-critical systems. Functional testing detects SDE-related faults but is
expensive to simulate. We present a unified spatio-temporal graph convolutional
network (ST-GCN) for fast, accurate prediction of long-cycle fault impact
probabilities (FIPs) in large sequential circuits, supporting quantitative risk
assessment. Gate-level netlists are modeled as spatio-temporal graphs to
capture topology and signal timing; dedicated spatial and temporal encoders
predict multi-cycle FIPs efficiently. On ISCAS-89 benchmarks, the method
reduces simulation time by more than 10x while maintaining high accuracy (mean
absolute error 0.024 for 5-cycle predictions). The framework accepts features
from testability metrics or fault simulation, allowing efficiency-accuracy
trade-offs. A test-point selection study shows that choosing observation points
by predicted FIPs improves detection of long-cycle, hard-to-detect faults. The
approach scales to SoC-level test strategy optimization and fits downstream
electronic design automation flows.

</details>


### [219] [LoaQ: Layer-wise Output Approximation Quantization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06297)
*Li Lin,Xiaojun Wan*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: LoaQ is an output-consistency layer-wise post-training quantization method that better aligns quantized outputs with full-model outputs, offering a closed-form solution, easy integration, and improved quantization quality demonstrated on LLaMA and Qwen.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Layer-wise PTQ typically optimizes locally and yields only activation-aware weight approximations, which can poorly reflect the full model’s outputs. For large language models with specific structural characteristics, there is a need for explicit output-level consistency to improve quantization fidelity.

Method: Introduce LoaQ, an output-approximation objective for layer-wise PTQ that explicitly targets output-level consistency. It offers a simple closed-form solution and is designed to be orthogonal to existing techniques, enabling seamless integration into current quantization pipelines.

Result: Empirical results on the LLaMA and Qwen model families show LoaQ is effective for both weight-only and weight-activation joint quantization, and it can be integrated with existing quantization strategies to improve overall quantization quality.

Conclusion: LoaQ advances post-training quantization by prioritizing output-level alignment, is easily integrable, and holds strong potential to push the frontier of PTQ for LLMs.

Abstract: A natural and intuitive idea in model quantization is to approximate each
component's quantized output to match its original. Layer-wise post-training
quantization (PTQ), though based on this idea, adopts a strictly local view and
can achieve, at best, only activation-aware approximations of weights. As a
result, it often leads to insufficient approximations and practical deviations
from this guiding intuition. Recent work has achieved a more accurate
approximation of linear-layer outputs within the framework of layer-wise PTQ,
but such refinements remain inadequate for achieving alignment with the full
model output. Based on a deeper understanding of the structural characteristics
of mainstream LLMs, we propose $LoaQ$, an output-approximation method for
layer-wise PTQ that explicitly targets output-level consistency. It better
aligns with this intuition and can feature a simple closed-form solution,
making it orthogonal to existing techniques and readily integrable into
existing quantization pipelines. Experiments on the LLaMA and Qwen model
families demonstrate that LoaQ performs effectively in both weight-only and
weight-activation joint quantization. By integrating seamlessly with existing
quantization strategies, it further enhances overall quantization quality and
shows strong potential to advance the frontier of post-training quantization.

</details>


### [220] [WindFM: An Open-Source Foundation Model for Zero-Shot Wind Power Forecasting](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06311)
*Hang Fan,Yu Shi,Zongliang Fu,Shuo Chen,Wei Wei,Wei Xu,Jian Li*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: WindFM is a lightweight generative foundation model for probabilistic wind power forecasting that uses a discretize-and-generate pipeline with a time-series tokenizer and decoder-only Transformer, achieving state-of-the-art zero-shot performance across deterministic and probabilistic tasks and robust OOD transfer, with 8.1M parameters and no fine-tuning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To overcome generalization limits of site-specific wind forecasting models and the difficulty of injecting domain data into general-purpose foundation models, by building a domain-focused, transferable foundation model for wind power.

Method: Discretize continuous multivariate data into discrete tokens via a time-series tokenizer; train a decoder-only Transformer autoregressively on token sequences; pre-train on WIND Toolkit (~150B time steps from 126k sites) to capture wind–power dynamics; evaluate zero-shot on deterministic and probabilistic forecasting tasks; assess robustness to out-of-distribution data from a different continent; model size 8.1M; public code.

Result: Achieves state-of-the-art zero-shot performance on both deterministic and probabilistic forecasting tasks without fine-tuning; outperforms specialized models and larger foundation models; demonstrates robustness under out-of-distribution continental data.

Conclusion: WindFM provides a compact, generalizable foundation model tailored for wind power forecasting, enabling accurate, robust probabilistic forecasts without site-specific fine-tuning, and offers public access to the pretrained model.

Abstract: High-quality wind power forecasting is crucial for the operation of modern
power grids. However, prevailing data-driven paradigms either train a
site-specific model which cannot generalize to other locations or rely on
fine-tuning of general-purpose time series foundation models which are
difficult to incorporate domain-specific data in the energy sector. This paper
introduces WindFM, a lightweight and generative Foundation Model designed
specifically for probabilistic wind power forecasting. WindFM employs a
discretize-and-generate framework. A specialized time-series tokenizer first
converts continuous multivariate observations into discrete, hierarchical
tokens. Subsequently, a decoder-only Transformer learns a universal
representation of wind generation dynamics by autoregressively pre-training on
these token sequences. Using the comprehensive WIND Toolkit dataset comprising
approximately 150 billion time steps from more than 126,000 sites, WindFM
develops a foundational understanding of the complex interplay between
atmospheric conditions and power output. Extensive experiments demonstrate that
our compact 8.1M parameter model achieves state-of-the-art zero-shot
performance on both deterministic and probabilistic tasks, outperforming
specialized models and larger foundation models without any fine-tuning. In
particular, WindFM exhibits strong adaptiveness under out-of-distribution data
from a different continent, demonstrating the robustness and transferability of
its learned representations. Our pre-trained model is publicly available at
https://github.com/shiyu-coder/WindFM.

</details>


### [221] [Evaluating the Efficiency of Latent Spaces via the Coupling-Matrix](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06314)
*Mehmet Can Yavuz,Berrin Yanikoglu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces rho(C), a redundancy index that quantifies inter-dimensional dependencies in latent representations using coupling matrices and energy-distance testing; it predicts performance and can guide NAS and regularization.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Redundancy in latent spaces hampers expressiveness and generalization; existing metrics fail to isolate redundancy; need a direct statistical measure of representational bottlenecks.

Method: Compute coupling matrices from latent embeddings, compare off-diagonal statistics to a normal distribution via energy distance to obtain rho(C); analyze across models/datasets; reliability grows with latent dimension; use Tree-structured Parzen Estimators (TPE) to explore low-rho regions.

Result: Low rho(C) correlates with high accuracy or low reconstruction error; high rho associated with performance collapse; rho(C) robust across datasets (MNIST variants, Fashion-MNIST, CIFAR-10/100) and architectures; reliability improves with latent dimension; TPE biases toward low-rho regions; suggests rho(C) as a criterion for NAS and redundancy-aware regularization.

Conclusion: rho(C) provides a universal bottleneck measure of representational efficiency that can guide architecture search and regularization; offers both theoretical insight and a practical tool for evaluating and improving latent representations.

Abstract: A central challenge in representation learning is constructing latent
embeddings that are both expressive and efficient. In practice, deep networks
often produce redundant latent spaces where multiple coordinates encode
overlapping information, reducing effective capacity and hindering
generalization. Standard metrics such as accuracy or reconstruction loss
provide only indirect evidence of such redundancy and cannot isolate it as a
failure mode. We introduce a redundancy index, denoted rho(C), that directly
quantifies inter-dimensional dependencies by analyzing coupling matrices
derived from latent representations and comparing their off-diagonal statistics
against a normal distribution via energy distance. The result is a compact,
interpretable, and statistically grounded measure of representational quality.
We validate rho(C) across discriminative and generative settings on MNIST
variants, Fashion-MNIST, CIFAR-10, and CIFAR-100, spanning multiple
architectures and hyperparameter optimization strategies. Empirically, low
rho(C) reliably predicts high classification accuracy or low reconstruction
error, while elevated redundancy is associated with performance collapse.
Estimator reliability grows with latent dimension, yielding natural lower
bounds for reliable analysis. We further show that Tree-structured Parzen
Estimators (TPE) preferentially explore low-rho regions, suggesting that rho(C)
can guide neural architecture search and serve as a redundancy-aware
regularization target. By exposing redundancy as a universal bottleneck across
models and tasks, rho(C) offers both a theoretical lens and a practical tool
for evaluating and improving the efficiency of learned representations.

</details>


### [222] [Text-Trained LLMs Can Zero-Shot Extrapolate PDE Dynamics](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06322)
*Jiajun Bao,Nicolas Boullé,Toni J. B. Liu,Raphaël Sarfati,Christopher J. Earls*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Text-trained foundation models can extrapolate discretized PDE dynamics via in-context learning without fine-tuning; predictive accuracy improves with longer temporal context but degrades at finer spatial discretization; in multi-step rollouts, errors grow algebraically with time horizon, echoing global error accumulation in finite-difference solvers; there is an in-context neural scaling law linking context length and output length, and a progression in token-level generation from imitation to exploratory to numerically grounded predictions.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To evaluate whether text-trained foundation models can perform accurate, fine-tuning-free extrapolation of spatiotemporal dynamics from discretized PDE solutions, and to uncover how ICL scales with context/output length and how the model internally processes PDE data.

Method: Experimentally prompt text-trained foundation models with discretized PDE solutions to forecast future states without fine-tuning or NL prompts. Vary temporal context length and spatial discretization, perform multi-step rollouts (recursive predictions over time), analyze token-level output distributions to characterize the ICL progression, and examine error growth dynamics.

Result: Prediction accuracy increases with longer temporal context but worsens with finer spatial discretization. In multi-step rollouts, the forward-error grows algebraically with the number of steps (time horizon). The authors identify in-context neural scaling laws: prediction quality varies predictably with context length and output length. Token-level analysis reveals an ICL progression: imitation of syntactic patterns, then a high-entropy exploratory phase, and finally confident, numerically grounded predictions.

Conclusion: LLMs can extrapolate discretized PDE dynamics via in-context learning without fine-tuning, with predictable scaling of performance w.r.t. context and output lengths. The work sheds light on how LLMs internally process numerical PDE information and suggests potential for in-context numerical tasks, while also highlighting limits related to spatial discretization granularity.

Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have demonstrated emergent in-context learning
(ICL) capabilities across a range of tasks, including zero-shot time-series
forecasting. We show that text-trained foundation models can accurately
extrapolate spatiotemporal dynamics from discretized partial differential
equation (PDE) solutions without fine-tuning or natural language prompting.
Predictive accuracy improves with longer temporal contexts but degrades at
finer spatial discretizations. In multi-step rollouts, where the model
recursively predicts future spatial states over multiple time steps, errors
grow algebraically with the time horizon, reminiscent of global error
accumulation in classical finite-difference solvers. We interpret these trends
as in-context neural scaling laws, where prediction quality varies predictably
with both context length and output length. To better understand how LLMs are
able to internally process PDE solutions so as to accurately roll them out, we
analyze token-level output distributions and uncover a consistent ICL
progression: beginning with syntactic pattern imitation, transitioning through
an exploratory high-entropy phase, and culminating in confident, numerically
grounded predictions.

</details>


### [223] [Exploring approaches to computational representation and classification of user-generated meal logs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06330)
*Guanlan Hu,Adit Anand,Pooja M. Desai,Iñigo Urteaga,Lena Mamykina*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Machine learning with nutrition-domain enrichment can classify meal logs against nutritional goals, outperforming self-assessment; enrichment boosts accuracy and shows variability by goal.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To unlock actionable nutrition insights from patient-generated free-text meal logs by combining NLP with domain-specific nutrition knowledge, enabling precision nutrition support especially in diverse, low-income settings.

Method: Dataset of 3000 meal records from 114 individuals in a diverse, low-income US community collected via a mobile app. Gold standard labels provided by registered dietitians. Methods included text embeddings (TFIDF, BERT) and nutrition-domain enrichment (ontologies, ingredient parsers, macronutrient contents). Classifiers: logistic regression and multilayer perceptron. Evaluation against dietitian gold standard and self-assessments using accuracy, precision, recall, F1.

Result: Without enrichment, ML outperformed self-assessments. The best performance came from combining ML with enrichment. Enrichment components—Parsed Ingredients, Food Entities, and Macronutrients—improved performance across multiple nutritional goals, though the impact varied by goal and classifier.

Conclusion: ML can effectively use unstructured free-text meal logs to determine alignment with nutritional goals, exceeding self-assessments, especially when incorporating nutrition-domain knowledge; supports patient-centered nutrition guidance in precision healthcare.

Abstract: This study examined the use of machine learning and domain specific
enrichment on patient generated health data, in the form of free text meal
logs, to classify meals on alignment with different nutritional goals. We used
a dataset of over 3000 meal records collected by 114 individuals from a
diverse, low income community in a major US city using a mobile app. Registered
dietitians provided expert judgement for meal to goal alignment, used as gold
standard for evaluation. Using text embeddings, including TFIDF and BERT, and
domain specific enrichment information, including ontologies, ingredient
parsers, and macronutrient contents as inputs, we evaluated the performance of
logistic regression and multilayer perceptron classifiers using accuracy,
precision, recall, and F1 score against the gold standard and self assessment.
Even without enrichment, ML outperformed self assessments of individuals who
logged meals, and the best performing combination of ML classifier with
enrichment achieved even higher accuracies. In general, ML classifiers with
enrichment of Parsed Ingredients, Food Entities, and Macronutrients information
performed well across multiple nutritional goals, but there was variability in
the impact of enrichment and classification algorithm on accuracy of
classification for different nutritional goals. In conclusion, ML can utilize
unstructured free text meal logs and reliably classify whether meals align with
specific nutritional goals, exceeding self assessments, especially when
incorporating nutrition domain knowledge. Our findings highlight the potential
of ML analysis of patient generated health data to support patient centered
nutrition guidance in precision healthcare.

</details>


### [224] [A Fragile Number Sense: Probing the Elemental Limits of Numerical Reasoning in LLMs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06332)
*Roussel Rahman,Aashwin Ananda Mishra*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: LLMs excel at deterministic numeric tasks but falter on a combinatorial puzzle (Game of 24), suggesting their numerical reasoning relies on pattern matching rather than flexible problem-solving.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Assess the robustness of LLM-based numeracy across tasks of increasing complexity and distinguish true reasoning from recall of algorithms.

Method: Evaluate several state-of-the-art LLM-based agents on a 100-problem challenge spanning four categories (basic arithmetic, advanced operations, primality checking, Game of 24); measure accuracy and analyze failure modes to identify bottlenecks related to heuristic search versus algorithmic execution.

Result: Agents show high accuracy on the first three categories that align with deterministic algorithms, but consistently fail at the Game of 24 puzzle, indicating a bottleneck in heuristic search over a large combinatorial space and revealing a reliance on recalling/executing known algorithms rather than true generative problem-solving.

Conclusion: Current numerical ability in LLMs appears limited to pattern-based execution of known algorithms; they struggle with tasks requiring novel or creative numerical insight, highlighting a need for improved reasoning strategies or integration of search/external tools for genuine numeracy.

Abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated remarkable emergent
capabilities, yet the robustness of their numerical reasoning remains an open
question. While standard benchmarks evaluate LLM reasoning on complex problem
sets using aggregated metrics, they often obscure foundational weaknesses. In
this work, we probe LLM mathematical numeracy by evaluating performance on
problems of escalating complexity, from constituent operations to combinatorial
puzzles. We test several state-of-the-art LLM-based agents on a 100-problem
challenge comprising four categories: (1) basic arithmetic, (2) advanced
operations, (3) primality checking, and (4) the Game of 24 number puzzle. Our
results show that while the agents achieved high accuracy on the first three
categories, which require deterministic algorithmic execution, they
consistently failed at the number puzzle, underlining its demand for a
heuristic search over a large combinatorial space to be a significant
bottleneck. These findings reveal that the agents' proficiency is largely
confined to recalling and executing known algorithms, rather than performing
generative problem-solving. This suggests their apparent numerical reasoning is
more akin to sophisticated pattern-matching than flexible, analytical thought,
limiting their potential for tasks that require novel or creative numerical
insights.

</details>


### [225] [Ban&Pick: Achieving Free Performance Gains and Inference Speedup via Smarter Routing in MoE-LLMs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06346)
*Yuanteng Chen,Peisong Wang,Yuantian Shao,Jian Cheng*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Ban&Pick is a post-training, plug-and-play method that identifies a small set of highly influential MoE experts and prunes redundant ones, yielding accuracy gains and faster inference without retraining or changing architecture.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In fine-grained sparse MoEs, routers optimized for stability lead to premature convergence and enforced balanced usage. This causes underutilization of influential experts and redundancy from fixed active-expert counts, limiting model performance and efficiency.

Method: A post-training pipeline with two components: Pick, which discovers and reinforces a small group of key experts with outsized impact; Ban, which dynamically prunes redundant experts based on layer- and token-sensitivity. This does not require retraining or architectural revisions and is plug-and-play.

Result: Experiments on DeepSeek and Qwen3 (math, code, general reasoning) show improvements in accuracy (e.g., Qwen3-30B-A3B: AIME2024 from 80.67 to 84.66; GPQA-Diamond from 65.66 to 68.18) and a 1.25x inference acceleration under vLLM.

Conclusion: Ban&Pick delivers free performance gains and faster inference for fine-grained MoE-LLMs without retraining or architectural changes, and can be applied broadly to existing MoE deployments.

Abstract: Sparse Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) has become a key architecture for scaling
large language models (LLMs) efficiently. Recent fine-grained MoE designs
introduce hundreds of experts per layer, with multiple experts activated per
token, enabling stronger specialization. However, during pre-training, routers
are optimized mainly for stability and robustness: they converge prematurely
and enforce balanced usage, limiting the full potential of model performance
and efficiency. In this work, we uncover two overlooked issues: (i) a few
highly influential experts are underutilized due to premature and balanced
routing decisions; and (ii) enforcing a fixed number of active experts per
token introduces substantial redundancy. Instead of retraining models or
redesigning MoE architectures, we introduce Ban&Pick, a post-training,
plug-and-play strategy for smarter MoE routing. Pick discovers and reinforces
key experts-a small group with outsized impact on performance-leading to
notable accuracy gains across domains. Ban complements this by dynamically
pruning redundant experts based on layer and token sensitivity, delivering
faster inference with minimal accuracy loss. Experiments on fine-grained
MoE-LLMs (DeepSeek, Qwen3) across math, code, and general reasoning benchmarks
demonstrate that Ban&Pick delivers free performance gains and inference
acceleration without retraining or architectural changes. For instance, on
Qwen3-30B-A3B, it improves accuracy from 80.67 to 84.66 on AIME2024 and from
65.66 to 68.18 on GPQA-Diamond, while accelerating inference by 1.25x under the
vLLM.

</details>


### [226] [Breaking SafetyCore: Exploring the Risks of On-Device AI Deployment](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06371)
*Victor Guyomard,Mathis Mauvisseau,Marie Paindavoine*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: On-device AI models can be extracted and manipulated to bypass detection, revealing security gaps in mobile AI deployments.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: As AI moves onto devices to improve privacy and latency, new security risks emerge that differ from traditional software; this paper investigates those risks using a real-world case study.

Method: Real-world case study of an Android system service (SafetyCore) for sensitive image content detection; demonstrates extraction and manipulation of the on-device model to bypass detection, accompanied by vulnerability analysis.

Result: The study shows that on-device models can be exfiltrated and attacked to bypass protection, effectively rendering the detector unreliable in practice.

Conclusion: On-device AI security requires stronger protection mechanisms and mitigations; the findings highlight concrete attack vectors and the need for robust defenses for on-device detectors.

Abstract: Due to hardware and software improvements, an increasing number of AI models
are deployed on-device. This shift enhances privacy and reduces latency, but
also introduces security risks distinct from traditional software. In this
article, we examine these risks through the real-world case study of
SafetyCore, an Android system service incorporating sensitive image content
detection. We demonstrate how the on-device AI model can be extracted and
manipulated to bypass detection, effectively rendering the protection
ineffective. Our analysis exposes vulnerabilities of on-device AI models and
provides a practical demonstration of how adversaries can exploit them.

</details>


### [227] [Variational Garrote for Statistical Physics-based Sparse and Robust Variable Selection](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06383)
*Hyungjoon Soh,Dongha Lee,Vipul Periwal,Junghyo Jo*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces Variational Garrote (VG), a statistical-physics-based sparse regression method with explicit feature-spin variables and variational inference, enhanced by automatic differentiation for scalable optimization. VG shows strong, robust variable selection in highly sparse regimes, with a sharp transition signal that helps estimate the number of relevant variables and identify key predictors in real-world data; outperforms Ridge and LASSO in sparse settings and has potential for sparse modeling tasks including compressed sensing and model pruning.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Need for reliable, interpretable feature selection in high-dimensional data. Sparse models offer simplicity but existing methods (Ridge, LASSO) can struggle in extreme sparsity; physics-inspired methods like Variational Garrote (VG) may offer robustness and scalability but are underutilized.

Method: Adaptation of a statistical-physics–based Variational Garrote (VG) that introduces explicit feature-selection spin variables and uses variational inference to derive a tractable loss. The approach is enhanced with modern automatic differentiation to enable scalable optimization. Evaluated on synthetic datasets (fully controllable) and complex real-world datasets.

Result: VG performs especially well in highly sparse regimes, providing more consistent and robust variable selection than Ridge and LASSO across varying sparsity levels. A sharp transition is observed: as superfluous variables are admitted, generalization degrades abruptly and uncertainty in variable selection increases. This transition point serves as a practical signal for estimating the correct number of relevant variables, enabling identification of key predictors in real data.

Conclusion: VG offers strong potential for sparse modeling across diverse applications, including compressed sensing and model pruning in machine learning.

Abstract: Selecting key variables from high-dimensional data is increasingly important
in the era of big data. Sparse regression serves as a powerful tool for this
purpose by promoting model simplicity and explainability. In this work, we
revisit a valuable yet underutilized method, the statistical physics-based
Variational Garrote (VG), which introduces explicit feature selection spin
variables and leverages variational inference to derive a tractable loss
function. We enhance VG by incorporating modern automatic differentiation
techniques, enabling scalable and efficient optimization. We evaluate VG on
both fully controllable synthetic datasets and complex real-world datasets. Our
results demonstrate that VG performs especially well in highly sparse regimes,
offering more consistent and robust variable selection than Ridge and LASSO
regression across varying levels of sparsity. We also uncover a sharp
transition: as superfluous variables are admitted, generalization degrades
abruptly and the uncertainty of the selection variables increases. This
transition point provides a practical signal for estimating the correct number
of relevant variables, an insight we successfully apply to identify key
predictors in real-world data. We expect that VG offers strong potential for
sparse modeling across a wide range of applications, including compressed
sensing and model pruning in machine learning.

</details>


### [228] [Beyond the Pre-Service Horizon: Infusing In-Service Behavior for Improved Financial Risk Forecasting](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06385)
*Senhao Liu,Zhiyu Guo,Zhiyuan Ji,Yueguo Chen,Yateng Tang,Yunhai Wang,Xuehao Zheng,Xiang Ao*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: MGKD: A teacher-student distillation framework that leverages in-service data to improve pre-service risk prediction, using multi-granularity distillation and re-weighting to handle class imbalance, validated on large Tencent Mpay datasets offline and online.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Pre-service risk assessment often ignores valuable signals from in-service user behavior and struggles with class imbalance; integrating in-service patterns can enhance early risk prediction before service activation.

Method: Three-part approach: (1) teacher model trained on historical in-service data; (2) student model trained on pre-service data using soft labels from the teacher; (3) multi-granularity distillation (coarse-grained, fine-grained, and self-distillation) to align representations/predictions; plus a re-weighting strategy to mitigate minority-class bias.

Result: Experiments on large-scale real-world Tencent Mobile Payment data show MGKD improves risk prediction and is effective in both offline and online deployments.

Conclusion: MGKD effectively transfers defaulter-related patterns from the teacher to the student, enhancing pre-service risk assessment with a scalable, multi-granularity, re-weighted distillation framework.

Abstract: Typical financial risk management involves distinct phases for pre-service
risk assessment and in-service default detection, often modeled separately.
This paper proposes a novel framework, Multi-Granularity Knowledge Distillation
(abbreviated as MGKD), aimed at improving pre-service risk prediction through
the integration of in-service user behavior data. MGKD follows the idea of
knowledge distillation, where the teacher model, trained on historical
in-service data, guides the student model, which is trained on pre-service
data. By using soft labels derived from in-service data, the teacher model
helps the student model improve its risk prediction prior to service
activation. Meanwhile, a multi-granularity distillation strategy is introduced,
including coarse-grained, fine-grained, and self-distillation, to align the
representations and predictions of the teacher and student models. This
approach not only reinforces the representation of default cases but also
enables the transfer of key behavioral patterns associated with defaulters from
the teacher to the student model, thereby improving the overall performance of
pre-service risk assessment. Moreover, we adopt a re-weighting strategy to
mitigate the model's bias towards the minority class. Experimental results on
large-scale real-world datasets from Tencent Mobile Payment demonstrate the
effectiveness of our proposed approach in both offline and online scenarios.

</details>


### [229] [Graph Neural Networks for Resource Allocation in Interference-limited Multi-Channel Wireless Networks with QoS Constraints](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06395)
*Lili Chen,Changyang She,Jingge Zhu,Jamie Evans*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Extends WMMSE to a convergent, QoS-constrained multi-channel setting (eWMMSE), and introduces a scalable GNN-based JCPGNN-M within a Lagrangian primal-dual framework that matches eWMMSE performance with faster inference, better generalization, and robustness to imperfect CSI.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To meet minimum data rate constraints in growing wireless networks where penalty-based DL methods lack convergence guarantees and fail to consistently satisfy QoS requirements.

Method: 1) Develop eWMMSE: a multi-channel extension of WMMSE with QoS constraints that is provably convergent to a local optimum when the problem is feasible. 2) Propose JCPGNN-M, a GNN-based allocator that supports simultaneous multi-channel allocation per user. 3) Integrate GNN with a Lagrangian-based primal-dual optimization during training to enforce QoS constraints and ensure convergence to a stationary point.

Result: Simulation results show JCPGNN-M achieves performance on par with eWMMSE while offering faster inference, better scalability to larger networks, and robustness under imperfect CSI.

Conclusion: The framework provides a scalable, theoretically grounded approach for constrained resource allocation in next-generation wireless networks, combining convergence guarantees with the practical benefits of GNN-based inference.

Abstract: Meeting minimum data rate constraints is a significant challenge in wireless
communication systems, particularly as network complexity grows. Traditional
deep learning approaches often address these constraints by incorporating
penalty terms into the loss function and tuning hyperparameters empirically.
However, this heuristic treatment offers no theoretical convergence guarantees
and frequently fails to satisfy QoS requirements in practical scenarios.
Building upon the structure of the WMMSE algorithm, we first extend it to a
multi-channel setting with QoS constraints, resulting in the enhanced WMMSE
(eWMMSE) algorithm, which is provably convergent to a locally optimal solution
when the problem is feasible. To further reduce computational complexity and
improve scalability, we develop a GNN-based algorithm, JCPGNN-M, capable of
supporting simultaneous multi-channel allocation per user. To overcome the
limitations of traditional deep learning methods, we propose a principled
framework that integrates GNN with a Lagrangian-based primal-dual optimization
method. By training the GNN within the Lagrangian framework, we ensure
satisfaction of QoS constraints and convergence to a stationary point.
Extensive simulations demonstrate that JCPGNN-M matches the performance of
eWMMSE while offering significant gains in inference speed, generalization to
larger networks, and robustness under imperfect channel state information. This
work presents a scalable and theoretically grounded solution for constrained
resource allocation in future wireless networks.

</details>


### [230] [NeuroDeX: Unlocking Diverse Support in Decompiling Deep Neural Network Executables](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06402)
*Yilin Li,Guozhu Meng,Mingyang Sun,Yanzhong Wang,Kun Sun,Hailong Chang,Yuekang Li*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: NeuroDeX uses LLM-based semantic understanding and dynamic analysis to decompile DNN executables into high-level models, handling both non-quantized and quantized forms, with strong experimental results.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Enable reliable reverse engineering of optimized DNN executables on edge devices to facilitate understanding, optimization, and interoperability amid compilation optimizations and quantization.

Method: Combine semantic analysis from large language models with dynamic analysis to identify operator types, recover operator attributes, and reconstruct the overall DNN model; evaluate on 96 executables across 12 models, across architectures and quantization states.

Result: Non-quantized executables are decompiled into high-level models that are nearly identical to originals; quantized executables achieve about 72% top-1 accuracy in reconstructed models; NeuroDeX outperforms prior decompilers.

Conclusion: NeuroDeX provides a comprehensive and effective solution for decompiling DNN executables, enabling better understanding and potential optimization across diverse architectures and quantization schemes.

Abstract: On-device deep learning models have extensive real world demands. Deep
learning compilers efficiently compile models into executables for deployment
on edge devices, but these executables may face the threat of reverse
engineering. Previous studies have attempted to decompile DNN executables, but
they face challenges in handling compilation optimizations and analyzing
quantized compiled models. In this paper, we present NeuroDeX to unlock diverse
support in decompiling DNN executables. NeuroDeX leverages the semantic
understanding capabilities of LLMs along with dynamic analysis to accurately
and efficiently perform operator type recognition, operator attribute recovery
and model reconstruction. NeuroDeX can recover DNN executables into high-level
models towards compilation optimizations, different architectures and quantized
compiled models. We conduct experiments on 96 DNN executables across 12 common
DNN models. Extensive experimental results demonstrate that NeuroDeX can
decompile non-quantized executables into nearly identical high-level models.
NeuroDeX can recover functionally similar high-level models for quantized
executables, achieving an average top-1 accuracy of 72%. NeuroDeX offers a more
comprehensive and effective solution compared to previous DNN executables
decompilers.

</details>


### [231] [CAPMix: Robust Time Series Anomaly Detection Based on Abnormal Assumptions with Dual-Space Mixup](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06419)
*Xudong Mou,Rui Wang,Tiejun Wang,Renyu Yang,Shiru Chen,Jie Sun,Tianyu Wo,Xudong Liu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: CAPMix is a controllable anomaly augmentation framework for time-series anomaly detection that tackles patchy generation and anomaly shift via CutAddPaste, adaptive label revision, and dual-space mixup within a temporal CNN, achieving strong gains across five benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Time-series anomaly detection faces scarce labeled anomalies and complex temporal dependencies. Existing anomaly-assumption augmentation can produce patchy, incoherent anomalies or distort decision boundaries (anomaly shift). A more controllable, robust augmentation strategy is needed.

Method: CAPMix consists of (1) CutAddPaste to inject diverse, coherent anomalies in a targeted way; (2) a label revision strategy to adaptively refine anomaly labels and reduce anomaly shift; (3) dual-space mixup within a temporal convolutional network to enforce smoother, more robust decision boundaries.

Result: CAPMix yields significant improvements over state-of-the-art baselines on five datasets (AIOps, UCR, SWaT, WADI, ESA) and shows enhanced robustness to contaminated training data.

Conclusion: CAPMix effectively addresses patchy generation and anomaly shift, providing a controllable anomaly augmentation framework for TSAD with strong empirical gains and practical robustness; code is publicly available.

Abstract: Time series anomaly detection (TSAD) is a vital yet challenging task,
particularly in scenarios where labeled anomalies are scarce and temporal
dependencies are complex. Recent anomaly assumption (AA) approaches alleviate
the lack of anomalies by injecting synthetic samples and training
discriminative models. Despite promising results, these methods often suffer
from two fundamental limitations: patchy generation, where scattered anomaly
knowledge leads to overly simplistic or incoherent anomaly injection, and
Anomaly Shift, where synthetic anomalies either resemble normal data too
closely or diverge unrealistically from real anomalies, thereby distorting
classification boundaries. In this paper, we propose CAPMix, a controllable
anomaly augmentation framework that addresses both issues. First, we design a
CutAddPaste mechanism to inject diverse and complex anomalies in a targeted
manner, avoiding patchy generation. Second, we introduce a label revision
strategy to adaptively refine anomaly labels, reducing the risk of anomaly
shift. Finally, we employ dual-space mixup within a temporal convolutional
network to enforce smoother and more robust decision boundaries. Extensive
experiments on five benchmark datasets, including AIOps, UCR, SWaT, WADI, and
ESA, demonstrate that CAPMix achieves significant improvements over
state-of-the-art baselines, with enhanced robustness against contaminated
training data. The code is available at https://github.com/alsike22/CAPMix.

</details>


### [232] [CAME-AB: Cross-Modality Attention with Mixture-of-Experts for Antibody Binding Site Prediction](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06465)
*Hongzong Li,Jiahao Ma,Zhanpeng Shi,Fanming Jin,Ye-Fan Hu,Jian-Dong Huang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A multimodal deep learning model (CAME-AB) integrates five biological modalities with a cross-modality attention and Mixture-of-Experts backbone to predict antibody binding sites on antigens, achieving superior accuracy over baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing antibody binding site prediction methods rely on single-view features (sequence or structure) and fail to capture antibody-specific antigen interactions, limiting representation and predictive performance.

Method: CAME-AB uses five modalities (raw amino acid encodings, BLOSUM profiles, pretrained language model embeddings, structure-aware features, and GCN-refined biochemical graphs) fused via an adaptive modality fusion module. A Transformer encoder with an MoE backbone enables feature specialization, reinforced by a supervised contrastive objective. Stochastic weight averaging is used to stabilize training. The approach is evaluated on benchmark antibody-antigen datasets with ablations to validate components.

Result: CAME-AB consistently outperforms strong baselines across metrics (Precision, Recall, F1-score, AUC-ROC, MCC). Ablation studies confirm the contribution of each component and the benefit of multimodal integration.

Conclusion: A robust, multimodal framework that leverages cross-modal reasoning and MoE capacity with contrastive learning improves antibody binding site prediction, with code available publicly.

Abstract: Antibody binding site prediction plays a pivotal role in computational
immunology and therapeutic antibody design. Existing sequence or structure
methods rely on single-view features and fail to identify antibody-specific
binding sites on the antigens-a dual limitation in representation and
prediction. In this paper, we propose CAME-AB, a novel Cross-modality Attention
framework with a Mixture-of-Experts (MoE) backbone for robust antibody binding
site prediction. CAME-AB integrates five biologically grounded modalities,
including raw amino acid encodings, BLOSUM substitution profiles, pretrained
language model embeddings, structure-aware features, and GCN-refined
biochemical graphs-into a unified multimodal representation. To enhance
adaptive cross-modal reasoning, we propose an adaptive modality fusion module
that learns to dynamically weight each modality based on its global relevance
and input-specific contribution. A Transformer encoder combined with an MoE
module further promotes feature specialization and capacity expansion. We
additionally incorporate a supervised contrastive learning objective to
explicitly shape the latent space geometry, encouraging intra-class compactness
and inter-class separability. To improve optimization stability and
generalization, we apply stochastic weight averaging during training. Extensive
experiments on benchmark antibody-antigen datasets demonstrate that CAME-AB
consistently outperforms strong baselines on multiple metrics, including
Precision, Recall, F1-score, AUC-ROC, and MCC. Ablation studies further
validate the effectiveness of each architectural component and the benefit of
multimodal feature integration. The model implementation details and the codes
are available on https://anonymous.4open.science/r/CAME-AB-C525

</details>


### [233] [DyC-STG: Dynamic Causal Spatio-Temporal Graph Network for Real-time Data Credibility Analysis in IoT](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06483)
*Guanjie Cheng,Boyi Li,Peihan Wu,Feiyi Chen,Xinkui Zhao,Mengying Zhu,Shuiguang Deng*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes DyC-STG, a dynamic causal spatio-temporal graph network for real-time IoT data credibility, combining event-driven topology updates and causal reasoning; reports SOTA F1 of 0.930 and 1.4pp improvement, with two datasets released.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Addresses data credibility in IoT spatio-temporal data, particularly in human-centric environments, where static STG topologies fail to capture event-driven dynamics and spurious correlations undermine robustness.

Method: Two modules: (1) an event-driven dynamic graph module updating the graph topology in real time to reflect physical state changes; (2) a causal reasoning module distilling causally-aware representations by enforcing temporal precedence; plus release of two real-world datasets.

Result: Comprehensive experiments show DyC-STG outperforms the strongest baselines by 1.4 percentage points and achieves an F1-Score up to 0.930.

Conclusion: DyC-STG advances real-time data credibility analysis in IoT by integrating dynamic graphs with causal reasoning; datasets released to spur further research.

Abstract: The wide spreading of Internet of Things (IoT) sensors generates vast
spatio-temporal data streams, but ensuring data credibility is a critical yet
unsolved challenge for applications like smart homes. While spatio-temporal
graph (STG) models are a leading paradigm for such data, they often fall short
in dynamic, human-centric environments due to two fundamental limitations: (1)
their reliance on static graph topologies, which fail to capture physical,
event-driven dynamics, and (2) their tendency to confuse spurious correlations
with true causality, undermining robustness in human-centric environments. To
address these gaps, we propose the Dynamic Causal Spatio-Temporal Graph Network
(DyC-STG), a novel framework designed for real-time data credibility analysis
in IoT. Our framework features two synergistic contributions: an event-driven
dynamic graph module that adapts the graph topology in real-time to reflect
physical state changes, and a causal reasoning module to distill causally-aware
representations by strictly enforcing temporal precedence. To facilitate the
research in this domain we release two new real-world datasets. Comprehensive
experiments show that DyC-STG establishes a new state-of-the-art, outperforming
the strongest baselines by 1.4 percentage points and achieving an F1-Score of
up to 0.930.

</details>


### [234] [A machine-learned expression for the excess Gibbs energy](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06484)
*Marco Hoffmann,Thomas Specht,Quirin Göttl,Jakob Burger,Stephan Mandt,Hans Hasse,Fabian Jirasek*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A physics-informed neural network, HANNA, predicts the excess Gibbs energy of liquid mixtures from molecular structure with thermodynamic consistency, achieving state-of-the-art accuracy and robust multi-component extrapolation; code and an interactive interface are released.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Predicting excess Gibbs energy for multi-component mixtures from only molecular structures is a long-standing, hard challenge. Enforcing physical laws as hard constraints can enforce thermodynamic consistency and improve extrapolation.

Method: End-to-end training of a physics-informed neural network (HANNA) with hard physical constraints; a surrogate solver enables inclusion of liquid-liquid equilibrium data; a geometric projection method allows robust extrapolation to multi-component mixtures without extra parameters; trained on extensive binary data from the Dortmund Data Bank; code and data are released.

Result: HANNA delivers highly accurate predictions, outperforming state-of-the-art benchmarks in accuracy and scope; robust extrapolation to multi-component mixtures without additional parameters; the approach is thermodynamically consistent and broadly applicable.

Conclusion: Physics-informed ML can effectively predict thermodynamic properties like excess Gibbs energy for complex mixtures, and the work provides open-source tools and interfaces (MLPROP) to facilitate adoption and further research.

Abstract: The excess Gibbs energy plays a central role in chemical engineering and
chemistry, providing a basis for modeling the thermodynamic properties of
liquid mixtures. Predicting the excess Gibbs energy of multi-component mixtures
solely from the molecular structures of their components is a long-standing
challenge. In this work, we address this challenge by integrating physical laws
as hard constraints within a flexible neural network. The resulting model,
HANNA, was trained end-to-end on an extensive experimental dataset for binary
mixtures from the Dortmund Data Bank, guaranteeing thermodynamically consistent
predictions. A novel surrogate solver developed in this work enabled the
inclusion of liquid-liquid equilibrium data in the training process.
Furthermore, a geometric projection method was applied to enable robust
extrapolations to multi-component mixtures, without requiring additional
parameters. We demonstrate that HANNA delivers excellent predictions, clearly
outperforming state-of-the-art benchmark methods in accuracy and scope. The
trained model and corresponding code are openly available, and an interactive
interface is provided on our website, MLPROP.

</details>


### [235] [On optimal solutions of classical and sliced Wasserstein GANs with non-Gaussian data](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06505)
*Yu-Jui Huang,Hsin-Hua Shen,Yu-Chih Huang,Wan-Yi Lin,Shih-Chun Lin*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Closed-form optimal WGAN parameters are derived for 1D with nonlinear activations and non-Gaussian data; extended to high dimensions via sliced Wasserstein with a joint-data constraint, showing a linear generator can be asymptotically optimal and competitive with r-PCA while saving resources.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To characterize and efficiently select optimal WGAN parameters beyond the linear-Gaussian (LQG) setting and obtain computationally tractable solutions for non-Gaussian data.

Method: Derive closed-form optimal parameters for one-dimensional WGAN with nonlinear activations and non-Gaussian data. Extend to high dimensions through the sliced Wasserstein framework by enforcing a constraint on the joint distribution of the original data (unprojected). Demonstrate that a linear generator is asymptotically optimal under this setup.

Result: The closed-form WGAN parameters converge well for data under Gaussian and Laplace distributions. In the sliced-WGAN setting with non-Gaussian data, a linear generator can be asymptotically optimal. Compared to r-PCA, the proposed approach achieves similar performance at a lower computational cost.

Conclusion: Provides a theoretically grounded, scalable method for selecting WGAN parameters beyond LQG, including non-Gaussian data, with practical efficiency advantages over r-PCA.

Abstract: The generative adversarial network (GAN) aims to approximate an unknown
distribution via a parameterized neural network (NN). While GANs have been
widely applied in reinforcement and semisupervised learning as well as computer
vision tasks, selecting their parameters often needs an exhaustive search and
only a few selection methods can be proved to be theoretically optimal. One of
the most promising GAN variants is the Wasserstein GAN (WGAN). Prior work on
optimal parameters for WGAN is limited to the linear-quadratic-Gaussian (LQG)
setting, where the NN is linear and the data is Gaussian. In this paper, we
focus on the characterization of optimal WGAN parameters beyond the LQG
setting. We derive closed-form optimal parameters for one-dimensional WGANs
when the NN has non-linear activation functions and the data is non-Gaussian.
To extend this to high-dimensional WGANs, we adopt the sliced Wasserstein
framework and replace the constraint on marginal distributions of the randomly
projected data by a constraint on the joint distribution of the original
(unprojected) data. We show that the linear generator can be asymptotically
optimal for sliced WGAN with non-Gaussian data. Empirical studies show that our
closed-form WGAN parameters have good convergence behavior with data under both
Gaussian and Laplace distributions. Also, compared to the r principal component
analysis (r-PCA) solution, our proposed solution for sliced WGAN can achieve
the same performance while requiring less computational resources.

</details>


### [236] [QualityFM: a Multimodal Physiological Signal Foundation Model with Self-Distillation for Signal Quality Challenges in Critically Ill Patients](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06516)
*Zongheng Guo,Tao Chen,Manuela Ferrario*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: QualityFM—a Transformer-based multimodal model for PPG/ECG signal quality; self-distillation, windowed sparse attention; pre-trained on 21M waveforms; transfers to ventricular tachycardia false-alarm detection, atrial fibrillation identification, and arterial blood pressure estimation from PPG and ECG.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In ICU/OR settings, poor, incomplete, and inconsistent signal quality leads to false alarms and diagnostic inaccuracies. Existing methods struggle with generalizability, require extensive labeled data, and show limited cross-task transferability.

Method: A dual-track Transformer-based model processes paired signals of differing quality via self-distillation: a high-quality encoder guides a low-quality encoder. It uses windowed sparse attention to handle long sequences and preserves frequency-domain characteristics through a composite loss that combines direct distillation loss on encoder outputs with an indirect reconstruction loss based on power and phase spectra. Pre-trained on a large-scale dataset (~21 million 30-second waveforms and ~179,757 hours) with three model sizes (9.6M to 319M parameters). Transfer learning evaluated on three clinical tasks: false alarm of ventricular tachycardia, atrial fibrillation identification, and arterial blood pressure estimation from PPG and ECG.

Result: The authors demonstrate efficacy and practical value by transferring the pre-trained models to three distinct clinical tasks, indicating improved generalizable understanding of signal quality and cross-task transfer potential across ICU/OR settings.

Conclusion: QualityFM provides a general-purpose understanding of PPG/ECG signal quality, enabling cross-task transfer and scalable deployment in clinical contexts. The approach addresses generalizability, data efficiency, and cross-task applicability challenges while supporting long-sequence reasoning through windowed attention.

Abstract: Photoplethysmogram (PPG) and electrocardiogram (ECG) are commonly recorded in
intesive care unit (ICU) and operating room (OR). However, the high incidence
of poor, incomplete, and inconsistent signal quality, can lead to false alarms
or diagnostic inaccuracies. The methods explored so far suffer from limited
generalizability, reliance on extensive labeled data, and poor cross-task
transferability. To overcome these challenges, we introduce QualityFM, a novel
multimodal foundation model for these physiological signals, designed to
acquire a general-purpose understanding of signal quality. Our model is
pre-trained on an large-scale dataset comprising over 21 million 30-second
waveforms and 179,757 hours of data. Our approach involves a dual-track
architecture that processes paired physiological signals of differing quality,
leveraging a self-distillation strategy where an encoder for high-quality
signals is used to guide the training of an encoder for low-quality signals. To
efficiently handle long sequential signals and capture essential local
quasi-periodic patterns, we integrate a windowed sparse attention mechanism
within our Transformer-based model. Furthermore, a composite loss function,
which combines direct distillation loss on encoder outputs with indirect
reconstruction loss based on power and phase spectra, ensures the preservation
of frequency-domain characteristics of the signals. We pre-train three models
with varying parameter counts (9.6 M to 319 M) and demonstrate their efficacy
and practical value through transfer learning on three distinct clinical tasks:
false alarm of ventricular tachycardia detection, the identification of atrial
fibrillation and the estimation of arterial blood pressure (ABP) from PPG and
ECG signals.

</details>


### [237] [Lane Change Intention Prediction of two distinct Populations using a Transformer](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06529)
*Francesco De Cristofaro,Cornelia Lex,Jia Hu,Arno Eichberger*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A transformer for lane-change intention prediction generalizes poorly when trained on a single dataset from one population, but performs well when trained on combined datasets from two populations.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To ensure reliable lane-change intention prediction across diverse driving populations and avoid dataset bias that overfits models to a single population.

Method: Evaluate a lane-change intention prediction transformer on two LevelX datasets (Germany and Hong Kong). Test cross-population generalization by training on one population and testing on another, then train on both populations jointly and evaluate performance.

Result: Cross-population testing with single-population training yielded accuracies as low as 39.43%. Joint training on both populations achieved up to 86.71% accuracy.

Conclusion: Cross-population generalization matters; incorporating diverse datasets improves performance and robustness, highlighting the need for multi-domain validation and possibly domain adaptation.

Abstract: As a result of the growing importance of lane change intention prediction for
a safe and efficient driving experience in complex driving scenarios,
researchers have in recent years started to train novel machine learning
algorithms on available datasets with promising results. A shortcoming of this
recent research effort, though, is that the vast majority of the proposed
algorithms are trained on a single datasets. In doing so, researchers failed to
test if their algorithm would be as effective if tested on a different dataset
and, by extension, on a different population with respect to the one on which
they were trained. In this article we test a transformer designed for lane
change intention prediction on two datasets collected by LevelX in Germany and
Hong Kong. We found that the transformer's accuracy plummeted when tested on a
population different to the one it was trained on with accuracy values as low
as 39.43%, but that when trained on both populations simultaneously it could
achieve an accuracy as high as 86.71%. - This work has been submitted to the
IEEE for possible publication. Copyright may be transferred without notice,
after which this version may no longer be accessible.

</details>


### [238] [Learning Optimal Defender Strategies for CAGE-2 using a POMDP Model](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06539)
*Duc Huy Le,Rolf Stadler*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: BF-PPO with particle filtering learns an optimal defender strategy for CAGE-2 modeled as a POMDP, outperforming CARDIFF in strategy quality and training time.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address CAGE-2's large, partially observable state space by providing a formal POMDP model and an efficient learning method, enabling robust defender policies.

Method: Formulate CAGE-2 inside POMDP; define optimal defender strategy; introduce BF-PPO, a PPO-based learner that uses a particle filter to approximate belief states and reduce computation; evaluate in CybORG environment; compare to CARDIFF.

Result: BF-PPO achieves superior defender strategy quality and requires less training time than CARDIFF on CAGE-2 benchmark in CybORG.

Conclusion: Formalizing CAGE-2 as a POMDP and applying particle-filtered PPO yields efficient, high-quality defender policies, with BF-PPO offering practical advantages over the current leading method CARDIFF.

Abstract: CAGE-2 is an accepted benchmark for learning and evaluating defender
strategies against cyberattacks. It reflects a scenario where a defender agent
protects an IT infrastructure against various attacks. Many defender methods
for CAGE-2 have been proposed in the literature. In this paper, we construct a
formal model for CAGE-2 using the framework of Partially Observable Markov
Decision Process (POMDP). Based on this model, we define an optimal defender
strategy for CAGE-2 and introduce a method to efficiently learn this strategy.
Our method, called BF-PPO, is based on PPO, and it uses particle filter to
mitigate the computational complexity due to the large state space of the
CAGE-2 model. We evaluate our method in the CAGE-2 CybORG environment and
compare its performance with that of CARDIFF, the highest ranked method on the
CAGE-2 leaderboard. We find that our method outperforms CARDIFF regarding the
learned defender strategy and the required training time.

</details>


### [239] [Predicting Fetal Outcomes from Cardiotocography Signals Using a Supervised Variational Autoencoder](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06540)
*John Tolladay,Beth Albert,Gabriel Davis Jones*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Supervised variational autoencoders (VAEs) on OxMat CTG data can predict pregnancy outcomes from short fetal heart rate (FHR) segments with competitive AUROC, while partially encoding clinically meaningful CTG features; full interpretability remains challenging due to multi-timescale, irregular FHR signals.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address interpretability gaps in deep learning for CTG-based outcome prediction and to develop latent representations that align with clinically relevant features.

Method: Train a supervised VAE on five-minute FHR segments labeled by postnatal outcomes using the OxMat CTG dataset. The model optimizes signal reconstruction and outcome prediction, incorporating Kullback-Leibler divergence and total correlation constraints to structure the latent space. Evaluation used AUROC and MSE; interpretability assessed via coefficient of determination, latent traversals, and unsupervised component analyses.

Result: AUROC 0.752 at segment level and 0.779 at CTG level (aggregated predictions). Relaxing TC constraints improved reconstruction and classification. Baseline-related features (e.g., FHR baseline, baseline shift) were well represented and aligned with model scores; variability features were less well encoded. Latent traversals showed clear changes for baseline features, while other properties were entangled or subtle. Unsupervised decompositions corroborated these patterns.

Conclusion: Supervised VAEs can achieve competitive fetal outcome prediction and partially encode clinically meaningful CTG features, but full interpretability was not achieved. The irregular, multi-timescale nature of FHR signals complicates disentangling physiological components, indicating room for more interpretable, generative models in this domain.

Abstract: Objective: To develop and interpret a supervised variational autoencoder
(VAE) model for classifying cardiotocography (CTG) signals based on pregnancy
outcomes, addressing interpretability limits of current deep learning
approaches. Methods: The OxMat CTG dataset was used to train a VAE on
five-minute fetal heart rate (FHR) segments, labeled with postnatal outcomes.
The model was optimised for signal reconstruction and outcome prediction,
incorporating Kullback-Leibler divergence and total correlation (TC)
constraints to structure the latent space. Performance was evaluated using area
under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC) and mean squared
error (MSE). Interpretability was assessed using coefficient of determination,
latent traversals and unsupervised component analyses. Results: The model
achieved an AUROC of 0.752 at the segment level and 0.779 at the CTG level,
where predicted scores were aggregated. Relaxing TC constraints improved both
reconstruction and classification. Latent analysis showed that baseline-related
features (e.g., FHR baseline, baseline shift) were well represented and aligned
with model scores, while metrics like short- and long-term variability were
less strongly encoded. Traversals revealed clear signal changes for baseline
features, while other properties were entangled or subtle. Unsupervised
decompositions corroborated these patterns. Findings: This work demonstrates
that supervised VAEs can achieve competitive fetal outcome prediction while
partially encoding clinically meaningful CTG features. The irregular,
multi-timescale nature of FHR signals poses challenges for disentangling
physiological components, distinguishing CTG from more periodic signals such as
ECG. Although full interpretability was not achieved, the model supports
clinically useful outcome prediction and provides a basis for future
interpretable, generative models.

</details>


### [240] [Contrastive Self-Supervised Network Intrusion Detection using Augmented Negative Pairs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06550)
*Jack Wilkie,Hanan Hindy,Christos Tachtatzis,Robert Atkinson*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: We present CLAN (Contrastive Learning using Augmented Negative pairs) for network intrusion detection. It uses augmented samples as negative views representing potentially malicious distributions, while benign samples serve as positive views. Pretrained on benign traffic, it achieves state-of-the-art results in binary intrusion detection and excels in multi-class classification when fine-tuned with limited labeled data on Lycos2017.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Supervised ML for intrusion detection requires large labeled datasets and struggles with imbalance and labeling costs. Anomaly detectors trained only on benign traffic suffer from high false positives. Self-supervised learning on benign data promises robust representations and lower FPRs, but existing contrastive setups use other samples as negatives and benign views as positives, potentially not capturing malicious-like distributions. CLAN reframes contrastive learning by treating augmented (potentially malicious) views as negatives to better separate benign and malicious behavior.

Method: Introduce CLAN, a contrastive self-supervised framework where augmented samples are treated as negative views, while other benign samples serve as positive views. Pretrain on benign traffic to learn latent representations that separate benign vs. augmented (malicious-like) distributions. After pretraining, fine-tune on limited labeled data. Evaluation on the Lycos2017 dataset for binary classification, with additional multi-class evaluation under label scarcity.

Result: CLAN surpasses existing self-supervised and anomaly detection approaches in binary intrusion detection on Lycos2017. When fine-tuned with limited labeled data, it achieves superior multi-class classification performance compared to existing self-supervised models.

Conclusion: Augmented negative pairs in contrastive learning are effective for network intrusion detection, enabling improved accuracy and efficiency. CLAN demonstrates strong performance in both binary detection and low-label multi-class scenarios, highlighting the viability of using augmented negatives to capture potentially malicious distributions.

Abstract: Network intrusion detection remains a critical challenge in cybersecurity.
While supervised machine learning models achieve state-of-the-art performance,
their reliance on large labelled datasets makes them impractical for many
real-world applications. Anomaly detection methods, which train exclusively on
benign traffic to identify malicious activity, suffer from high false positive
rates, limiting their usability. Recently, self-supervised learning techniques
have demonstrated improved performance with lower false positive rates by
learning discriminative latent representations of benign traffic. In
particular, contrastive self-supervised models achieve this by minimizing the
distance between similar (positive) views of benign traffic while maximizing it
between dissimilar (negative) views. Existing approaches generate positive
views through data augmentation and treat other samples as negative. In
contrast, this work introduces Contrastive Learning using Augmented Negative
pairs (CLAN), a novel paradigm for network intrusion detection where augmented
samples are treated as negative views - representing potentially malicious
distributions - while other benign samples serve as positive views. This
approach enhances both classification accuracy and inference efficiency after
pretraining on benign traffic. Experimental evaluation on the Lycos2017 dataset
demonstrates that the proposed method surpasses existing self-supervised and
anomaly detection techniques in a binary classification task. Furthermore, when
fine-tuned on a limited labelled dataset, the proposed approach achieves
superior multi-class classification performance compared to existing
self-supervised models.

</details>


### [241] [Tackling Device Data Distribution Real-time Shift via Prototype-based Parameter Editing](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06552)
*Zheqi Lv,Wenqiao Zhang,Kairui Fu,Qi Tian,Shengyu Zhang,Jiajie Su,Jingyuan Chen,Kun Kuang,Fei Wu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Persona is a prototype-based, backpropagation-free parameter editing framework that personalizes on-device models in real time by using a cloud-generated editing matrix to adapt models to distribution shifts without retraining.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address on-device data distribution shifts that hurt generalization of lightweight models, avoiding heavy data-/compute-intensive fine-tuning and post-deployment retraining.

Method: Introduce Persona, which uses a neural adapter in the cloud to produce a parameter editing matrix based on real-time device data. This matrix updates on-device models without backpropagation, clustering them into prototypes. Prototypes are refined by the editing matrix; cross-layer knowledge transfer enforces consistent multi-layer changes and prototype assignments, enabling efficient evolution.

Result: Extensive experiments on vision and recommendation tasks across multiple datasets show Persona’s effectiveness and generality under distribution shifts, validating its approach for efficient on-device adaptation.

Conclusion: Persona offers a practical, generalizable, backpropagation-free adaptation framework for on-device models, enabling real-time personalization and efficient evolution via cloud-generated parameter editing matrices and cross-layer knowledge transfer, without post-deployment retraining.

Abstract: The on-device real-time data distribution shift on devices challenges the
generalization of lightweight on-device models. This critical issue is often
overlooked in current research, which predominantly relies on data-intensive
and computationally expensive fine-tuning approaches. To tackle this, we
introduce Persona, a novel personalized method using a prototype-based,
backpropagation-free parameter editing framework to enhance model
generalization without post-deployment retraining. Persona employs a neural
adapter in the cloud to generate a parameter editing matrix based on real-time
device data. This matrix adeptly adapts on-device models to the prevailing data
distributions, efficiently clustering them into prototype models. The
prototypes are dynamically refined via the parameter editing matrix,
facilitating efficient evolution. Furthermore, the integration of cross-layer
knowledge transfer ensures consistent and context-aware multi-layer parameter
changes and prototype assignment. Extensive experiments on vision task and
recommendation task on multiple datasets confirm Persona's effectiveness and
generality.

</details>


### [242] [AI for Scientific Discovery is a Social Problem](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06580)
*Georgia Channing,Avijit Ghosh*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: AI for science is hampered more by social/institutional barriers than by data or compute, with four interconnected challenges (community dysfunction, misaligned research priorities, data fragmentation, and infrastructure inequities) rooted in culture and organization; solving them requires intentional community-building, cross-disciplinary education, shared benchmarks, and accessible infrastructure, framing AI for science as a collective social project for sustainable progress.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Explain why AI-driven scientific acceleration benefits are uneven and argue that social and institutional reform is essential, not just technical innovation.

Method: Conceptual analysis and synthesis of existing observations and perspectives; proposes a framework and actionable directions, rather than reporting new empirical results.

Result: Identification of four interconnected challenges and their cultural/organizational roots; emphasis on community-building, re-aligned incentives, data/infrastructure sharing, and cross-disciplinary education; calls for reframing AI-for-science as a collaborative social project with equitable participation.

Conclusion: Addressing social and institutional factors is a prerequisite for real technical progress in AI for science; sustainable collaboration and equitable participation are essential.

Abstract: Artificial intelligence promises to accelerate scientific discovery, yet its
benefits remain unevenly distributed. While technical obstacles such as scarce
data, fragmented standards, and unequal access to computation are significant,
we argue that the primary barriers are social and institutional. Narratives
that defer progress to speculative "AI scientists," the undervaluing of data
and infrastructure contributions, misaligned incentives, and gaps between
domain experts and machine learning researchers all constrain impact. We
highlight four interconnected challenges: community dysfunction, research
priorities misaligned with upstream needs, data fragmentation, and
infrastructure inequities. We argue that their roots lie in cultural and
organizational practices. Addressing them requires not only technical
innovation but also intentional community-building, cross-disciplinary
education, shared benchmarks, and accessible infrastructure. We call for
reframing AI for science as a collective social project, where sustainable
collaboration and equitable participation are treated as prerequisites for
technical progress.

</details>


### [243] [Information-Theoretic Bounds and Task-Centric Learning Complexity for Real-World Dynamic Nonlinear Systems](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06599)
*Sri Satish Krishna Chaitanya Bulusu,Mikko Sillanpää*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A theoretical framework for modeling dynamic nonlinear systems via structured decomposition, variance analysis, and task-aware complexity bounds; introduces a Behavioral Uncertainty Principle and a memory-thermodynamics link; explains and justifies structured residual learning benefits.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address data-driven modeling challenges from intertwined static and dynamic distortions in complex systems, offering principled bounds, learnability measures, and a thermodynamic grounding beyond classical entropy-based bounds.

Method: Develop a directional interaction bound that extends inner-product orthogonality to structurally asymmetric settings; derive variance inequalities; define a memory finiteness index; establish a power-based first-law link; formulate the Behavioral Uncertainty Principle; prove two theorems connecting variance to mean-squared Lipschitz continuity and to learning complexity; propose a model-agnostic, task-aware complexity metric.
