Result: Establishes bounds and principles showing static/dynamic distortions cannot be minimized simultaneously; shows real systems resist complete deterministic decomposition; provides theorems tying variance to Lipschitz continuity and learning complexity; explains empirical benefits of structured residual learning and aligns with power amplifier experiments; framework is broadly applicable and scalable.

Conclusion: Offers a scalable, theoretically grounded framework for modeling complex dynamic nonlinear systems, clarifying why structured residual learning improves generalization, reduces parameters, and lowers training cost, with broad applicability across domains.

Abstract: Dynamic nonlinear systems exhibit distortions arising from coupled static and
dynamic effects. Their intertwined nature poses major challenges for
data-driven modeling. This paper presents a theoretical framework grounded in
structured decomposition, variance analysis, and task-centric complexity
bounds.
  The framework employs a directional lower bound on interactions between
measurable system components, extending orthogonality in inner product spaces
to structurally asymmetric settings. This bound supports variance inequalities
for decomposed systems. Key behavioral indicators are introduced along with a
memory finiteness index. A rigorous power-based condition establishes a
measurable link between finite memory in realizable systems and the First Law
of Thermodynamics. This offers a more foundational perspective than classical
bounds based on the Second Law.
  Building on this foundation, we formulate a `Behavioral Uncertainty
Principle,' demonstrating that static and dynamic distortions cannot be
minimized simultaneously. We identify that real-world systems seem to resist
complete deterministic decomposition due to entangled static and dynamic
effects. We also present two general-purpose theorems linking function variance
to mean-squared Lipschitz continuity and learning complexity. This yields a
model-agnostic, task-aware complexity metric, showing that lower-variance
components are inherently easier to learn.
  These insights explain the empirical benefits of structured residual
learning, including improved generalization, reduced parameter count, and lower
training cost, as previously observed in power amplifier linearization
experiments. The framework is broadly applicable and offers a scalable,
theoretically grounded approach to modeling complex dynamic nonlinear systems.

</details>


### [244] [PAC-Bayesian Generalization Bounds for Graph Convolutional Networks on Inductive Node Classification](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06600)
*Huayi Tang,Yong Liu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A PAC-Bayesian analysis derives generalization bounds for inductive node classification with GCNs on dynamic graphs, showing one-layer GCNs can achieve vanishing generalization gap under mild conditions, while two-layer GCNs require stronger graph-topology assumptions.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Real-world graphs evolve over time with new nodes and changing edges, making inductive, non-iid, and non-stationary analysis essential; transductive theories fail to capture this temporal dynamics.

Method: Develop a PAC-Bayesian framework for GCNs treating nodes as dependent, non-identically distributed samples. Derive generalization bounds for a one-layer GCN incorporating data dependency and non-stationarity; analyze convergence of the generalization gap as the number of nodes grows; extend the analysis to a two-layer GCN and identify stronger graph-topology requirements.

Result: New generalization bounds that explicitly account for node dependence and non-stationarity in dynamic graphs; conditions under which the generalization gap vanishes with increasing node count for one-layer GCNs; deeper networks require stricter topological assumptions for similar convergence.

Conclusion: Provides a theoretical foundation for understanding and improving GNN generalization in dynamic environments and highlights the role of graph topology in deeper GCNs for ensuring convergence.

Abstract: Graph neural networks (GNNs) have achieved remarkable success in processing
graph-structured data across various applications. A critical aspect of
real-world graphs is their dynamic nature, where new nodes are continually
added and existing connections may change over time. Previous theoretical
studies, largely based on the transductive learning framework, fail to
adequately model such temporal evolution and structural dynamics. In this
paper, we presents a PAC-Bayesian theoretical analysis of graph convolutional
networks (GCNs) for inductive node classification, treating nodes as dependent
and non-identically distributed data points. We derive novel generalization
bounds for one-layer GCNs that explicitly incorporate the effects of data
dependency and non-stationarity, and establish sufficient conditions under
which the generalization gap converges to zero as the number of nodes
increases. Furthermore, we extend our analysis to two-layer GCNs, and reveal
that it requires stronger assumptions on graph topology to guarantee
convergence. This work establishes a theoretical foundation for understanding
and improving GNN generalization in dynamic graph environments.

</details>


### [245] [Demo: Healthcare Agent Orchestrator (HAO) for Patient Summarization in Molecular Tumor Boards](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06602)
*Noel Codella,Sam Preston,Hao Qiu,Leonardo Schettini,Wen-wai Yim,Mert Öz,Shrey Jain,Matthew P. Lungren,Thomas Osborne*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces Healthcare Agent Orchestrator (HAO), an LLM-driven multi-agent system to generate comprehensive MTB patient summaries, and TBFact, a model-as-judge framework for evaluation; demonstrates high information capture and data-free assessment for MTB summaries.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Manual MTB patient summaries are labor-intensive, subjective, and prone to omissions; robust, scalable evaluation of generated summaries is needed.

Method: Develop HAO to coordinate multiple AI agents to create accurate patient histories; develop TBFact to assess summaries' comprehensiveness and succinctness; benchmark on de-identified tumor board discussions; evaluate Patient History agent; demonstrate data-free evaluation.

Result: HAO captured 94% of high-importance information (including partial entailments); TBFact recall 0.84 under strict entailment; TBFact enables local, data-free evaluation.

Conclusion: HAO and TBFact provide a robust foundation for reliable, scalable MTB support with privacy-preserving evaluation, enabling broader deployment.

Abstract: Molecular Tumor Boards (MTBs) are multidisciplinary forums where oncology
specialists collaboratively assess complex patient cases to determine optimal
treatment strategies. A central element of this process is the patient summary,
typically compiled by a medical oncologist, radiation oncologist, or surgeon,
or their trained medical assistant, who distills heterogeneous medical records
into a concise narrative to facilitate discussion. This manual approach is
often labor-intensive, subjective, and prone to omissions of critical
information. To address these limitations, we introduce the Healthcare Agent
Orchestrator (HAO), a Large Language Model (LLM)-driven AI agent that
coordinates a multi-agent clinical workflow to generate accurate and
comprehensive patient summaries for MTBs. Evaluating predicted patient
summaries against ground truth presents additional challenges due to stylistic
variation, ordering, synonym usage, and phrasing differences, which complicate
the measurement of both succinctness and completeness. To overcome these
evaluation hurdles, we propose TBFact, a ``model-as-a-judge'' framework
designed to assess the comprehensiveness and succinctness of generated
summaries. Using a benchmark dataset derived from de-identified tumor board
discussions, we applied TBFact to evaluate our Patient History agent. Results
show that the agent captured 94% of high-importance information (including
partial entailments) and achieved a TBFact recall of 0.84 under strict
entailment criteria. We further demonstrate that TBFact enables a data-free
evaluation framework that institutions can deploy locally without sharing
sensitive clinical data. Together, HAO and TBFact establish a robust foundation
for delivering reliable and scalable support to MTBs.

</details>


### [246] [Small Vectors, Big Effects: A Mechanistic Study of RL-Induced Reasoning via Steering Vectors](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06608)
*Viacheslav Sinii,Nikita Balagansky,Yaroslav Aksenov,Vadim Kurochkin,Daniil Laptev,Gleb Gerasimov,Alexey Gorbatovski,Boris Shaposhnikov,Daniil Gavrilov*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Reasoning training reshapes LM computations via lightweight steering vectors that provide additive, interpretable changes: last-layer vectors bias the first token as a substitution signal; penultimate-layer vectors alter processing via the MLP/unembedding without big attention changes, enabling near full-finetuning performance with simple interventions.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand how reasoning training alters language-model computations and to develop an interpretable, additive intervention framework that can match full fine-tuning performance.

Method: Insert small steering vectors into the base model's residual stream and train them with a reinforcement-learning objective. Analyze two models using logit-lens readouts, path patching, and circuit analyses.

Result: Last-layer steering behaves like a token-substitution bias focused on the first generated token, boosting tokens like ”To” and ”Step.” Penultimate-layer steering leaves attention patterns largely unchanged and acts through the MLP and unembedding, preferentially up-weighting process words and structure symbols.

Conclusion: Provides a principled framework for interpreting the behavioral changes induced by reasoning training and demonstrates that small, additive steering can reproduce strong performance while preserving interpretability.

Abstract: The mechanisms by which reasoning training reshapes language-model
computations remain poorly understood. We study lightweight steering vectors
inserted into the base model's residual stream and trained with a
reinforcement-learning objective, which can match full fine-tuning performance
while retaining the interpretability of small, additive interventions. Using
logit-lens readouts, path patching, and circuit analyses, we analyze two models
and find: (i) the last-layer steering vector behaves like a token-substitution
bias concentrated on the first generated token, consistently boosting tokens
such as "To" and "Step"; and (ii) the penultimate-layer steering vector leaves
attention patterns largely unchanged and instead acts through the MLP and
unembedding, preferentially up-weighting process words and structure symbols.
These results establish a principled framework for interpreting the behavioral
changes induced by reasoning training.

</details>


### [247] [A Survey of Generalization of Graph Anomaly Detection: From Transfer Learning to Foundation Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06609)
*Junjun Pan,Yu Zheng,Yue Tan,Yixin Liu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: This paper surveys generalization in Graph Anomaly Detection (GAD): tracing evolution, formalizing problem settings, proposing a taxonomy, surveying generalized methods across tasks, and outlining open challenges and future directions.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: GAD models often assume stationary distributions and ample labeled data; real-world shifts and data scarcity hinder performance; thus there is a need to understand and improve generalization through transfer learning and foundation models.

Method: Systematic literature review: historical overview of generalization in GAD, formal definitions, development of a taxonomy, and an up-to-date survey of methods organized by taxonomy; identification of gaps and future directions.

Result: A structured taxonomy and comprehensive survey of existing generalized GAD approaches; synthesis of current progress; mapping of methods to generalization scenarios; a roadmap of challenges and opportunities.

Conclusion: Generalization in GAD remains under-explored; calls for standardized benchmarks, better transfer learning frameworks, robust foundation models, and more cross-domain evaluation; encourages future research directions.

Abstract: Graph anomaly detection (GAD) has attracted increasing attention in recent
years for identifying malicious samples in a wide range of graph-based
applications, such as social media and e-commerce. However, most GAD methods
assume identical training and testing distributions and are tailored to
specific tasks, resulting in limited adaptability to real-world scenarios such
as shifting data distributions and scarce training samples in new applications.
To address the limitations, recent work has focused on improving the
generalization capability of GAD models through transfer learning that
leverages knowledge from related domains to enhance detection performance, or
developing "one-for-all" GAD foundation models that generalize across multiple
applications. Since a systematic understanding of generalization in GAD is
still lacking, in this paper, we provide a comprehensive review of
generalization in GAD. We first trace the evolution of generalization in GAD
and formalize the problem settings, which further leads to our systematic
taxonomy. Rooted in this fine-grained taxonomy, an up-to-date and comprehensive
review is conducted for the existing generalized GAD methods. Finally, we
identify current open challenges and suggest future directions to inspire
future research in this emerging field.

</details>


### [248] [BEAM: Brainwave Empathy Assessment Model for Early Childhood](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06620)
*Chen Xie,Gaofeng Wu,Kaidong Wang,Zihao Zhu,Xiaoshu Luo,Yan Liang,Feiyu Quan,Ruoxi Wu,Xianghui Huang,Han Zhang*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A deep-learning framework BEAM uses multi-view EEG to predict empathy in 4-6 year olds, combining LaBraM-based spatio-temporal encoding, fusion, and contrastive learning; tested on CBCP and outperforms baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Empathy prediction in young children is important but difficult; biases in self/observer reports; EEG offers objective measures; existing methods miss temporal dynamics; need a method to capture dynamics.

Method: BEAM architecture with LaBraM-based encoder for spatio-temporal EEG features; a fusion module to combine multi-view signals; a contrastive learning module to improve class separation; evaluated on CBCP dataset.

Result: BEAM outperforms state-of-the-art across multiple metrics on CBCP data; demonstrates objective empathy assessment and potential early interventions.

Conclusion: BEAM provides objective empathy assessment in early childhood, enabling insights into pro-social development and informing interventions.

Abstract: Empathy in young children is crucial for their social and emotional
development, yet predicting it remains challenging. Traditional methods often
only rely on self-reports or observer-based labeling, which are susceptible to
bias and fail to objectively capture the process of empathy formation. EEG
offers an objective alternative; however, current approaches primarily extract
static patterns, neglecting temporal dynamics. To overcome these limitations,
we propose a novel deep learning framework, the Brainwave Empathy Assessment
Model (BEAM), to predict empathy levels in children aged 4-6 years. BEAM
leverages multi-view EEG signals to capture both cognitive and emotional
dimensions of empathy. The framework comprises three key components: 1) a
LaBraM-based encoder for effective spatio-temporal feature extraction, 2) a
feature fusion module to integrate complementary information from multi-view
signals, and 3) a contrastive learning module to enhance class separation.
Validated on the CBCP dataset, BEAM outperforms state-of-the-art methods across
multiple metrics, demonstrating its potential for objective empathy assessment
and providing a preliminary insight into early interventions in children's
prosocial development.

</details>


### [249] [Knowledge-Guided Machine Learning for Stabilizing Near-Shortest Path Routing](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06640)
*Yung-Fu Chen,Sen Lin,Anish Arora*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A sample-efficient, domain-informed learning framework to derive local routing policies on geometric graphs; it yields exact greedy forwarding and a superior Greedy Tensile routing, with interpretable, ultra-fast DNN-based decisions.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address all-pairs near-shortest path routing on geometric graphs with scalable, local decision policies learned from few samples, while ensuring generalization across a rich class of Euclidean networks.

Method: Train deep neural networks that use only local node states and neighbor states as inputs. Leverage domain knowledge to select features and policy structure, including a seed graph with sampled node data to enable generalization. Compare two policies: (1) distance-to-destination only, which recovers Greedy Forwarding, and (2) distance-to-destination plus node stretch, yielding Greedy Tensile routing. Explainability is pursued by symbolically interpreting the trained DNN as simple linear actions.

Result: The network learns Greedy Forwarding exactly when using distance-to-destination. Greedy Tensile routing outperforms Greedy Forwarding in most cases. The approach offers explainability and ultra-low-latency runtime, demonstrated by a symbolic, low-complexity interpretation of the DNN.

Conclusion: A simple, sample-efficient learning paradigm with domain-informed features and seed-based generalization can produce local routing policies that perform near-optimally across geometric random graphs, with interpretable models and scalable, fast routing.

Abstract: We propose a simple algorithm that needs only a few data samples from a
single graph for learning local routing policies that generalize across a rich
class of geometric random graphs in Euclidean metric spaces. We thus solve the
all-pairs near-shortest path problem by training deep neural networks (DNNs)
that let each graph node efficiently and scalably route (i.e., forward) packets
by considering only the node's state and the state of the neighboring nodes.
Our algorithm design exploits network domain knowledge in the selection of
input features and design of the policy function for learning an approximately
optimal policy. Domain knowledge also provides theoretical assurance that the
choice of a ``seed graph'' and its node data sampling suffices for
generalizable learning. Remarkably, one of these DNNs we train -- using
distance-to-destination as the only input feature -- learns a policy that
exactly matches the well-known Greedy Forwarding policy, which forwards packets
to the neighbor with the shortest distance to the destination. We also learn a
new policy, which we call GreedyTensile routing -- using both
distance-to-destination and node stretch as the input features -- that almost
always outperforms greedy forwarding. We demonstrate the explainability and
ultra-low latency run-time operation of Greedy Tensile routing by symbolically
interpreting its DNN in low-complexity terms of two linear actions.

</details>


### [250] [Group Effect Enhanced Generative Adversarial Imitation Learning for Individual Travel Behavior Modeling under Incentives](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06656)
*Yuanyuan Wu,Zhenlin Qin,Leizhen Wang,Xiaolei Ma,Zhenliang Ma*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: gcGAIL uses group-effect enhanced imitation learning to model individual travel behavior more efficiently, achieving higher accuracy and robustness than AIRL, GAIL, and conditional GAIL in a public transport fare-discount case study.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Data-intensive MDP modeling of individual travel behavior faces limitations in data quantity, spatial-temporal coverage, and situational diversity; leveraging shared patterns among passenger groups can improve learning efficiency and generalization.

Method: Introduce gcGAIL, a group-effect enhanced generative adversarial imitation learning framework. It leverages shared behavioral patterns across passenger groups to imitate incentives responses, reduces data requirements, and is validated against AIRL, baseline GAIL, and conditional GAIL using a fare-discount case study. Demonstrates robustness to sparsity and spatial variation with partial expert demonstrations.

Result: gcGAIL outperforms baseline methods in learning individual travel behavior responses to incentives—achieving higher accuracy, better generalization, and more efficient demonstration usage. It remains robust to spatial variation, data sparsity, and behavioral diversity, including underrepresented groups, and can predict responses at any time.

Conclusion: gcGAIL enables accurate, generalizable, and efficient modeling of individual travel behavior in response to incentives, facilitating personalized incentive timing to promote sustainable behavior changes.

Abstract: Understanding and modeling individual travel behavior responses is crucial
for urban mobility regulation and policy evaluation. The Markov decision
process (MDP) provides a structured framework for dynamic travel behavior
modeling at the individual level. However, solving an MDP in this context is
highly data-intensive and faces challenges of data quantity, spatial-temporal
coverage, and situational diversity. To address these, we propose a
group-effect-enhanced generative adversarial imitation learning (gcGAIL) model
that improves the individual behavior modeling efficiency by leveraging shared
behavioral patterns among passenger groups. We validate the gcGAIL model using
a public transport fare-discount case study and compare against
state-of-the-art benchmarks, including adversarial inverse reinforcement
learning (AIRL), baseline GAIL, and conditional GAIL. Experimental results
demonstrate that gcGAIL outperforms these methods in learning individual travel
behavior responses to incentives over time in terms of accuracy,
generalization, and pattern demonstration efficiency. Notably, gcGAIL is robust
to spatial variation, data sparsity, and behavioral diversity, maintaining
strong performance even with partial expert demonstrations and underrepresented
passenger groups. The gcGAIL model predicts the individual behavior response at
any time, providing the basis for personalized incentives to induce sustainable
behavior changes (better timing of incentive injections).

</details>


### [251] [TrajAware: Graph Cross-Attention and Trajectory-Aware for Generalisable VANETs under Partial Observations](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06665)
*Xiaolu Fu,Ziyuan Bao,Eiman Kanjo*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: TrajAware is an edge-friendly RL framework for VANET routing that combines action-space pruning, graph cross-attention, and trajectory-aware prediction to handle dynamic topologies and partial observations, achieving near-shortest paths, high delivery ratios, and efficiency on constrained devices, outperforming baselines in full and partial observation settings.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: VANET routing with RL often assumes fixed graph structures and retraining needs, which is impractical for constrained edge devices and dynamic networks. There is a need for generalizable, resource-efficient RL approaches that can operate under partial observations.

Method: (i) action space pruning to cut redundant neighbor options while preserving two-hop reachability; (ii) graph cross-attention to map pruned neighbors into global graph context, producing size-generalizable features; (iii) trajectory-aware prediction to estimate real-time positions from historical routes and junction info under partial observations. Evaluation uses SUMO with leave-one-city-out in real-city maps.

Result: Empirical results show TrajAware achieves near-shortest paths and high delivery ratios while maintaining efficiency suitable for constrained edge devices, outperforming state-of-the-art baselines in both full and partial observation scenarios.

Conclusion: TrajAware offers a robust, scalable, edge-deployable RL framework for VANET routing that generalizes across network sizes and observation conditions, enabling effective routing in dynamic urban environments without frequent retraining.

Abstract: Vehicular ad hoc networks (VANETs) are a crucial component of intelligent
transportation systems; however, routing remains challenging due to dynamic
topologies, incomplete observations, and the limited resources of edge devices.
Existing reinforcement learning (RL) approaches often assume fixed graph
structures and require retraining when network conditions change, making them
unsuitable for deployment on constrained hardware. We present TrajAware, an
RL-based framework designed for edge AI deployment in VANETs. TrajAware
integrates three components: (i) action space pruning, which reduces redundant
neighbour options while preserving two-hop reachability, alleviating the curse
of dimensionality; (ii) graph cross-attention, which maps pruned neighbours to
the global graph context, producing features that generalise across diverse
network sizes; and (iii) trajectory-aware prediction, which uses historical
routes and junction information to estimate real-time positions under partial
observations. We evaluate TrajAware in the open-source SUMO simulator using
real-world city maps with a leave-one-city-out setup. Results show that
TrajAware achieves near-shortest paths and high delivery ratios while
maintaining efficiency suitable for constrained edge devices, outperforming
state-of-the-art baselines in both full and partial observation scenarios.

</details>


### [252] [Barycentric Neural Networks and Length-Weighted Persistent Entropy Loss: A Green Geometric and Topological Framework for Function Approximation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06694)
*Victor Toscano-Duran,Rocio Gonzalez-Diaz,Miguel A. Gutiérrez-Naranjo*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A small shallow model called the Barycentric Neural Network (BNN) uses fixed base points and barycentric coordinates to exactly represent continuous piecewise linear functions, enabling efficient function approximation. It introduces a new topological loss, length-weighted persistent entropy (LWPE), and optimizes base points (not internal weights) for learning, achieving faster and better performance under resource constraints.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the computational cost and inefficiency of deep/overparameterized networks while retaining universal approximation capabilities by using a compact, interpretable, geometry-informed model and a topology-aware loss.

Method: Define a BN N with fixed base points and barycentric coordinates to represent CPLFs exactly; leverage the fact that continuous functions on compact domains can be approximated by CPLFs. Introduce LWPE, a stable, scale-invariant variant of persistent entropy weighted by feature lifetimes, and use it as a loss. Optimize the base points directly rather than internal weights, combining BN N with LWPE loss.

Result: Empirical results show superior and faster approximation performance compared to standard losses (MSE, RMSE, MAE, log-cosh) under resource-constrained settings.

Conclusion: BNN, together with LWPE, offers a flexible, geometrically interpretable approach to function approximation that is particularly suitable for resource-limited scenarios (few base points, few training epochs) and provides a bridge between neural and topological methods.

Abstract: While it is well-established that artificial neural networks are
\emph{universal approximators} for continuous functions on compact domains,
many modern approaches rely on deep or overparameterized architectures that
incur high computational costs. In this paper, a new type of \emph{small
shallow} neural network, called the \emph{Barycentric Neural Network} ($\BNN$),
is proposed, which leverages a fixed set of \emph{base points} and their
\emph{barycentric coordinates} to define both its structure and its parameters.
We demonstrate that our $\BNN$ enables the exact representation of
\emph{continuous piecewise linear functions} ($\CPLF$s), ensuring strict
continuity across segments. Since any continuous function over a compact domain
can be approximated arbitrarily well by $\CPLF$s, the $\BNN$ naturally emerges
as a flexible and interpretable tool for \emph{function approximation}. Beyond
the use of this representation, the main contribution of the paper is the
introduction of a new variant of \emph{persistent entropy}, a topological
feature that is stable and scale invariant, called the \emph{length-weighted
persistent entropy} ($\LWPE$), which is weighted by the lifetime of topological
features. Our framework, which combines the $\BNN$ with a loss function based
on our $\LWPE$, aims to provide flexible and geometrically interpretable
approximations of nonlinear continuous functions in resource-constrained
settings, such as those with limited base points for $\BNN$ design and few
training epochs. Instead of optimizing internal weights, our approach directly
\emph{optimizes the base points that define the $\BNN$}. Experimental results
show that our approach achieves \emph{superior and faster approximation
performance} compared to classical loss functions such as MSE, RMSE, MAE, and
log-cosh.

</details>


### [253] [Probabilistic Modeling of Latent Agentic Substructures in Deep Neural Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06701)
*Su Hyeong Lee,Risi Kondor,Richard Ngo*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A probabilistic theory of intelligent agency for neural models, where agents are outcome distributions with log-score utility, composed via weighted logarithmic pooling. It proves bounds on unanimous agreement under pooling, develops a recursive, clone-invariant framework, and applies it to LLM alignment, showing benevolent prompts can induce antagonistic countermodels and that certain strategies yield larger misalignment reductions than pure reinforcement.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To provide a principled mathematical framework for how subagents can cohere into higher-level intelligent entities, formalize aggregation via probabilistic pooling, and explore how these dynamics affect alignment in AI systems, including LLMs.

Method: Represent agents as outcome distributions with epistemic utility given by log score. Use weighted logarithmic pooling to compose agents, proving properties like strict unanimity behavior: impossible under linear pooling or binary outcomes, possible with three or more outcomes. Establish recursive structure through cloning invariance, continuity, and openness, and apply tilt-based analysis to avoid trivial duplication. Demonstrate agentic alignment phenomena in LLMs by eliciting a benevolent persona (Luigi) and observing an antagonistic counterpart (Waluigi), comparing strategies such as manifest-then-suppress Waluigi versus Luigi reinforcement.

Result: Demonstrates that strict unanimity cannot be achieved with linear pooling or in binary-outcome spaces, but is achievable with three or more outcomes. Provides a recursive, continuous, and open framework for subagent coalescence, with tilt-based analysis ruling out trivial duplications. In LLM experiments, Luigified prompts spur Waluigi antagonism; a manifest-then-suppress Waluigi strategy yields greater first-order misalignment reduction than pure Luigi reinforcement alone.

Conclusion: The paper offers a principled mathematical framework for subagents coalescing into coherent higher-level agents and delivers new implications for alignment in agentic AI systems, including nontrivial dynamics in LLM-based alignment and guidance for designing aggregation mechanisms that promote coherent, aligned behavior.

Abstract: We develop a theory of intelligent agency grounded in probabilistic modeling
for neural models. Agents are represented as outcome distributions with
epistemic utility given by log score, and compositions are defined through
weighted logarithmic pooling that strictly improves every member's welfare. We
prove that strict unanimity is impossible under linear pooling or in binary
outcome spaces, but possible with three or more outcomes. Our framework admits
recursive structure via cloning invariance, continuity, and openness, while
tilt-based analysis rules out trivial duplication. Finally, we formalize an
agentic alignment phenomenon in LLMs using our theory: eliciting a benevolent
persona ("Luigi'") induces an antagonistic counterpart ("Waluigi"), while a
manifest-then-suppress Waluigi strategy yields strictly larger first-order
misalignment reduction than pure Luigi reinforcement alone. These results
clarify how developing a principled mathematical framework for how subagents
can coalesce into coherent higher-level entities provides novel implications
for alignment in agentic AI systems.

</details>


### [254] [Nested Optimal Transport Distances](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06702)
*Ruben Bontorno,Songyan Hou*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes a time-causal nested optimal transport distance as a robust evaluation metric for generative models of financial time series in decision-making tasks, and introduces a statistically consistent, parallelizable algorithm that achieves substantial speedups over existing methods.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: There is no consensus metric for evaluating deep generative models of financial time series in decision-making contexts. Robust metrics are needed for stress testing, scenario generation, hedging, and RL-enabled decisions.

Method: Adopt the nested optimal transport distance (a time-causal variant) as the evaluation metric and develop a statistically consistent, naturally parallelizable algorithm for its computation, designed to be robust for tasks like hedging, optimal stopping, and reinforcement learning.

Result: The algorithm achieves substantial speedups over existing approaches while providing a robust, task-appropriate evaluation metric for financial time series in decision-making settings.

Conclusion: A robust, scalable evaluation framework for generative AI in financial time series is established, enabling reliable assessment across hedging, stopping, and RL tasks and enabling faster computation.

Abstract: Simulating realistic financial time series is essential for stress testing,
scenario generation, and decision-making under uncertainty. Despite advances in
deep generative models, there is no consensus metric for their evaluation. We
focus on generative AI for financial time series in decision-making
applications and employ the nested optimal transport distance, a time-causal
variant of optimal transport distance, which is robust to tasks such as
hedging, optimal stopping, and reinforcement learning. Moreover, we propose a
statistically consistent, naturally parallelizable algorithm for its
computation, achieving substantial speedups over existing approaches.

</details>


### [255] [RT-HCP: Dealing with Inference Delays and Sample Efficiency to Learn Directly on Robotic Platforms](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06714)
*Zakariae El Asri,Ibrahim Laiche,Clément Rambour,Olivier Sigaud,Nicolas Thome*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Proposes RT-HCP and a general framework to handle inference delays in model-based RL, achieving a favorable trade-off between performance, sample efficiency, and inference time; validated on a high-frequency Furuta pendulum with open-source code.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To enable sample-efficient robot learning while meeting real-time control frequency constraints, addressing the gap where model-based RL is efficient in data but slow in inference.

Method: Define a generic framework for dealing with inference delays by feeding a sequence of actions from a slow, high-level controller to a fast execution platform without gaps; compare multiple RL algorithms under this framework and introduce RT-HCP as a practical solution.

Result: RT-HCP achieves an excellent balance among performance, sample efficiency, and inference time in experiments; demonstrates viability of learning a controller directly on a high-frequency robot platform (FURUTA pendulum).

Conclusion: The proposed framework and RT-HCP offer a practical, generalizable approach for real-time, sample-efficient robotic control; code is available for reproducibility (GitHub).

Abstract: Learning a controller directly on the robot requires extreme sample
efficiency. Model-based reinforcement learning (RL) methods are the most sample
efficient, but they often suffer from a too long inference time to meet the
robot control frequency requirements. In this paper, we address the sample
efficiency and inference time challenges with two contributions. First, we
define a general framework to deal with inference delays where the slow
inference robot controller provides a sequence of actions to feed the
control-hungry robotic platform without execution gaps. Then, we compare
several RL algorithms in the light of this framework and propose RT-HCP, an
algorithm that offers an excellent trade-off between performance, sample
efficiency and inference time. We validate the superiority of RT-HCP with
experiments where we learn a controller directly on a simple but high frequency
FURUTA pendulum platform. Code: github.com/elasriz/RTHCP

</details>


### [256] [Long-Range Graph Wavelet Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06743)
*Filippo Guerranti,Fabrizio Forte,Simon Geisler,Stephan Günnemann*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: LR-GWN proposes a long-range graph wavelet network that splits wavelet filters into a local, low-order polynomial part and a global, flexible spectral part to capture long-range interactions. This hybrid approach unifies short- and long-distance information flow within a principled wavelet framework, achieving state-of-the-art performance among wavelet-based methods on long-range benchmarks while remaining competitive on short-range data.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Graph neural networks struggle to propagate information across long distances in large graphs. Wavelet-based GNNs capture multi-scale structure but rely on finite-order polynomial approximations, limiting receptive fields. A hybrid design aims to extend the effective range of information propagation without sacrificing locality.

Method: Decompose wavelet filters into complementary local and global components. Use efficient low-order polynomials for local aggregation, and a flexible spectral-domain parameterization to model long-range interactions. Integrate these within a unified wavelet framework to enable simultaneous short- and long-distance information flow.

Result: Empirical evaluations show LR-GWN achieves state-of-the-art performance among wavelet-based methods on long-range benchmarks and remains competitive on short-range datasets.

Conclusion: A hybrid wavelet design successfully unifies short- and long-distance information flow, enhancing long-range propagation while preserving short-range performance; supports broader applicability of wavelet-based GNNs with spectral parameterization.

Abstract: Modeling long-range interactions, the propagation of information across
distant parts of a graph, is a central challenge in graph machine learning.
Graph wavelets, inspired by multi-resolution signal processing, provide a
principled way to capture both local and global structures. However, existing
wavelet-based graph neural networks rely on finite-order polynomial
approximations, which limit their receptive fields and hinder long-range
propagation. We propose Long-Range Graph Wavelet Networks (LR-GWN), which
decompose wavelet filters into complementary local and global components. Local
aggregation is handled with efficient low-order polynomials, while long-range
interactions are captured through a flexible spectral domain parameterization.
This hybrid design unifies short- and long-distance information flow within a
principled wavelet framework. Experiments show that LR-GWN achieves
state-of-the-art performance among wavelet-based methods on long-range
benchmarks, while remaining competitive on short-range datasets.

</details>


### [257] [Aligning Large Vision-Language Models by Deep Reinforcement Learning and Direct Preference Optimization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06759)
*Thanh Thi Nguyen,Campbell Wilson,Janis Dalins*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: LVLMs can be better aligned and made more adaptive by integrating DRL and DPO, enabling reward-driven policy optimization and direct preference alignment for multimodal tasks; the work surveys paradigms, data sources, signals, and challenges.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address the critical need for aligning LVLMs with human values, improving task performance, and enabling adaptive multimodal interaction in a scalable, safe, and generalizable manner.

Method: Conceptual overview / survey that categorizes DRL- and DPO-based fine-tuning approaches for LVLMs, analyzes sources of preference data and reward signals, and discusses scalability, continual learning, generalization, and safety.

Result: Provides a synthesized framework showing how DRL and DPO contribute to robust, human-aligned LVLMs; highlights open challenges and outlines directions for improving scalability, sample efficiency, continual learning, generalization, and safety.

Conclusion: DRL and DPO offer complementary pathways for aligning LVLMs with human preferences. Future work should focus on improving efficiency, generalization, and safety while enabling adaptive multimodal interaction.

Abstract: Large Vision-Language Models (LVLMs) or multimodal large language models
represent a significant advancement in artificial intelligence, enabling
systems to understand and generate content across both visual and textual
modalities. While large-scale pretraining has driven substantial progress,
fine-tuning these models for aligning with human values or engaging in specific
tasks or behaviors remains a critical challenge. Deep Reinforcement Learning
(DRL) and Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) offer promising frameworks for
this aligning process. While DRL enables models to optimize actions using
reward signals instead of relying solely on supervised preference data, DPO
directly aligns the policy with preferences, eliminating the need for an
explicit reward model. This overview explores paradigms for fine-tuning LVLMs,
highlighting how DRL and DPO techniques can be used to align models with human
preferences and values, improve task performance, and enable adaptive
multimodal interaction. We categorize key approaches, examine sources of
preference data, reward signals, and discuss open challenges such as
scalability, sample efficiency, continual learning, generalization, and safety.
The goal is to provide a clear understanding of how DRL and DPO contribute to
the evolution of robust and human-aligned LVLMs.

</details>


### [258] [Asynchronous Message Passing for Addressing Oversquashing in Graph Neural Networks](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06777)
*Kushal Bose,Swagatam Das*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: An asynchronous, model-agnostic GNN framework that updates node features in layer-wise batches based on centrality to mitigate oversquashing, avoiding fixed-capacity bottlenecks while maintaining inductive bias; shows improvements on long-range tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Oversquashing bottlenecks hinder long-range information flow in GNNs; graph rewiring can help but often degrades inductive bias and increases complexity; there is a need for a lightweight, scalable solution with preserved inductive biases.

Method: In each layer, form node batches according to centrality; update features only for nodes in the current batch; perform asynchronous message updates sequentially across layers rather than synchronous all-at-once passing; provide theoretical bounds showing higher feature sensitivity than standard synchronous methods; evaluate on six standard datasets and two long-range datasets for graph classification.

Result: Achieves 5% improvement on REDDIT-BINARY and 4% on Peptides-struct; competitive or improved performance on other datasets; demonstrates effective mitigation of oversquashing with modest computational overhead.

Conclusion: The proposed asynchronous feature-update framework offers a model-agnostic, scalable path to tackling oversquashing while preserving inductive biases and maintaining performance on long-range graph tasks.

Abstract: Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) suffer from Oversquashing, which occurs when
tasks require long-range interactions. The problem arises from the presence of
bottlenecks that limit the propagation of messages among distant nodes.
Recently, graph rewiring methods modify edge connectivity and are expected to
perform well on long-range tasks. Yet, graph rewiring compromises the inductive
bias, incurring significant information loss in solving the downstream task.
Furthermore, increasing channel capacity may overcome information bottlenecks
but enhance the parameter complexity of the model. To alleviate these
shortcomings, we propose an efficient model-agnostic framework that
asynchronously updates node features, unlike traditional synchronous message
passing GNNs. Our framework creates node batches in every layer based on the
node centrality values. The features of the nodes belonging to these batches
will only get updated. Asynchronous message updates process information
sequentially across layers, avoiding simultaneous compression into
fixed-capacity channels. We also theoretically establish that our proposed
framework maintains higher feature sensitivity bounds compared to standard
synchronous approaches. Our framework is applied to six standard graph datasets
and two long-range datasets to perform graph classification and achieves
impressive performances with a $5\%$ and $4\%$ improvements on REDDIT-BINARY
and Peptides-struct, respectively.

</details>


### [259] [Physics-informed Value Learner for Offline Goal-Conditioned Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06782)
*Vittorio Giammarino,Ruiqi Ni,Ahmed H. Qureshi*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Introduces a physics-informed regularizer for value learning in offline GCRL based on the Eikonal PDE, embedding a geometric cost-to-go bias; when paired with Hierarchical Implicit Q-Learning (HIQL) as Pi-HIQL, it improves performance and generalization, especially in stitching regimes and large navigation tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Offline GCRL struggles with limited state-action coverage and long-horizon generalization. A physics-inspired, continuous-time optimal-control prior can stabilize learning and encourage value functions to reflect cost-to-go structures.

Method: Derives a Pi regularizer from the Eikonal PDE to regularize the value function during TD-based learning. The regularizer imposes a geometric inductive bias aligned with cost-to-go and is compatible with existing offline GCRL methods. It is combined with HIQL to form Physics-informed HIQL (Pi-HIQL).

Result: The Pi regularizer leads to notable improvements in performance and generalization, with pronounced gains in stitching regimes and large-scale navigation tasks.

Conclusion: A physics-informed, PDE-based regularizer provides a principled inductive bias for value learning in offline GCRL, stabilizing training and enhancing generalization. When integrated with HIQL (Pi-HIQL), it yields strong empirical gains in challenging long-horizon navigation scenarios.

Abstract: Offline Goal-Conditioned Reinforcement Learning (GCRL) holds great promise
for domains such as autonomous navigation and locomotion, where collecting
interactive data is costly and unsafe. However, it remains challenging in
practice due to the need to learn from datasets with limited coverage of the
state-action space and to generalize across long-horizon tasks. To improve on
these challenges, we propose a Physics-informed (Pi) regularized loss for value
learning, derived from the Eikonal Partial Differential Equation (PDE) and
which induces a geometric inductive bias in the learned value function. Unlike
generic gradient penalties that are primarily used to stabilize training, our
formulation is grounded in continuous-time optimal control and encourages value
functions to align with cost-to-go structures. The proposed regularizer is
broadly compatible with temporal-difference-based value learning and can be
integrated into existing Offline GCRL algorithms. When combined with
Hierarchical Implicit Q-Learning (HIQL), the resulting method, Physics-informed
HIQL (Pi-HIQL), yields significant improvements in both performance and
generalization, with pronounced gains in stitching regimes and large-scale
navigation tasks.

</details>


### [260] [\texttt{R$^\textbf{2}$AI}: Towards Resistant and Resilient AI in an Evolving World](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06786)
*Youbang Sun,Xiang Wang,Jie Fu,Chaochao Lu,Bowen Zhou*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A position paper proposes safe-by-coevolution and R^2AI to achieve ongoing, proactive AI safety through adversarial, dynamic learning, combining fast/slow safe models and wind-tunnel testing.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Bridges the gap between rapid AI capability growth and safety progress; critiques post-hoc safety and intrinsic-safety approaches; advocates adaptive safety in open-ended environments inspired by biological immunity.

Method: Define safe-by-coevolution; present R^2AI framework integrating fast/slow safe models, adversarial simulation and verification via a safety wind tunnel, and continual feedback loops to coevolve safety and capability.

Result: Conceptual framework with a vision for scalable, proactive safety; no empirical results yet; aims to address near-term vulnerabilities and long-term existential risks toward AGI/ASI.

Conclusion: R^2AI and safe-by-coevolution offer a dynamic, adversarial safety paradigm that could enable continual, scalable safety in evolving AI systems.

Abstract: In this position paper, we address the persistent gap between rapidly growing
AI capabilities and lagging safety progress. Existing paradigms divide into
``Make AI Safe'', which applies post-hoc alignment and guardrails but remains
brittle and reactive, and ``Make Safe AI'', which emphasizes intrinsic safety
but struggles to address unforeseen risks in open-ended environments. We
therefore propose \textit{safe-by-coevolution} as a new formulation of the
``Make Safe AI'' paradigm, inspired by biological immunity, in which safety
becomes a dynamic, adversarial, and ongoing learning process. To operationalize
this vision, we introduce \texttt{R$^2$AI} -- \textit{Resistant and Resilient
AI} -- as a practical framework that unites resistance against known threats
with resilience to unforeseen risks. \texttt{R$^2$AI} integrates \textit{fast
and slow safe models}, adversarial simulation and verification through a
\textit{safety wind tunnel}, and continual feedback loops that guide safety and
capability to coevolve. We argue that this framework offers a scalable and
proactive path to maintain continual safety in dynamic environments, addressing
both near-term vulnerabilities and long-term existential risks as AI advances
toward AGI and ASI.

</details>


### [261] [floq: Training Critics via Flow-Matching for Scaling Compute in Value-Based RL](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06863)
*Bhavya Agrawalla,Michal Nauman,Khush Agarwal,Aviral Kumar*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Floq uses a flow-matching Q-function parameterized by a velocity field trained via TD-learning with iterative numerical integration; it acts as an adjustable-capacity, flowing Quantum-like value function.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Dense supervision of intermediate computations in modern models suggests iterative computation can boost learning; applying this to RL value learning may overcome fixed, monolithic Q-functions and improve scalability.

Method: Parameterize Q(s,a) as the integral of a velocity field (a flow) over time. Train with flow-matching techniques, bootstrapping from a target velocity field obtained by running multiple integration steps. The number of integration steps serves as a capacity knob for the Q-function.

Result: On offline RL benchmarks and online fine-tuning tasks, floq yields about 1.8x performance improvements and scales capacity more effectively than standard TD-learning architectures.

Conclusion: Iterative, flow-based value learning via velocity-field Q-functions offers a scalable and effective alternative to traditional TD methods, with strong empirical gains across tasks.

Abstract: A hallmark of modern large-scale machine learning techniques is the use of
training objectives that provide dense supervision to intermediate
computations, such as teacher forcing the next token in language models or
denoising step-by-step in diffusion models. This enables models to learn
complex functions in a generalizable manner. Motivated by this observation, we
investigate the benefits of iterative computation for temporal difference (TD)
methods in reinforcement learning (RL). Typically they represent value
functions in a monolithic fashion, without iterative compute. We introduce floq
(flow-matching Q-functions), an approach that parameterizes the Q-function
using a velocity field and trains it using techniques from flow-matching,
typically used in generative modeling. This velocity field underneath the flow
is trained using a TD-learning objective, which bootstraps from values produced
by a target velocity field, computed by running multiple steps of numerical
integration. Crucially, floq allows for more fine-grained control and scaling
of the Q-function capacity than monolithic architectures, by appropriately
setting the number of integration steps. Across a suite of challenging offline
RL benchmarks and online fine-tuning tasks, floq improves performance by nearly
1.8x. floq scales capacity far better than standard TD-learning architectures,
highlighting the potential of iterative computation for value learning.

</details>


### [262] [Concolic Testing on Individual Fairness of Neural Network Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06864)
*Ming-I Huang,Chih-Duo Hong,Fang Yu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: PyFair is a formal framework that uses concolic testing with a dual-network design to test and verify individual fairness in DNNs. It provides completeness guarantees for some architectures, is evaluated on 25 models, and can detect discriminatory instances but faces scalability challenges on large models.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Growing reliance on DNNs in high-stakes decisions requires reliable, verifiable fairness guarantees; existing bias mitigation lacks rigorous verification and completeness.

Method: Adapts PyCT concolic testing to generate fairness-specific path constraints; introduces a dual-network architecture to enable comprehensive fairness assessment and, for some network types, completeness guarantees; evaluates on 25 benchmark models including bias-mitigated ones.

Result: PyFair effectively detects discriminatory instances and verifies fairness; reveals scalability challenges for complex models.

Conclusion: PyFair advances algorithmic fairness by providing a rigorous, systematic framework for fairness testing and verification of pre-trained DNNs, while outlining scalability limitations and directions for future improvement.

Abstract: This paper introduces PyFair, a formal framework for evaluating and verifying
individual fairness of Deep Neural Networks (DNNs). By adapting the concolic
testing tool PyCT, we generate fairness-specific path constraints to
systematically explore DNN behaviors. Our key innovation is a dual network
architecture that enables comprehensive fairness assessments and provides
completeness guarantees for certain network types. We evaluate PyFair on 25
benchmark models, including those enhanced by existing bias mitigation
techniques. Results demonstrate PyFair's efficacy in detecting discriminatory
instances and verifying fairness, while also revealing scalability challenges
for complex models. This work advances algorithmic fairness in critical domains
by offering a rigorous, systematic method for fairness testing and verification
of pre-trained DNNs.

</details>


### [263] [AxelSMOTE: An Agent-Based Oversampling Algorithm for Imbalanced Classification](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06875)
*Sukumar Kishanthan,Asela Hevapathige*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: AxelSMOTE is a culture-inspired, agent-based oversampling method that uses trait-based feature grouping, similarity-driven interactions, Beta-distributed interpolation, and controlled diversity to improve minority-class performance, showing superior results on eight imbalanced datasets with good efficiency.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address class imbalance and overcome the drawbacks of traditional oversampling methods: treating features independently, lacking similarity-based control, limiting sample diversity, and failing to manage synthetic variety.

Method: An agent-based framework grounded in Axelrod's cultural dissemination model. Key components include (1) trait-based feature grouping to preserve correlations, (2) a similarity-based probabilistic exchange mechanism for meaningful interactions, (3) Beta distribution blending for realistic interpolation of samples, and (4) controlled diversity injection to prevent overfitting.

Result: Empirical evaluation on eight imbalanced datasets showing AxelSMOTE outperforms state-of-the-art sampling methods while maintaining computational efficiency.

Conclusion: AxelSMOTE introduces a novel, effective, and efficient oversampling strategy that leverages social-agent dynamics to enhance minority-class learning while preserving feature correlations and controlling synthetic diversity.

Abstract: Class imbalance in machine learning poses a significant challenge, as skewed
datasets often hinder performance on minority classes. Traditional oversampling
techniques, which are commonly used to alleviate class imbalance, have several
drawbacks: they treat features independently, lack similarity-based controls,
limit sample diversity, and fail to manage synthetic variety effectively. To
overcome these issues, we introduce AxelSMOTE, an innovative agent-based
approach that views data instances as autonomous agents engaging in complex
interactions. Based on Axelrod's cultural dissemination model, AxelSMOTE
implements four key innovations: (1) trait-based feature grouping to preserve
correlations; (2) a similarity-based probabilistic exchange mechanism for
meaningful interactions; (3) Beta distribution blending for realistic
interpolation; and (4) controlled diversity injection to avoid overfitting.
Experiments on eight imbalanced datasets demonstrate that AxelSMOTE outperforms
state-of-the-art sampling methods while maintaining computational efficiency.

</details>


### [264] [Not All Samples Are Equal: Quantifying Instance-level Difficulty in Targeted Data Poisoning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06896)
*William Xu,Yiwei Lu,Yihan Wang,Matthew Y. R. Yang,Zuoqiu Liu,Gautam Kamath,Yaoliang Yu*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Three predictive criteria—ergodic prediction accuracy, poison distance, and poison budget—predict the difficulty of targeted data poisoning on a test instance, demonstrated by experiments across scenarios.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Targeted data poisoning threatens individual test instances and requires understanding why some samples are more vulnerable, enabling vulnerability assessment and risk mitigation.

Method: Define three predictive criteria and empirically evaluate them: ergodic prediction accuracy via clean training dynamics, poison distance, and poison budget. Conduct experiments across real-world targeted poisoning attacks and diverse datasets to assess predictive power.

Result: The proposed metrics correlate with attack difficulty and reliably predict which test samples are more susceptible to targeted poisoning, offering practical guidance for vulnerability assessment.

Conclusion: These criteria provide actionable, instance-level metrics for vulnerability assessment and can inform the design of defenses to reduce susceptibility of high-risk samples.

Abstract: Targeted data poisoning attacks pose an increasingly serious threat due to
their ease of deployment and high success rates. These attacks aim to
manipulate the prediction for a single test sample in classification models.
Unlike indiscriminate attacks that aim to decrease overall test performance,
targeted attacks present a unique threat to individual test instances. This
threat model raises a fundamental question: what factors make certain test
samples more susceptible to successful poisoning than others? We investigate
how attack difficulty varies across different test instances and identify key
characteristics that influence vulnerability. This paper introduces three
predictive criteria for targeted data poisoning difficulty: ergodic prediction
accuracy (analyzed through clean training dynamics), poison distance, and
poison budget. Our experimental results demonstrate that these metrics
effectively predict the varying difficulty of real-world targeted poisoning
attacks across diverse scenarios, offering practitioners valuable insights for
vulnerability assessment and understanding data poisoning attacks.

</details>


### [265] [Tackling the Noisy Elephant in the Room: Label Noise-robust Out-of-Distribution Detection via Loss Correction and Low-rank Decomposition](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06918)
*Tarhib Al Azad,Shahana Ibrahim*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A robust OOD detection framework that addresses noisy labels by fusing loss-correction methods from noisy-label learning with low-rank/sparse decomposition, achieving strong gains over state-of-the-art under heavy label noise.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: OOD detection is essential for safe AI; label noise routinely degrades performance and existing naive combos are insufficient; there is a need for principled robust approaches.

Method: Combine loss-correction techniques from noisy-label learning with low-rank and sparse decomposition (signal-processing inspired) to jointly mitigate label noise and separate in-distribution vs out-of-distribution signals, evaluated on synthetic and real-world datasets.

Result: Significant improvements over state-of-the-art OOD methods, especially under severe label-noise scenarios; method demonstrates robustness and generalization across datasets.

Conclusion: The integrated framework provides a principled path for robust OOD detection under label noise and highlights the value of cross-disciplinary techniques; suggests directions for future work and deployment in safety-critical AI.

Abstract: Robust out-of-distribution (OOD) detection is an indispensable component of
modern artificial intelligence (AI) systems, especially in safety-critical
applications where models must identify inputs from unfamiliar classes not seen
during training. While OOD detection has been extensively studied in the
machine learning literature--with both post hoc and training-based
approaches--its effectiveness under noisy training labels remains
underexplored. Recent studies suggest that label noise can significantly
degrade OOD performance, yet principled solutions to this issue are lacking. In
this work, we demonstrate that directly combining existing label noise-robust
methods with OOD detection strategies is insufficient to address this critical
challenge. To overcome this, we propose a robust OOD detection framework that
integrates loss correction techniques from the noisy label learning literature
with low-rank and sparse decomposition methods from signal processing.
Extensive experiments on both synthetic and real-world datasets demonstrate
that our method significantly outperforms the state-of-the-art OOD detection
techniques, particularly under severe noisy label settings.

</details>


### [266] [Staying in the Sweet Spot: Responsive Reasoning Evolution via Capability-Adaptive Hint Scaffolding](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06923)
*Ziheng Li,Zexu Sun,Jinman Zhao,Erxue Min,Yongcheng Zeng,Hui Wu,Hengyi Cai,Shuaiqiang Wang,Dawei Yin,Xu Chen,Zhi-Hong Deng*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: SEELE adaptively tunes problem difficulty in RLVR by appending adaptive hints and using multi-round rollout sampling with an item response theory model to predict hint lengths, improving exploration efficiency and achieving strong gains across six math benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address exploration inefficiency in RLVR caused by mismatch between training data difficulty and LLM capability; enabling consistent progress by keeping problems within the model's high-efficiency region.

Method: Append hints to problems and adapt hint length per instance using multi-round rollout sampling. In each round, collect accuracy-hint data, fit an item response theory model to predict the next-round required hint length, and adjust difficulty for subsequent rounds.

Result: SEELE outperforms Group Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO) and Supervised Fine-tuning (SFT) by +11.8 and +10.5 points, and surpasses the best previous supervision-aided approach by +3.6 points on average across six math reasoning benchmarks.

Conclusion: Instance-level, real-time difficulty adjustment via adaptive hints and IRT-based planning improves exploration efficiency and overall performance in RLVR for math reasoning tasks.

Abstract: Reinforcement learning with verifiable rewards (RLVR) has achieved remarkable
success in enhancing the reasoning capabilities of large language models
(LLMs). However, existing RLVR methods often suffer from exploration
inefficiency due to mismatches between the training data's difficulty and the
model's capability. LLMs fail to discover viable reasoning paths when problems
are overly difficult, while learning little new capability when problems are
too simple. In this work, we formalize the impact of problem difficulty by
quantifying the relationship between loss descent speed and rollout accuracy.
Building on this analysis, we propose SEELE, a novel supervision-aided RLVR
framework that dynamically adjusts problem difficulty to stay within the
high-efficiency region. SEELE augments each training sample by appending a hint
(part of a full solution) after the original problem. Unlike previous
hint-based approaches, SEELE deliberately and adaptively adjusts the hint
length for each problem to achieve an optimal difficulty. To determine the
optimal hint length, SEELE employs a multi-round rollout sampling strategy. In
each round, it fits an item response theory model to the accuracy-hint pairs
collected in preceding rounds to predict the required hint length for the next
round. This instance-level, real-time difficulty adjustment aligns problem
difficulty with the evolving model capability, thereby improving exploration
efficiency. Experimental results show that SEELE outperforms Group Relative
Policy Optimization (GRPO) and Supervised Fine-tuning (SFT) by +11.8 and +10.5
points, respectively, and surpasses the best previous supervision-aided
approach by +3.6 points on average across six math reasoning benchmarks.

</details>


### [267] [Neutron Reflectometry by Gradient Descent](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06924)
*Max D. ~Champneys,Andrew J. ~Parnell,Philipp Gutfreund,Maximilian W. A. Skoda,. Patrick A. Fairclough,Timothy J. ~Rogers,Stephanie L. ~Burg*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Optimizes neutron reflectometry analysis by differentiating the forward model instead of relying on black-box surrogates, enabling efficient gradient-based inference and tool-assisted fitting.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Neutron reflectometry data are indirect measurements; inverse modeling is computationally expensive, especially for complex multilayer structures. Surrogate ML often sacrifices physical intuition. A gradient-based approach on the forward model preserves physics while enabling modern optimization.

Method: Compute exact gradients of the error with respect to model parameters using automatic differentiation on the forward reflectivity model; perform gradient descent on these parameters. Develop differentiable reflectometry kernels in Python and apply to two benchmarks (thick oxide quartz film and organic LED multilayer devices).

Result: Achieves state-of-the-art performance on the thick oxide quartz film and robust co-fitting performance in the high-complexity organic LED multilayer regime; provides an open-source Python library of differentiable reflectometry kernels for easy adoption.

Conclusion: Gradient-based optimisation on a differentiable forward model preserves physical insight while enabling efficient, modern inference for NR data; the approach is broadly applicable to NR datasets and facilitates wider adoption of gradient-based methods.

Abstract: Neutron reflectometry (NR) is a powerful technique to probe surfaces and
interfaces. NR is inherently an indirect measurement technique, access to the
physical quantities of interest (layer thickness, scattering length density,
roughness), necessitate the solution of an inverse modelling problem, that is
inefficient for large amounts of data or complex multiplayer structures (e.g.
lithium batteries / electrodes). Recently, surrogate machine learning models
have been proposed as an alternative to existing optimisation routines.
Although such approaches have been successful, physical intuition is lost when
replacing governing equations with fast neural networks. Instead, we propose a
novel and efficient approach; to optimise reflectivity data analysis by
performing gradient descent on the forward reflection model itself. Herein,
automatic differentiation techniques are used to evaluate exact gradients of
the error function with respect to the parameters of interest. Access to these
quantities enables users of neutron reflectometry to harness a host of powerful
modern optimisation and inference techniques that remain thus far unexploited
in the context of neutron reflectometry. This paper presents two benchmark case
studies; demonstrating state-of-the-art performance on a thick oxide quartz
film, and robust co-fitting performance in the high complexity regime of
organic LED multilayer devices. Additionally, we provide an open-source library
of differentiable reflectometry kernels in the python programming language so
that gradient based approaches can readily be applied to other NR datasets.

</details>


### [268] [Learning words in groups: fusion algebras, tensor ranks and grokking](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06931)
*Maor Shutman,Oren Louidor,Ran Tessler*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: A simple two-layer network can learn arbitrary word operations over finite groups when width is sufficient, exhibiting grokking; the task is reframed as learning a low-rank 3-tensor. Low-rank structure arises by decomposing along triplets of self-conjugate group representations and using fusion rules to prune components. A surrogate model shows the network can discover such low-rank implementations, effectively performing Strassen-like efficient matrix multiplication for the multiplication word. The work also analyzes gradient descent dynamics that lead to these solutions.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand how neural networks acquire algebraic computation abilities for group-based word operations, including the role of network width, training dynamics (grokking), and representations-theoretic structure; to connect practical learning phenomena with low-rank tensor decompositions and efficient-multiplication concepts (Strassen).

Method: Reframe the problem as learning a 3-tensor representing a word-operation in a finite group. Argue the tensor is typically low-rank and can be obtained by decomposing along triplets of basic self-conjugate representations, aided by fusion rules that discard many components. Use a surrogate, tractable model to show the network can discover such low-rank implementations or good approximations, enabling width-limited generalization. For the simple multiplication word, analyze the form of the low-rank implementation and show it corresponds to Strassen-like matrix multiplication. Additionally, study how gradient descent facilitates reaching these solutions.

Result: Demonstrates that wide but not necessarily fat networks can learn arbitrary word-operations in finite groups via low-rank 3-tensor representations. The network discovers decompositions along triplets of self-conjugate representations and leverages fusion rules to prune components, effectively performing a Strassen-like matrix multiplication for the multiplication word. The surrogate model confirms the network can find such low-rank implementations and highlights the gradient-descent dynamics that lead to these solutions.

Conclusion: Low-dimensional tensor structure underpins the network’s ability to learn algebraic word-operations, with width enabling a low-rank, generalizable implementation. The work elucidates how representation-theoretic decompositions and gradient-based optimization enable grokking to yield efficient, structured solutions (e.g., Strassen-like multiplication), offering a lens to interpret learning dynamics for group-based computations.

Abstract: In this work, we demonstrate that a simple two-layer neural network with
standard activation functions can learn an arbitrary word operation in any
finite group, provided sufficient width is available and exhibits grokking
while doing so. To explain the mechanism by which this is achieved, we reframe
the problem as that of learning a particular $3$-tensor, which we show is
typically of low rank. A key insight is that low-rank implementations of this
tensor can be obtained by decomposing it along triplets of basic self-conjugate
representations of the group and leveraging the fusion structure to rule out
many components. Focusing on a phenomenologically similar but more tractable
surrogate model, we show that the network is able to find such low-rank
implementations (or approximations thereof), thereby using limited width to
approximate the word-tensor in a generalizable way. In the case of the simple
multiplication word, we further elucidate the form of these low-rank
implementations, showing that the network effectively implements efficient
matrix multiplication in the sense of Strassen. Our work also sheds light on
the mechanism by which a network reaches such a solution under gradient
descent.

</details>


### [269] [From Noise to Narrative: Tracing the Origins of Hallucinations in Transformers](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06938)
*Praneet Suresh,Jack Stanley,Sonia Joseph,Luca Scimeca,Danilo Bzdok*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Transformers' hallucinations are tied to activations of semantic concepts captured by sparse autoencoders; as input becomes more unstructured, more concepts are used and hallucinations emerge from input-insensitive features; even pure noise reveals robust concepts; hallucinations can be predicted from activation patterns and steered, with implications for alignment, safety, attack surface, and risk quantification.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To understand when and why transformer models hallucinate, especially under uncertain or unstructured inputs, and to link internal concept representations to failure modes for safety and risk assessment.

Method: Apply sparse autoencoders to pre-trained transformer activations to extract concept representations; systematically vary input uncertainty; analyze how the number and nature of activated concepts change; examine whether hallucinations can be steered and whether they can be predicted from activation patterns.

Result: Increasing input unstructuredness leads to more semantic concepts being used; under uncertainty, transformers activate coherent but input-insensitive concepts, causing hallucinations; with pure-noise inputs a wide set of robust concepts activate; these concepts can be steered and are predictive of hallucinations.

Conclusion: The study illuminates transformer internal processing, with practical implications for AI alignment, safety, vulnerability to adversarial manipulation, and the ability to automatically quantify a model's hallucination risk.

Abstract: As generative AI systems become competent and democratized in science,
business, and government, deeper insight into their failure modes now poses an
acute need. The occasional volatility in their behavior, such as the propensity
of transformer models to hallucinate, impedes trust and adoption of emerging AI
solutions in high-stakes areas. In the present work, we establish how and when
hallucinations arise in pre-trained transformer models through concept
representations captured by sparse autoencoders, under scenarios with
experimentally controlled uncertainty in the input space. Our systematic
experiments reveal that the number of semantic concepts used by the transformer
model grows as the input information becomes increasingly unstructured. In the
face of growing uncertainty in the input space, the transformer model becomes
prone to activate coherent yet input-insensitive semantic features, leading to
hallucinated output. At its extreme, for pure-noise inputs, we identify a wide
variety of robustly triggered and meaningful concepts in the intermediate
activations of pre-trained transformer models, whose functional integrity we
confirm through targeted steering. We also show that hallucinations in the
output of a transformer model can be reliably predicted from the concept
patterns embedded in transformer layer activations. This collection of insights
on transformer internal processing mechanics has immediate consequences for
aligning AI models with human values, AI safety, opening the attack surface for
potential adversarial attacks, and providing a basis for automatic
quantification of a model's hallucination risk.

</details>


### [270] [Outcome-based Exploration for LLM Reasoning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06941)
*Yuda Song,Julia Kempe,Remi Munos*

Main category: cs.LG

TL;DR: Outcome-based RL improves final-answer accuracy but reduces generation diversity; proposes outcome-based exploration (historical and batch) to recover diversity while preserving performance, supported by theory and math-task experiments.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: RL post-training can enhance reasoning in LLMs, but outcome-only rewards raise accuracy at the cost of diversity, which harms test-time scalability and real-world performance. Understanding and mitigating this diversity collapse is essential.

Method: Model the RL post-training as a sampling process and analyze diversity dynamics.
