The approach is 6-DoF vision-based and evaluated on real and simulated clutter datasets (FetchBench).

Result: Grasp-MPC increases grasp success rates by up to 32.6% in simulation and 33.3% in noisy real-world conditions, outperforming open-loop, diffusion policy, transformer policy, and IQL baselines.

Conclusion: A robust, reactive, generalizable closed-loop grasping policy for novel objects in clutter is achievable using a learned value function within an MPC formulation, showing substantial improvements over several baseline policies.

Abstract: Grasping of diverse objects in unstructured environments remains a
significant challenge. Open-loop grasping methods, effective in controlled
settings, struggle in cluttered environments. Grasp prediction errors and
object pose changes during grasping are the main causes of failure. In
contrast, closed-loop methods address these challenges in simplified settings
(e.g., single object on a table) on a limited set of objects, with no path to
generalization. We propose Grasp-MPC, a closed-loop 6-DoF vision-based grasping
policy designed for robust and reactive grasping of novel objects in cluttered
environments. Grasp-MPC incorporates a value function, trained on visual
observations from a large-scale synthetic dataset of 2 million grasp
trajectories that include successful and failed attempts. We deploy this
learned value function in an MPC framework in combination with other cost terms
that encourage collision avoidance and smooth execution. We evaluate Grasp-MPC
on FetchBench and real-world settings across diverse environments. Grasp-MPC
improves grasp success rates by up to 32.6% in simulation and 33.3% in
real-world noisy conditions, outperforming open-loop, diffusion policy,
transformer policy, and IQL approaches. Videos and more at
http://grasp-mpc.github.io.

</details>


### [298] [O$^3$Afford: One-Shot 3D Object-to-Object Affordance Grounding for Generalizable Robotic Manipulation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06233)
*Tongxuan Tian,Xuhui Kang,Yen-Ling Kuo*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A one-shot 3D object-to-object affordance grounding framework (O3Afford) that fuses vision foundation-model features with 3D geometry and LLM reasoning to generalize to novel object pairs in robotic manipulation, outperforming baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Grounding affordances between object pairs is essential for manipulation but is underexplored, especially under limited data. Real-world interactions involve relationships between objects, requiring generalization to novel objects and integration of perception with reasoning.

Method: Propose a one-shot 3D object-to-object affordance learning approach (O3Afford). It leverages semantic features from vision foundation models and 3D point cloud geometry to learn robust affordance representations from limited data. The approach further integrates this 3D affordance representation with large language models to reason about object interactions and generate task-specific constraint functions for manipulation.

Result: Experiments on 3D object-to-object grounding and robotic manipulation show that O3Afford significantly outperforms existing baselines in accuracy and generalization to novel objects and categories.

Conclusion: The proposed framework bridges perception and action for object-to-object affordance grounding in 3D, enables effective learning from limited data, and enhances robotic manipulation through LLM-based reasoning about object interactions.

Abstract: Grounding object affordance is fundamental to robotic manipulation as it
establishes the critical link between perception and action among interacting
objects. However, prior works predominantly focus on predicting single-object
affordance, overlooking the fact that most real-world interactions involve
relationships between pairs of objects. In this work, we address the challenge
of object-to-object affordance grounding under limited data contraints.
Inspired by recent advances in few-shot learning with 2D vision foundation
models, we propose a novel one-shot 3D object-to-object affordance learning
approach for robotic manipulation. Semantic features from vision foundation
models combined with point cloud representation for geometric understanding
enable our one-shot learning pipeline to generalize effectively to novel
objects and categories. We further integrate our 3D affordance representation
with large language models (LLMs) for robotics manipulation, significantly
enhancing LLMs' capability to comprehend and reason about object interactions
when generating task-specific constraint functions. Our experiments on 3D
object-to-object affordance grounding and robotic manipulation demonstrate that
our O$^3$Afford significantly outperforms existing baselines in terms of both
accuracy and generalization capability.

</details>


### [299] [DCReg: Decoupled Characterization for Efficient Degenerate LiDAR Registration](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06285)
*Xiangcheng Hu,Xieyuanli Chen,Mingkai Jia,Jin Wu,Ping Tan,Steven L. Waslander*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: DCReg presents a principled ill-conditioning-aware LiDAR registration framework that decouples rotation/translations via Schur complement, maps eigenspaces to physical motions, and uses a targeted preconditioner to stabilize ill-conditioned directions, achieving significant accuracy and speedups with PCG.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Registration in degenerate/narrow environments is ill-conditioned, leading to unstable solutions; current methods inadequately detect and mitigate degeneracy.

Method: 1) Schur decomposition of Hessian to separate rotational and translational subspaces; 2) quantitative mapping from eigenspaces to motion directions; 3) a selective preconditioner stabilizing only ill-conditioned directions within observable space, enabling fast Preconditioned Conjugate Gradient with a single interpretable parameter.

Result: Experiments show 20-50% localization accuracy improvement and 5-100x speedups over SOTA across diverse environments; code to be released.

Conclusion: DCReg provides a principled pipeline for detecting and mitigating ill-conditioning in LiDAR registration, improving robustness and efficiency by operating in decoupled subspaces and applying targeted preconditioning.

Abstract: LiDAR point cloud registration is fundamental to robotic perception and
navigation. However, in geometrically degenerate or narrow environments,
registration problems become ill-conditioned, leading to unstable solutions and
degraded accuracy. While existing approaches attempt to handle these issues,
they fail to address the core challenge: accurately detection, interpret, and
resolve this ill-conditioning, leading to missed detections or corrupted
solutions. In this study, we introduce DCReg, a principled framework that
systematically addresses the ill-conditioned registration problems through
three integrated innovations. First, DCReg achieves reliable ill-conditioning
detection by employing a Schur complement decomposition to the hessian matrix.
This technique decouples the registration problem into clean rotational and
translational subspaces, eliminating coupling effects that mask degeneracy
patterns in conventional analyses. Second, within these cleanly subspaces, we
develop quantitative characterization techniques that establish explicit
mappings between mathematical eigenspaces and physical motion directions,
providing actionable insights about which specific motions lack constraints.
Finally, leveraging this clean subspace, we design a targeted mitigation
strategy: a novel preconditioner that selectively stabilizes only the
identified ill-conditioned directions while preserving all well-constrained
information in observable space. This enables efficient and robust optimization
via the Preconditioned Conjugate Gradient method with a single physical
interpretable parameter. Extensive experiments demonstrate DCReg achieves at
least 20% - 50% improvement in localization accuracy and 5-100 times speedup
over state-of-the-art methods across diverse environments. Our implementation
will be available at https://github.com/JokerJohn/DCReg.

</details>


### [300] [Learning to Walk with Less: a Dyna-Style Approach to Quadrupedal Locomotion](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06296)
*Francisco Affonso,Felipe Andrade G. Tommaselli,Juliano Negri,Vivian S. Medeiros,Mateus V. Gasparino,Girish Chowdhary,Marcelo Becker*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A model-based RL approach adds short-horizon synthetic data (Dyna-style) to PPO rollouts to boost sample efficiency in quadrupedal locomotion; a predictive model is trained alongside the policy to generate synthetic transitions, with a scheduling strategy that gradually integrates them based on policy updates. Ablation reveals rollout length strongly affects efficiency. In simulation (Unitree Go1), replacing part of simulated steps with synthetic data improves returns, reduces variance, and enhances the ability to track diverse locomotion commands with fewer simulated steps.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Traditional RL-based locomotion controllers are data-inefficient, requiring extensive interaction to achieve robust performance. The study aims to improve sample efficiency for quadrupedal locomotion.

Method: Train a predictive model in parallel with the policy to generate short-horizon synthetic transitions. Append synthetic data to the end of standard rollouts in PPO-based controllers, following a Dyna-style paradigm. Use a scheduling strategy based on policy update iterations to integrate synthetic data. Conduct an ablation study to examine the impact of rollout length. Validate in simulation on the Unitree Go1 robot, showing that partial replacement of simulated steps with synthetic ones mimics longer rollouts and improves policy return and reduces variance. Demonstrate transfer to tracking a wide range of locomotion commands with fewer simulated steps.

Result: Synthetic data augmentation improves policy performance and stability: higher returns, lower variance, and better adaptability to diverse commands using fewer simulated steps. The synthetic data effectively extends effective rollouts.

Conclusion: MDLR with Dyna-style synthetic data enhances sample efficiency and robustness for quadrupedal locomotion and transfers to varying locomotion commands; scheduling of synthetic data based on update iterations is key to performance gains.

Abstract: Traditional RL-based locomotion controllers often suffer from low data
efficiency, requiring extensive interaction to achieve robust performance. We
present a model-based reinforcement learning (MBRL) framework that improves
sample efficiency for quadrupedal locomotion by appending synthetic data to the
end of standard rollouts in PPO-based controllers, following the Dyna-Style
paradigm. A predictive model, trained alongside the policy, generates
short-horizon synthetic transitions that are gradually integrated using a
scheduling strategy based on the policy update iterations. Through an ablation
study, we identified a strong correlation between sample efficiency and rollout
length, which guided the design of our experiments. We validated our approach
in simulation on the Unitree Go1 robot and showed that replacing part of the
simulated steps with synthetic ones not only mimics extended rollouts but also
improves policy return and reduces variance. Finally, we demonstrate that this
improvement transfers to the ability to track a wide range of locomotion
commands using fewer simulated steps.

</details>


### [301] [Towards bridging the gap: Systematic sim-to-real transfer for diverse legged robots](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06342)
*Filip Bjelonic,Fabian Tischhauser,Marco Hutter*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A sim-to-real RL framework for legged robots that uses a physics-grounded energy model for permanent-magnet synchronous motors, enabling transferable, energy-efficient policies with minimal parameter tuning and no dynamic-parameter randomization; reports 32% COD reduction on ANYmal and broad hardware validation; code, models, and datasets forthcoming.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Legged robots require both robust locomotion and energy efficiency in real-world environments. Sim-to-real transfer is difficult, and many methods rely on hand-tuned rewards or neglect actuator-specific energy losses, limiting efficiency and transfer reliability.

Method: Integrates sim-to-real reinforcement learning with a first-principles energy model for PM motors. Uses a compact parameter set to capture the sim-to-real gap and a four-term reward designed around a principled energetic loss formulation that balances electrical and mechanical dissipation. Validation includes a bottom-up dynamic parameter identification study and experiments across actuators, full-robot in-air trajectories, and on-ground locomotion. Demonstrated on three primary platforms and deployed on ten additional robots withoutrandomizing dynamic parameters.

Result: Achieves reliable policy transfer and improved energetic efficiency, including a 32% reduction in full Cost of Transport on ANYmal (CoT = 1.27). Demonstrations spanned actuator-scale dynamics to real-world locomotion.

Conclusion: The framework provides transferable, energy-aware policies for legged robots with a lightweight, physics-based energy model and minimal parameter complexity. It shows strong generalization across platforms and handles actuator losses more faithfully than prior approaches; the authors plan to release code, models, and datasets.

Abstract: Legged robots must achieve both robust locomotion and energy efficiency to be
practical in real-world environments. Yet controllers trained in simulation
often fail to transfer reliably, and most existing approaches neglect
actuator-specific energy losses or depend on complex, hand-tuned reward
formulations. We propose a framework that integrates sim-to-real reinforcement
learning with a physics-grounded energy model for permanent magnet synchronous
motors. The framework requires a minimal parameter set to capture the
simulation-to-reality gap and employs a compact four-term reward with a
first-principle-based energetic loss formulation that balances electrical and
mechanical dissipation. We evaluate and validate the approach through a
bottom-up dynamic parameter identification study, spanning actuators,
full-robot in-air trajectories and on-ground locomotion. The framework is
tested on three primary platforms and deployed on ten additional robots,
demonstrating reliable policy transfer without randomization of dynamic
parameters. Our method improves energetic efficiency over state-of-the-art
methods, achieving a 32 percent reduction in the full Cost of Transport of
ANYmal (value 1.27). All code, models, and datasets will be released.

</details>


### [302] [Adaptive Evolution Factor Risk Ellipse Framework for Reliable and Safe Autonomous Driving](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06375)
*Fujiang Yuan,Zhen Tian,Yangfan He,Guojian Zou,Chunhong Yuan,Yanhong Peng,Zhihao Lin*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: ERPF-MPC dynamically updates risk assessments via Evolution Factor and Risk-Ellipse to create an adaptive, collision-avoiding control for autonomous driving; outperforms static risk fields and traditional methods in experiments.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current methods either conservative or data-hungry; need adaptive, interpretable, and efficient risk models for interactive driving.

Method: Introduce Risk-Ellipse that fuses longitudinal reach and lateral uncertainty; Evolution Factor via sigmoid of TTC and TWH; integrate into MPC; dynamic adaptation in real-time.

Result: ERPF-MPC yields smoother trajectories, higher average speeds, collision-free navigation in complex interactive scenarios; robust performance across conditions.

Conclusion: ERPF-MPC is a robust, adaptive framework for safe and efficient autonomous driving in uncertain, interactive environments, balancing safety with performance.

Abstract: In recent years, ensuring safety, efficiency, and comfort in interactive
autonomous driving has become a critical challenge. Traditional model-based
techniques, such as game-theoretic methods and robust control, are often overly
conservative or computationally intensive. Conversely, learning-based
approaches typically require extensive training data and frequently exhibit
limited interpretability and generalizability. Simpler strategies, such as Risk
Potential Fields (RPF), provide lightweight alternatives with minimal data
demands but are inherently static and struggle to adapt effectively to dynamic
traffic conditions. To overcome these limitations, we propose the Evolutionary
Risk Potential Field (ERPF), a novel approach that dynamically updates risk
assessments in dynamical scenarios based on historical obstacle proximity data.
We introduce a Risk-Ellipse construct that combines longitudinal reach and
lateral uncertainty into a unified spatial temporal collision envelope.
Additionally, we define an adaptive Evolution Factor metric, computed through
sigmoid normalization of Time to Collision (TTC) and Time-Window-of-Hazard
(TWH), which dynamically adjusts the dimensions of the ellipse axes in real
time. This adaptive risk metric is integrated seamlessly into a Model
Predictive Control (MPC) framework, enabling autonomous vehicles to proactively
address complex interactive driving scenarios in terms of uncertain driving of
surrounding vehicles. Comprehensive comparative experiments demonstrate that
our ERPF-MPC approach consistently achieves smoother trajectories, higher
average speeds, and collision-free navigation, offering a robust and adaptive
solution suitable for complex interactive driving environments.

</details>


### [303] [Safety Meets Speed: Accelerated Neural MPC with Safety Guarantees and No Retraining](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06404)
*Kaikai Wang,Tianxun Li,Liang Xu,Qinglei Hu,Keyou You*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: BAN-MPC enables fast, safe embedded MPC by integrating barrier-based collision avoidance and a neural value function with parameter-sensitivity adaptation. It achieves ~200x speed-up and robust collision-free navigation on Jetson Nano.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: MPC guarantees safety via constraints but is often too slow for real-time embedded platforms. There is a need for an approach that preserves MPC safety while significantly reducing online computation and adapting to parameter changes without retraining.

Method: Replace Euclidean distance with Control Barrier Functions for collision avoidance; integrate an offline-learned neural value function into the short-horizon MPC objective; train a second neural network to learn the value function's sensitivity to system parameters and adapt online when parameters change without retraining.

Result: Hardware-in-the-loop experiments on Jetson Nano show BAN-MPC solving ~200x faster than traditional MPC, enabling collision-free navigation with control error below 5% under model parameter variations up to 15%.

Conclusion: BAN-MPC is an effective embedded MPC alternative that combines neural speed with MPC safety guarantees, reduces offline computation, and robustly adapts to parameter changes without retraining.

Abstract: While Model Predictive Control (MPC) enforces safety via constraints, its
real-time execution can exceed embedded compute budgets. We propose a
Barrier-integrated Adaptive Neural Model Predictive Control (BAN-MPC) framework
that synergizes neural networks' fast computation with MPC's
constraint-handling capability. To ensure strict safety, we replace traditional
Euclidean distance with Control Barrier Functions (CBFs) for collision
avoidance. We integrate an offline-learned neural value function into the
optimization objective of a Short-horizon MPC, substantially reducing online
computational complexity. Additionally, we use a second neural network to learn
the sensitivity of the value function to system parameters, and adaptively
adjust the neural value function based on this neural sensitivity when model
parameters change, eliminating the need for retraining and reducing offline
computation costs. The hardware in-the-loop (HIL) experiments on Jetson Nano
show that BAN-MPC solves 200 times faster than traditional MPC, enabling
collision-free navigation with control error below 5\% under model parameter
variations within 15\%, making it an effective embedded MPC alternative.

</details>


### [304] [Real-time Photorealistic Mapping for Situational Awareness in Robot Teleoperation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06433)
*Ian Page,Pierre Susbielle,Olivier Aycard,Pierre-Brice Wieber*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: GPU-accelerated Gaussian splatting SLAM integrated with online map-based teleoperation yields photorealistic, real-time 3D maps that boost decision speed and teleoperation efficiency in unknown environments.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Unknown environments hinder teleoperator situational understanding; real-time, accurate 3D mapping is computationally expensive, limiting performance.

Method: Develop modular GPU-based integration combining Gaussian splatting SLAM advances with existing online map-based teleoperation systems; validate via real-world aerial-vehicle experiments and comparisons to state-of-the-art.

Result: Significant improvements in decision-making speed and more accurate interaction with the environment; higher teleoperation efficiency; photorealistic mapping generated in real-time.

Conclusion: The integration enhances remote teleoperation in unfamiliar environments by blending high-fidelity mapping with real-time capability, enabling more effective exploration and control.

Abstract: Achieving efficient remote teleoperation is particularly challenging in
unknown environments, as the teleoperator must rapidly build an understanding
of the site's layout. Online 3D mapping is a proven strategy to tackle this
challenge, as it enables the teleoperator to progressively explore the site
from multiple perspectives. However, traditional online map-based teleoperation
systems struggle to generate visually accurate 3D maps in real-time due to the
high computational cost involved, leading to poor teleoperation performances.
In this work, we propose a solution to improve teleoperation efficiency in
unknown environments. Our approach proposes a novel, modular and efficient
GPU-based integration between recent advancement in gaussian splatting SLAM and
existing online map-based teleoperation systems. We compare the proposed
solution against state-of-the-art teleoperation systems and validate its
performances through real-world experiments using an aerial vehicle. The
results show significant improvements in decision-making speed and more
accurate interaction with the environment, leading to greater teleoperation
efficiency. In doing so, our system enhances remote teleoperation by seamlessly
integrating photorealistic mapping generation with real-time performances,
enabling effective teleoperation in unfamiliar environments.

</details>


### [305] [Interactive Shaping of Granular Media Using Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06469)
*Benedikt Kreis,Malte Mosbach,Anny Ripke,Muhammad Ehsan Ullah,Sven Behnke,Maren Bennewitz*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: RL with a cubic-end-effector camera setup shapes granular media into target structures using compact observations and concise rewards; demonstrates effective visual policy training and real-world deployment, outperforming two baselines.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Shaping granular media is challenging due to high-dimensional configuration space and complex dynamics; classical rule-based methods require heavy engineering. RL offers adaptive manipulation strategies learned from interaction.

Method: Develop an RL framework where a robotic arm with a cubic end-effector and a stereo camera learns to shape granular media into target structures. Emphasize compact observations and concise reward formulations. Include ablation studies to validate design choices. Train visual policies and test both in simulation and real-world deployment, comparing against two baseline approaches.

Result: The proposed framework effectively trains visual policies for manipulating granular media and achieves successful real-world deployment, outperforming two baseline methods.

Conclusion: Compact observation and reward design are key to enabling RL in high-dimensional granular manipulation tasks; the approach demonstrates practical viability and potential for broader applications, though further work is needed on generalization and sample efficiency.

Abstract: Autonomous manipulation of granular media, such as sand, is crucial for
applications in construction, excavation, and additive manufacturing. However,
shaping granular materials presents unique challenges due to their
high-dimensional configuration space and complex dynamics, where traditional
rule-based approaches struggle without extensive engineering efforts.
Reinforcement learning (RL) offers a promising alternative by enabling agents
to learn adaptive manipulation strategies through trial and error. In this
work, we present an RL framework that enables a robotic arm with a cubic
end-effector and a stereo camera to shape granular media into desired target
structures. We show the importance of compact observations and concise reward
formulations for the large configuration space, validating our design choices
with an ablation study. Our results demonstrate the effectiveness of the
proposed approach for the training of visual policies that manipulate granular
media including their real-world deployment, outperforming two baseline
approaches.

</details>


### [306] [Event Driven CBBA with Reduced Communication](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06481)
*Vinita Sao,Tu Dac Ho,Sujoy Bhore,P. B. Sujit*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Proposes ED-CBBA, an event-driven communication extension to the CBBA framework for multi-robot task allocation, achieving up to 52% fewer messages while preserving convergence and solution quality.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: CBBA's performance hinges on continuous communication, which can cause congestion and packet loss in limited-range, multi-robot networks. The work aims to reduce communications without sacrificing task allocation guarantees.

Method: Introduce an event-driven communication mechanism within CBBA (ED-CBBA), prove theoretically that the solution quality remains on par with CBBA and validate via Monte-Carlo simulations across various numbers of targets, agents, and bundles.

Result: The ED-CBBA protocol reduces message transmissions by up to 52% while maintaining convergence guarantees and comparable solution quality to CBBA across tested scenarios.

Conclusion: Event-driven communication in CBBA can substantially cut communications without sacrificing performance, making decentralized multi-robot task allocation more robust to communication constraints.

Abstract: In various scenarios such as multi-drone surveillance and search-and-rescue
operations, deploying multiple robots is essential to accomplish multiple tasks
at once. Due to the limited communication range of these vehicles, a
decentralised task allocation algorithm is crucial for effective task
distribution among robots. The consensus-based bundle algorithm (CBBA) has been
promising for multi-robot operation, offering theoretical guarantees. However,
CBBA demands continuous communication, leading to potential congestion and
packet loss that can hinder performance. In this study, we introduce an
event-driven communication mechanism designed to address these communication
challenges while maintaining the convergence and performance bounds of CBBA. We
demonstrate theoretically that the solution quality matches that of CBBA and
validate the approach with Monte-Carlo simulations across varying targets,
agents, and bundles. Results indicate that the proposed algorithm (ED-CBBA) can
reduce message transmissions by up to 52%.

</details>


### [307] [Co-Located VR with Hybrid SLAM-based HMD Tracking and Motion Capture Synchronization](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06582)
*Carlos A. Pinheiro de Sousa,Niklas Gröne,Mathias Günther,Oliver Deussen*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A hybrid VR co-location framework blending motion capture with inside-out SLAM to maintain real-time, drift-corrected spatial alignment across multiple users, with real-time pose sharing and improved robustness over prior methods.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Co-located multi-user VR requires accurate, low-latency spatial alignment across devices. External tracking can add latency/jitter; one-time calibration can't handle drift. A scalable solution that combines responsiveness of local SLAM with external realignment.

Method: Integrates motion capture with SLAM-based inside-out tracking; real-time pose sharing across devices; supports external realignments when needed; aims for high framerate, low latency; evaluates spatial accuracy and comfort.

Result: Demonstrates sufficient spatial accuracy for natural multi-user interaction; improved comfort, scalability, and robustness over existing co-located VR solutions; real-time pose sharing maintains alignment across devices; better drift handling than one-time calibration.

Conclusion: The framework offers an effective balance between responsiveness and drift correction for multi-user co-located VR, enabling robust, scalable, and comfortable shared virtual experiences.

Abstract: We introduce a multi-user VR co-location framework that synchronizes users
within a shared virtual environment aligned to physical space. Our approach
combines a motion capture system with SLAM-based inside-out tracking to deliver
smooth, high-framerate, low-latency performance. Previous methods either rely
on continuous external tracking, which introduces latency and jitter, or on
one-time calibration, which cannot correct drift over time. In contrast, our
approach combines the responsiveness of local HMD SLAM tracking with the
flexibility to realign to an external source when needed. It also supports
real-time pose sharing across devices, ensuring consistent spatial alignment
and engagement between users. Our evaluation demonstrates that our framework
achieves the spatial accuracy required for natural multi-user interaction while
offering improved comfort, scalability, and robustness over existing co-located
VR solutions.

</details>


### [308] [A Robust Approach for LiDAR-Inertial Odometry Without Sensor-Specific Modeling](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06593)
*Meher V. R. Malladi,Tiziano Guadagnino,Luca Lobefaro,Cyrill Stachniss*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Sensor-agnostic LiDAR–IMU odometry using direct scan-to-map registration with a regularized LiDAR registration and a simplified IMU model; robust across diverse sensors and platforms and released as open-source.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Accurate odometry is essential for navigation; existing sensor fusion methods rely on sensor-specific models or feature extraction and may not generalize across domains (urban LiDARs to handheld packages). A robust, sensor-agnostic approach enables deployment in varied environments without per-sensor tuning.

Method: Direct LiDAR scan-to-map registration with a simplified IMU integration model, avoiding sensor-specific LiDAR modeling and Kalman/filter-based fusion. Introduces a novel regularization term on LiDAR registration to improve robustness. Validates across multiple datasets using the same configuration, and open-sources the implementation.

Result: Demonstrates robustness and cross-domain applicability: the system works with the same configuration across different sensor types and platforms, achieving improved or competitive odometry performance without sensor-specific tuning.

Conclusion: A robust, sensor-agnostic LiDAR–IMU odometry framework that relies on scan-to-map registration with regularization and a simplified IMU model, showing strong generalization across domains and ready for integration into navigation stacks; released as open source.

Abstract: Accurate odometry is a critical component in a robotic navigation stack, and
subsequent modules such as planning and control often rely on an estimate of
the robot's motion. Sensor-based odometry approaches should be robust across
sensor types and deployable in different target domains, from solid-state
LiDARs mounted on cars in urban-driving scenarios to spinning LiDARs on
handheld packages used in unstructured natural environments. In this paper, we
propose a robust LiDAR-inertial odometry system that does not rely on
sensor-specific modeling. Sensor fusion techniques for LiDAR and inertial
measurement unit (IMU) data typically integrate IMU data iteratively in a
Kalman filter or use pre-integration in a factor graph framework, combined with
LiDAR scan matching often exploiting some form of feature extraction. We
propose an alternative strategy that only requires a simplified motion model
for IMU integration and directly registers LiDAR scans in a scan-to-map
approach. Our approach allows us to impose a novel regularization on the LiDAR
registration, improving the overall odometry performance. We detail extensive
experiments on a number of datasets covering a wide array of commonly used
robotic sensors and platforms. We show that our approach works with the exact
same configuration in all these scenarios, demonstrating its robustness. We
have open-sourced our implementation so that the community can build further on
our work and use it in their navigation stacks.

</details>


### [309] [LiHRA: A LiDAR-Based HRI Dataset for Automated Risk Monitoring Methods](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06597)
*Frederik Plahl,Georgios Katranis,Ilshat Mamaev,Andrey Morozov*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A multi-modal HRI safety dataset (LiHRA) with 3D LiDAR, human keypoints, and robot state for six scenarios, enabling learning-based and classical risk monitoring for human-robot collaboration; includes safe/hazardous variants and a baseline RM method.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address the lack of realistic, high-quality, multi-modal HRI datasets that capture potentially dangerous interactions, enabling development of real-time risk monitoring and adaptive safety in collaborative robots.

Method: Collected 4,431 labeled point clouds at 10 Hz across six HRI scenarios; captured 3D LiDAR, human pose keypoints, and robot joint states; provided safe and hazardous versions; demonstrated a risk-monitoring method using contextual info and robot dynamics.

Result: LiHRA delivers a comprehensive multi-modal dataset and a baseline RM method that quantifies risk over time; shows feasibility of training RM algorithms for HRI with real-time potential.

Conclusion: LiHRA provides foundational data and a demonstrator method to advance real-time RM and adaptive safety strategies in human-robot workspaces, supporting both AI-driven and classical approaches.

Abstract: We present LiHRA, a novel dataset designed to facilitate the development of
automated, learning-based, or classical risk monitoring (RM) methods for
Human-Robot Interaction (HRI) scenarios. The growing prevalence of
collaborative robots in industrial environments has increased the need for
reliable safety systems. However, the lack of high-quality datasets that
capture realistic human-robot interactions, including potentially dangerous
events, slows development. LiHRA addresses this challenge by providing a
comprehensive, multi-modal dataset combining 3D LiDAR point clouds, human body
keypoints, and robot joint states, capturing the complete spatial and dynamic
context of human-robot collaboration. This combination of modalities allows for
precise tracking of human movement, robot actions, and environmental
conditions, enabling accurate RM during collaborative tasks. The LiHRA dataset
covers six representative HRI scenarios involving collaborative and coexistent
tasks, object handovers, and surface polishing, with safe and hazardous
versions of each scenario. In total, the data set includes 4,431 labeled point
clouds recorded at 10 Hz, providing a rich resource for training and
benchmarking classical and AI-driven RM algorithms. Finally, to demonstrate
LiHRA's utility, we introduce an RM method that quantifies the risk level in
each scenario over time. This method leverages contextual information,
including robot states and the dynamic model of the robot. With its combination
of high-resolution LiDAR data, precise human tracking, robot state data, and
realistic collision events, LiHRA offers an essential foundation for future
research into real-time RM and adaptive safety strategies in human-robot
workspaces.

</details>


### [310] [T-araVLN: Translator for Agricultural Robotic Agents on Vision-and-Language Navigation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06644)
*Xiaobei Zhao,Xingqi Lyu,Xiang Li*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A Translator module (T-araVLN) refines natural language instructions to improve agricultural VLN navigation, achieving state-of-the-art results on A2A: SR 0.63 (from 0.47) and NE 2.28m (from 2.91m).


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Agricultural robotic agents rely on natural language navigation but struggle with complex instructions; bridging the gap with an instruction translator can enhance navigation accuracy and efficiency in the agricultural domain.

Method: Introduce T-araVLN with an Instruction Translator module that refines and clarifies original instructions before feeding them to a vision-and-language navigation model; evaluated on the A2A agricultural benchmark.

Result: SR improved from 0.47 to 0.63; NE reduced from 2.91m to 2.28m; achieves state-of-the-art performance for agricultural VLN; code available at provided GitHub link.

Conclusion: Instruction translation effectively enhances VLN performance in agriculture, suggesting that refining natural language before perception-action decision can generalize to domain-specific navigation tasks.

Abstract: Agricultural robotic agents have been becoming powerful helpers in a wide
range of agricultural tasks, nevertheless, still heavily rely on manual
operation or untransportable railway for movement. The AgriVLN method and the
A2A benchmark pioneeringly extend Vision-and-Language Navigation (VLN) to the
agricultural domain, enabling agents navigate to the target position following
the natural language instructions. AgriVLN effectively understands the simple
instructions, however, often misunderstands the complicated instructions. To
bridge this gap, we propose the method of Translator for Agricultural Robotic
Agents on Vision-and-Language Navigation (T-araVLN), in which the Instruction
Translator module translates the original instruction to be both refined and
precise. Being evaluated on the A2A benchmark, our T-araVLN effectively
improves SR from 0.47 to 0.63 and reduces NE from 2.91m to 2.28m, demonstrating
the state-of-the-art performance in the agricultural domain. Code:
https://github.com/AlexTraveling/T-araVLN.

</details>


### [311] [An Adaptive Coverage Control Approach for Multiple Autonomous Off-road Vehicles in Dynamic Agricultural Fields](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06682)
*Sajad Ahmadi,Mohammadreza Davoodi,Javad Mohammadpour Velni*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Adaptive coverage control for a fleet of off-road UGVs using UAV-assisted real-time path planning on a dynamic weighted directed graph with Voronoi partitioning; simulation shows improved path planning, lower traversal costs, and robust coverage amidst dynamic obstacles and muddy terrain.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Conventional coverage control assumes static conditions, which fail in real-world farming where moving machinery and uneven, muddy terrain create ongoing challenges. There is a need for real-time adaptability to maintain coverage.

Method: Proposes an adaptive coverage control framework where UAVs detect obstacles and assess terrain to update a dynamic weighted directed graph. The graph uses Voronoi-based partitioning, adaptive edge weights tied to UAV observations, and cost-based path optimization to guide UGV coverage paths.

Result: Simulation results demonstrate improved path planning, reduced traversal costs, and robust coverage in the presence of dynamic obstacles and muddy terrains.

Conclusion: The framework enables effective adaptive coverage for UGV fleets in dynamic agricultural environments by leveraging UAV-perception and graph-based planning to enhance navigation efficiency.

Abstract: This paper presents an adaptive coverage control method for a fleet of
off-road and Unmanned Ground Vehicles (UGVs) operating in dynamic
(time-varying) agricultural environments. Traditional coverage control
approaches often assume static conditions, making them unsuitable for
real-world farming scenarios where obstacles, such as moving machinery and
uneven terrains, create continuous challenges. To address this, we propose a
real-time path planning framework that integrates Unmanned Aerial Vehicles
(UAVs) for obstacle detection and terrain assessment, allowing UGVs to
dynamically adjust their coverage paths. The environment is modeled as a
weighted directed graph, where the edge weights are continuously updated based
on the UAV observations to reflect obstacle motion and terrain variations. The
proposed approach incorporates Voronoi-based partitioning, adaptive edge weight
assignment, and cost-based path optimization to enhance navigation efficiency.
Simulation results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed method in
improving path planning, reducing traversal costs, and maintaining robust
coverage in the presence of dynamic obstacles and muddy terrains.

</details>


### [312] [Safe Robust Predictive Control-based Motion Planning of Automated Surface Vessels in Inland Waterways](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06687)
*Sajad Ahmadi,Hossein Nejatbakhsh Esfahani,Javad Mohammadpour Velni*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: RMPC with CBFs for ASV navigation in confined inland waterways, integrating safety constraints to ensure collision-free, robust operation; simulations show improved safety vs. state-of-the-art.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Need for safe, reliable autonomous surface vessels in narrow, high-density waterways where hydrodynamic disturbances and confined boundaries challenge existing planners.

Method: Apply Robust Model Predictive Control with Control Barrier Functions encoding channel borders and obstacles as safety constraints to guarantee collision avoidance while maintaining robust performance.

Result: Simulation experiments demonstrate successful safe navigation under realistic disturbances, with enhanced safety and adaptability relative to current methods.

Conclusion: The RMPC-CBF framework is effective for safe autonomous navigation in complex waterways and may enable practical deployment, though real-world validation is needed.

Abstract: Deploying self-navigating surface vessels in inland waterways offers a
sustainable alternative to reduce road traffic congestion and emissions.
However, navigating confined waterways presents unique challenges, including
narrow channels, higher traffic density, and hydrodynamic disturbances.
Existing methods for autonomous vessel navigation often lack the robustness or
precision required for such environments. This paper presents a new motion
planning approach for Automated Surface Vessels (ASVs) using Robust Model
Predictive Control (RMPC) combined with Control Barrier Functions (CBFs). By
incorporating channel borders and obstacles as safety constraints within the
control design framework, the proposed method ensures both collision avoidance
and robust navigation on complex waterways. Simulation results demonstrate the
efficacy of the proposed method in safely guiding ASVs under realistic
conditions, highlighting its improved safety and adaptability compared to the
state-of-the-art.

</details>


### [313] [Embodied Hazard Mitigation using Vision-Language Models for Autonomous Mobile Robots](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06768)
*Oluwadamilola Sotomi,Devika Kodi,Kiruthiga Chandra Shekar,Aliasghar Arab*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A multimodal perception and proactive mitigation system for autonomous robots uses vision-language models and large language models to detect and report hazards and conflicts in real time, enabling automated mitigation; validated with user study (n=30) showing 91.2% accuracy and low latency on edge AI.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: In dynamic urban and environmental settings, anomalies threaten safety and continuity. There is a need for an integrated system that not only detects anomalies but also interprets, reports, and applies proactive mitigation strategies, incorporating Hazardous and Conflict states into the robot's decision-making.

Method: A multimodal architecture combining vision-language models and large language models to detect Hazardous and Conflict states, report findings, and trigger mitigation actions in real time. The system operates on edge-AI to reduce latency and supports proactive responses.

Result: High detection performance (91.2% accuracy) with relatively low latency on edge hardware, demonstrating effective anomaly detection and timely mitigation actions in dynamic environments.

Conclusion: The paper demonstrates the feasibility and benefits of integrating Hazardous and Conflict states into robotic decision-making for proactive anomaly management, presenting a capable framework for perception, interpretation, reporting, and mitigation in real time.

Abstract: Autonomous robots operating in dynamic environments should identify and
report anomalies. Embodying proactive mitigation improves safety and
operational continuity. This paper presents a multimodal anomaly detection and
mitigation system that integrates vision-language models and large language
models to identify and report hazardous situations and conflicts in real-time.
The proposed system enables robots to perceive, interpret, report, and if
possible respond to urban and environmental anomalies through proactive
detection mechanisms and automated mitigation actions. A key contribution in
this paper is the integration of Hazardous and Conflict states into the robot's
decision-making framework, where each anomaly type can trigger specific
mitigation strategies. User studies (n = 30) demonstrated the effectiveness of
the system in anomaly detection with 91.2% prediction accuracy and relatively
low latency response times using edge-ai architecture.

</details>


### [314] [CRISP -- Compliant ROS2 Controllers for Learning-Based Manipulation Policies and Teleoperation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06819)
*Daniel San José Pro,Oliver Hausdörfer,Ralf Römer,Maximilian Dösch,Martin Schuck,Angela P. Schöllig*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: CRISP is a lightweight ROS2-compliant compliant Cartesian and joint-space controller suite in C++, with Python and Gymnasium interfaces to enable data collection and learning-policy deployment on manipulators (e.g., FR3, IIWA14, Gen3).


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Learning-based controllers often cause low-frequency or discontinuous state changes. A low-level, torque-based controller is needed to achieve smooth reference tracking and compliant behavior during contact, and a unified pipeline is needed to integrate high-level policies with ROS2 manipulators.

Method: CRISP implements compliant Cartesian and joint-space controllers as a lightweight C++ ROS2 control package. It interfaces with the joint-torque interface, provides Python and Gymnasium APIs for data logging and policy deployment, and is designed for real-time performance and rapid integration with hardware and simulation (FR3, IIWA14, Gen3).

Result: Hardware validation on Franka FR3 and simulation validation on Kuka IIWA14 and Kinova Gen3, showing real-time performance and seamless interaction with learning-based policies and teleoperation workflows; demonstrates a unified pipeline for data collection and policy execution.

Conclusion: CRISP lowers barriers to applying learning-based methods on ROS2-compatible manipulators by delivering a ready-to-use, real-time, compliant torque-control solution with easy data collection and policy deployment, backed by documentation and hardware/simulation validation.

Abstract: Learning-based controllers, such as diffusion policies and vision-language
action models, often generate low-frequency or discontinuous robot state
changes. Achieving smooth reference tracking requires a low-level controller
that converts high-level targets commands into joint torques, enabling
compliant behavior during contact interactions. We present CRISP, a lightweight
C++ implementation of compliant Cartesian and joint-space controllers for the
ROS2 control standard, designed for seamless integration with high-level
learning-based policies as well as teleoperation. The controllers are
compatible with any manipulator that exposes a joint-torque interface. Through
our Python and Gymnasium interfaces, CRISP provides a unified pipeline for
recording data from hardware and simulation and deploying high-level
learning-based policies seamlessly, facilitating rapid experimentation. The
system has been validated on hardware with the Franka Robotics FR3 and in
simulation with the Kuka IIWA14 and Kinova Gen3. Designed for rapid
integration, flexible deployment, and real-time performance, our implementation
provides a unified pipeline for data collection and policy execution, lowering
the barrier to applying learning-based methods on ROS2-compatible manipulators.
Detailed documentation is available at the project website -
https://utiasDSL.github.io/crisp_controllers.

</details>


### [315] [Dynamic Modeling and Efficient Data-Driven Optimal Control for Micro Autonomous Surface Vehicles](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06882)
*Zhiheng Chen,Wei Wang*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: Physics-informed online learning-based control for an over-actuated MicroASV using a weak-form approach to adapt the dynamics model in real time, improving trajectory tracking under disturbances in simulations.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Precise, robust control of micro-scale surface vehicles is hard due to nonlinear hydrodynamics and strong sensitivity to self-motion and environmental disturbances; real-time adaptivity is needed for reliable operations.

Method: A physics-driven (physics-based) over-actuated MicroASV dynamics model is augmented with a data-driven online learning module that uses a weak formulation to update the model in real time; the adaptive model feeds an optimal control framework for trajectory tracking.

Result: Simulation results show substantially improved trajectory tracking accuracy and robustness, including under unknown payloads and external disturbances.

Conclusion: Data-driven online learning-based optimal control can enhance MicroASV performance, enabling more reliable and precise autonomous surface vehicle operations in challenging environments.

Abstract: Micro Autonomous Surface Vehicles (MicroASVs) offer significant potential for
operations in confined or shallow waters and swarm robotics applications.
However, achieving precise and robust control at such small scales remains
highly challenging, mainly due to the complexity of modeling nonlinear
hydrodynamic forces and the increased sensitivity to self-motion effects and
environmental disturbances, including waves and boundary effects in confined
spaces. This paper presents a physics-driven dynamics model for an
over-actuated MicroASV and introduces a data-driven optimal control framework
that leverages a weak formulation-based online model learning method. Our
approach continuously refines the physics-driven model in real time, enabling
adaptive control that adjusts to changing system parameters. Simulation results
demonstrate that the proposed method substantially enhances trajectory tracking
accuracy and robustness, even under unknown payloads and external disturbances.
These findings highlight the potential of data-driven online learning-based
optimal control to improve MicroASV performance, paving the way for more
reliable and precise autonomous surface vehicle operations.

</details>


### [316] [LLaDA-VLA: Vision Language Diffusion Action Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06932)
*Yuqing Wen,Hebei Li,Kefan Gu,Yucheng Zhao,Tiancai Wang,Xiaoyan Sun*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: First Vision-Language-Diffusion-Action (LLaDA-VLA) model for robotic manipulation built on pretrained diffusion-based VLMs; introduces two design strategies to adapt diffusion models to robotics; achieves SOTA results in both simulation and real robots.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Bridge diffusion-based vision-language models with robotic manipulation by enabling effective policy learning in the VLA setting and addressing adaptation challenges when applying d-VLMs to robotics.

Method: Two design components: (1) localized special-token classification — replace full-vocabulary classification with special action token classification to ease adaptation; (2) hierarchical action-structured decoding — decode action sequences hierarchically, capturing dependencies within and across actions.

Result: LLaDA-VLA significantly outperforms state-of-the-art Vision-Language-Action models on both simulated environments and real-world robotic platforms.

Conclusion: Demonstrates the feasibility and effectiveness of diffusion-based VLA for robotics, suggesting diffusion models are a strong building block for future vision-language-action policies in robotic manipulation.

Abstract: The rapid progress of auto-regressive vision-language models (VLMs) has
inspired growing interest in vision-language-action models (VLA) for robotic
manipulation. Recently, masked diffusion models, a paradigm distinct from
autoregressive models, have begun to demonstrate competitive performance in
text generation and multimodal applications, leading to the development of a
series of diffusion-based VLMs (d-VLMs). However, leveraging such models for
robot policy learning remains largely unexplored. In this work, we present
LLaDA-VLA, the first Vision-Language-Diffusion-Action model built upon
pretrained d-VLMs for robotic manipulation. To effectively adapt d-VLMs to
robotic domain, we introduce two key designs: (1) a localized special-token
classification strategy that replaces full-vocabulary classification with
special action token classification, reducing adaptation difficulty; (2) a
hierarchical action-structured decoding strategy that decodes action sequences
hierarchically considering the dependencies within and across actions.
Extensive experiments demonstrate that LLaDA-VLA significantly outperforms
state-of-the-art VLAs on both simulation and real-world robots.

</details>


### [317] [F1: A Vision-Language-Action Model Bridging Understanding and Generation to Actions](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06951)
*Qi Lv,Weijie Kong,Hao Li,Jia Zeng,Zherui Qiu,Delin Qu,Haoming Song,Qizhi Chen,Xiang Deng,Jiangmiao Pang*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: F1 introduces a pretrained Vision-Language-Action model with foresight generation integrated into the planning pipeline, using a Mixture-of-Transformer architecture and next-scale visual foresight to convert action generation into a foresight-guided inverse dynamics problem; trained on 330k trajectories across 136 tasks, achieving state-of-the-art results in accuracy and generalization.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To overcome the short-sighted, reactive behavior of existing VLA systems in dynamic environments by incorporating visual foresight into decision-making, thereby improving robustness and long-horizon planning.

Method: A Mixture-of-Transformer architecture with dedicated perception, foresight generation, and control modules. Introduces a next-scale prediction mechanism to synthesize goal-conditioned future visual states as explicit planning targets. Action generation is reformulated as a foresight-guided inverse dynamics problem. Three-stage training on a dataset with 330k trajectories across 136 tasks to promote modular reasoning and transferable foresight.

Result: Extensive evaluations on real-world tasks and simulation benchmarks show F1 consistently outperforms existing approaches, with substantial gains in task success rate and generalization.

Conclusion: Integrating explicit visual foresight into VLA systems via modular Transformer components and foresight-guided planning improves robustness and generalization in dynamic environments, with a scalable training recipe supporting transfer across diverse tasks.

Abstract: Executing language-conditioned tasks in dynamic visual environments remains a
central challenge in embodied AI. Existing Vision-Language-Action (VLA) models
predominantly adopt reactive state-to-action mappings, often leading to
short-sighted behaviors and poor robustness in dynamic scenes. In this paper,
we introduce F1, a pretrained VLA framework which integrates the visual
foresight generation into decision-making pipeline. F1 adopts a
Mixture-of-Transformer architecture with dedicated modules for perception,
foresight generation, and control, thereby bridging understanding, generation,
and actions. At its core, F1 employs a next-scale prediction mechanism to
synthesize goal-conditioned visual foresight as explicit planning targets. By
forecasting plausible future visual states, F1 reformulates action generation
as a foresight-guided inverse dynamics problem, enabling actions that
implicitly achieve visual goals. To endow F1 with robust and generalizable
capabilities, we propose a three-stage training recipe on an extensive dataset
comprising over 330k trajectories across 136 diverse tasks. This training
scheme enhances modular reasoning and equips the model with transferable visual
foresight, which is critical for complex and dynamic environments. Extensive
evaluations on real-world tasks and simulation benchmarks demonstrate F1
consistently outperforms existing approaches, achieving substantial gains in
both task success rate and generalization ability.

</details>


### [318] [Deep Reactive Policy: Learning Reactive Manipulator Motion Planning for Dynamic Environments](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06953)
*Jiahui Yang,Jason Jingzhou Liu,Yulong Li,Youssef Khaky,Kenneth Shaw,Deepak Pathak*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: DRP (Deep Reactive Policy) enables robust, reactive motion in dynamic, partially observable environments via a visuo-motor neural policy (IMPACT) trained on 10M expert trajectories; it uses iterative finetuning for static obstacles and a local reactive module for dynamic obstacles, achieving superior generalization and success in both simulated and real-world tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Classical global planners require full environment knowledge and are slow in dynamic scenes; purely neural policies can lack generalization to complex, changing environments. There is a need for a reactive, generalizable policy that operates on raw sensor data (point clouds) and handles both static and dynamic obstacles.

Method: DRP uses IMPACT, a transformer-based neural motion policy pretrained on 10 million expert trajectories spanning diverse simulations. Static obstacle avoidance is improved via iterative student-teacher finetuning. Dynamic obstacle avoidance is augmented at inference with DCP-RMP, a locally reactive goal-proposal module. The system operates directly on point cloud inputs.

Result: DRP demonstrates strong generalization and achieves higher success rates than prior classical and neural methods across both simulated and real-world tasks featuring clutter, moving obstacles, and goal obstructions.

Conclusion: DRP offers a robust, generalizable approach to reactive motion generation in dynamic environments, leveraging large-scale imitation learning, targeted finetuning, and local reactive modules. It shows promise for real-world robotic manipulation and opens avenues for further enhancements in dynamic scene understanding and efficiency.

Abstract: Generating collision-free motion in dynamic, partially observable
environments is a fundamental challenge for robotic manipulators. Classical
motion planners can compute globally optimal trajectories but require full
environment knowledge and are typically too slow for dynamic scenes. Neural
motion policies offer a promising alternative by operating in closed-loop
directly on raw sensory inputs but often struggle to generalize in complex or
dynamic settings. We propose Deep Reactive Policy (DRP), a visuo-motor neural
motion policy designed for reactive motion generation in diverse dynamic
environments, operating directly on point cloud sensory input. At its core is
IMPACT, a transformer-based neural motion policy pretrained on 10 million
generated expert trajectories across diverse simulation scenarios. We further
improve IMPACT's static obstacle avoidance through iterative student-teacher
finetuning. We additionally enhance the policy's dynamic obstacle avoidance at
inference time using DCP-RMP, a locally reactive goal-proposal module. We
evaluate DRP on challenging tasks featuring cluttered scenes, dynamic moving
obstacles, and goal obstructions. DRP achieves strong generalization,
outperforming prior classical and neural methods in success rate across both
simulated and real-world settings. Video results and code available at
https://deep-reactive-policy.com

</details>


### [319] [LocoMamba: Vision-Driven Locomotion via End-to-End Deep Reinforcement Learning with Mamba](https://arxiv.org/abs/2508.11849)
*Yinuo Wang,Gavin Tao*

Main category: cs.RO

TL;DR: A vision-driven cross-modal DRL framework (LocoMamba) uses selective Mamba layers to achieve near-linear-time long-sequence modeling, fusing proprioceptive signals and depth patches for robust, efficient navigation under obstacles and varied terrains, outperforming baselines in simulation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address sample inefficiency and poor long-horizon reasoning in DRL for robotics by enabling scalable, long-range sequence modeling in a cross-modal setting (proprioception + vision) with robust generalization to terrain and obstacle variation.

Method: Tokenize proprioceptive states with an MLP and patchify depth images with a lightweight CNN to form compact tokens. Apply stacked Mamba layers for near-linear-time, selective fusion of tokens, enabling long sequences with reduced latency and memory. Train end-to-end with Proximal Policy Optimization under terrain/appearance randomization and an obstacle-density curriculum, using a compact state-centric reward balancing progress, smoothness, and safety.

Result: Outperforms state-of-the-art baselines in simulation: higher returns and success rates with fewer collisions, stronger generalization to unseen terrains and obstacle densities, and faster convergence under the same compute budget, in environments with static/moving obstacles and uneven terrain.

Conclusion: LocoMamba demonstrates that near-linear-time selective sequence modeling on cross-modal tokens can yield robust, efficient, and scalable vision-guided DRL for navigation across challenging terrains, with practical training efficiency gains and improved generalization.

Abstract: We introduce LocoMamba, a vision-driven cross-modal DRL framework built on
selective state-space models, specifically leveraging Mamba, that achieves
near-linear-time sequence modeling, effectively captures long-range
dependencies, and enables efficient training with longer sequences. First, we
embed proprioceptive states with a multilayer perceptron and patchify depth
images with a lightweight convolutional neural network, producing compact
tokens that improve state representation. Second, stacked Mamba layers fuse
these tokens via near-linear-time selective scanning, reducing latency and
memory footprint, remaining robust to token length and image resolution, and
providing an inductive bias that mitigates overfitting. Third, we train the
policy end-to-end with Proximal Policy Optimization under terrain and
appearance randomization and an obstacle-density curriculum, using a compact
state-centric reward that balances progress, smoothness, and safety. We
evaluate our method in challenging simulated environments with static and
moving obstacles as well as uneven terrain. Compared with state-of-the-art
baselines, our method achieves higher returns and success rates with fewer
collisions, exhibits stronger generalization to unseen terrains and obstacle
densities, and improves training efficiency by converging in fewer updates
under the same compute budget.

</details>


<div id='cs.CG'></div>

# cs.CG [[Back]](#toc)

### [320] [Well-Separated Pairs Decomposition Revisited](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05997)
*Sariel Har-Peled,Benjamin Raichel,Eliot W. Robson*

Main category: cs.CG

TL;DR: New WSPD constructions: (i) for any finite metric space with instance-optimal size; (ii) weighted unit-distance metric in the plane with size O(ε^{-2} n log n). Also applications: near-linear-time distortion approximation between point sets; shortcut polygonal curves to low-dilation, including a near-linear time algorithm to extract a simple non-self-intersecting subcurve.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: WSPD is a fundamental tool for fast geometric algorithms to bound pair interactions; reducing their size improves running time and memory in high-performance geometry tasks. Extending WSPD to arbitrary finite metric spaces and to weighted unit-distance metrics in the plane opens doors to efficient approximation in broader settings and sharper bounds. New applications to bijection distortion and curve simplification expand practical uses.

Method: Construct a new WSPD for any finite metric space with asymptotically instance-optimal size; develop a WSPD for the weighted unit-distance metric in the plane with O(ε^{-2} n log n) size; analyze complexity and provide simpler construction; apply WSPD to approximate bijection distortion; propose and implement a near-linear-time shortcutting algorithm for polygonal curves to achieve a target dilation and produce a simple non-self-intersecting subcurve.

Result: Instance-optimal WSPD size in general finite metric spaces; improved size bound in plane weighted unit-distance metric: O(ε^{-2} n log n), beating previous ε^{-2} factor; simpler construction; near-linear-time algorithms for dilation approximation and subcurve simplification; practical algorithm for obtaining a simple subcurve with no self-intersections.

Conclusion: The work tightens theoretical bounds on WSPD size across settings and broadens practical applications in geometric computation, suggesting further exploration in other metrics, dimensions, and optimization targets.

Abstract: We revisit the notion of WSPD (i.e., well-separated pairs-decomposition),
presenting a new construction of WSPD for any finite metric space, and show
that it is asymptotically instance-optimal in size. Next, we describe a new
WSPD construction for the weighted unit-distance metric in the plane, and show
a bound $O( \varepsilon^{-2} n \log n)$ on its size, improving by a factor of
$1/\varepsilon^2$ over previous work. The new construction is arguably simpler
and more elegant.
  We point out that using WSPD, one can approximate, in near-linear time, the
distortion of a bijection between two point sets in low dimensions. As a new
application of WSPD, we show how to shortcut a polygonal curve such that its
dilation is below a prespecified quantity. In particular, we show a near-linear
time algorithm for computing a simple subcurve for a given polygonal curve in
the plane so that the new subcurve has no self-intersection.

</details>


### [321] [Using Reinforcement Learning to Optimize the Global and Local Crossing Number](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06108)
*Timo Brand,Henry Förster,Stephen Kobourov,Robin Schukrafft,Markus Wallinger,Johannes Zink*

Main category: cs.CG

TL;DR: An RL-based method for graph drawing to minimize total and maximum edge crossings, using a vertex-moving agent with local rewards and a stress-based initialization; mixed results, competitive for local crossing number.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Crossings degrade readability in graph drawings. Traditional methods use force- or stress-based optimization; a learning-based approach could adaptively optimize layouts. 

Method: An agent observes a feature vector and moves a vertex to reduce crossings. The agent receives local rewards tied to crossing reductions. An initial layout is generated by a stress-based algorithm. The method is compared against force- and stress-based baselines and three established global-crossing algorithms on benchmark graphs.

Result: Experiments show mixed results: the RL method is mainly competitive for minimizing the local crossing number; performance on global crossing minimization is not clearly superior. The results indicate potential but require further development.

Conclusion: Reinforcement learning for graph drawing is promising but not yet outperforming traditional methods across objectives; future work should focus on improving stability, generalization, and performance on global crossing minimization.

Abstract: We present a novel approach to graph drawing based on reinforcement learning
for minimizing the global and the local crossing number, that is, the total
number of edge crossings and the maximum number of crossings on any edge,
respectively. In our framework, an agent learns how to move a vertex based on a
given observation vector in order to optimize its position. The agent receives
feedback in the form of local reward signals tied to crossing reduction. To
generate an initial layout, we use a stress-based graph-drawing algorithm. We
compare our method against force- and stress-based (baseline) algorithms as
well as three established algorithms for global crossing minimization on a
suite of benchmark graphs. The experiments show mixed results: our current
algorithm is mainly competitive for the local crossing number. We see a
potential for further development of the approach in the future.

</details>


<div id='cs.AI'></div>

# cs.AI [[Back]](#toc)

### [322] [Attention of a Kiss: Exploring Attention Maps in Video Diffusion for XAIxArts](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05323)
*Adam Cole,Mick Grierson*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: A tool to extract and visualize cross-attention maps in text-to-video diffusion models (Wan), enabling interpretable analysis of temporal/spatial attention and presenting attention maps as both analytical tools and artistic material within a XAIxArts framework.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To illuminate how attention operates in video diffusion transformers and to merge Explainable AI with the arts by offering artists a window into the model's inner workings, drawing inspiration from early video artists who manipulated analog signals.

Method: Proposes a workflow to extract and visualize cross-attention maps from a text-to-video diffusion model, built on the Wan open-source framework. The approach emphasizes temporal and spatial attention behavior and includes exploratory probes and an artistic case study to demonstrate interpretability and potential artistic use.

Result: A usable visualization tool that reveals cross-attention dynamics across time and space in video-generation, accompanied by exploratory probes and an artistic case study, illustrating the twin role of attention maps as analytical assets and raw material for art within XAIxArts.

Conclusion: The work advances Explainable AI for the Arts by providing a concrete method and tooling to access attention in video diffusion models, inviting artists to reclaim and repurpose the model's inner mechanisms as a creative medium.

Abstract: This paper presents an artistic and technical investigation into the
attention mechanisms of video diffusion transformers. Inspired by early video
artists who manipulated analog video signals to create new visual aesthetics,
this study proposes a method for extracting and visualizing cross-attention
maps in generative video models. Built on the open-source Wan model, our tool
provides an interpretable window into the temporal and spatial behavior of
attention in text-to-video generation. Through exploratory probes and an
artistic case study, we examine the potential of attention maps as both
analytical tools and raw artistic material. This work contributes to the
growing field of Explainable AI for the Arts (XAIxArts), inviting artists to
reclaim the inner workings of AI as a creative medium.

</details>


### [323] [Perception Graph for Cognitive Attack Reasoning in Augmented Reality](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05324)
*Rongqian Chen,Shu Hong,Rifatul Islam,Mahdi Imani,G. Gary Tan,Tian Lan*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: A Perception Graph to quantify perception distortion in AR tactical systems to detect cognitive attacks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: AR systems in tactical environments are vulnerable to cognitive attacks that manipulate perception and impair decision-making; there is a need for a robust, measurable method to detect and analyze such distortion.

Method: Proposes the Perception Graph, a model that mimics how humans interpret key information from a mixed reality environment and encodes the outcomes into a semantically meaningful structure, enabling computation of a distortion score.

Result: Demonstrates that the Perception Graph can compute a quantitative score representing the level of perception distortion, offering a robust and measurable method for detecting and analyzing cognitive attacks in AR systems.

Conclusion: The Perception Graph provides a novel, quantitative framework for detecting and analyzing perception-manipulation attacks in AR/Tactical MR settings, enhancing safety and reliability.

Abstract: Augmented reality (AR) systems are increasingly deployed in tactical
environments, but their reliance on seamless human-computer interaction makes
them vulnerable to cognitive attacks that manipulate a user's perception and
severely compromise user decision-making. To address this challenge, we
introduce the Perception Graph, a novel model designed to reason about human
perception within these systems. Our model operates by first mimicking the
human process of interpreting key information from an MR environment and then
representing the outcomes using a semantically meaningful structure. We
demonstrate how the model can compute a quantitative score that reflects the
level of perception distortion, providing a robust and measurable method for
detecting and analyzing the effects of such cognitive attacks.

</details>


### [324] [SynDelay: A Synthetic Dataset for Delivery Delay Prediction](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05325)
*Liming Xu,Yunbo Long,Alexandra Brintrup*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: SynDelay proposes a synthetic, privacy-preserving dataset for delivery delay prediction to enable reproducible benchmarks in supply chain AI, with baseline results and open availability.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Progress in predictive supply chain tasks is hindered by scarce, proprietary, or inconsistently maintained datasets. A high-quality, open, and privacy-preserving dataset is needed to enable reproducibility and benchmarking.

Method: A generative model trained on real-world data creates SynDelay, a synthetic delivery delay dataset that preserves realistic patterns while protecting privacy. The dataset includes baseline results and evaluation metrics. Code and data are openly available to the community.

Result: SynDelay provides a realistic, challenging testbed for predictive modelling; baseline results and evaluation metrics are provided as reference points. The dataset is publicly available via the Supply Chain Data Hub; expect some noise and inconsistencies inherent in synthetic data but useful for benchmarking.

Conclusion: SynDelay supports open benchmarking in supply chain AI, encouraging community contributions of datasets, models, and evaluation practices to advance research in delivery delay prediction.

Abstract: Artificial intelligence (AI) is transforming supply chain management, yet
progress in predictive tasks -- such as delivery delay prediction -- remains
constrained by the scarcity of high-quality, openly available datasets.
Existing datasets are often proprietary, small, or inconsistently maintained,
hindering reproducibility and benchmarking. We present SynDelay, a synthetic
dataset designed for delivery delay prediction. Generated using an advanced
generative model trained on real-world data, SynDelay preserves realistic
delivery patterns while ensuring privacy. Although not entirely free of noise
or inconsistencies, it provides a challenging and practical testbed for
advancing predictive modelling. To support adoption, we provide baseline
results and evaluation metrics as initial benchmarks, serving as reference
points rather than state-of-the-art claims. SynDelay is publicly available
through the Supply Chain Data Hub, an open initiative promoting dataset sharing
and benchmarking in supply chain AI. We encourage the community to contribute
datasets, models, and evaluation practices to advance research in this area.
All code is openly accessible at https://supplychaindatahub.org.

</details>


### [325] [MVRS: The Multimodal Virtual Reality Stimuli-based Emotion Recognition Dataset](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05330)
*Seyed Muhammad Hossein Mousavi,Atiye Ilanloo*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Launches MVRS, a synchronized multimodal emotion dataset with eye-tracking, body motion, EMG, and GSR during VR stimuli, enabling early/late fusion and classifier-based validation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the shortage of multimodal affective datasets that combine body motion and physiological signals, to advance emotion recognition research in AI-enabled domains (healthcare, education, automotive).

Method: Record 13 participants (ages 12–60) exposed to VR emotional stimuli (relaxation, fear, stress, sadness, joy). Collect synchronized data: eye tracking via VR headset webcam, Kinect v2 body motion, EMG and GSR via Arduino UNO; timestamp alignment; standardized protocol with consent and questionnaires; extract features per modality; apply early and late fusion; train/evaluate classifiers to assess data quality and emotion separability.

Result: Validated dataset quality and demonstrated emotion separability across modalities, supporting MVRS as a useful resource for multimodal affective computing.

Conclusion: MVRS provides a valuable, synchronized multimodal dataset to advance multimodal emotion recognition and fusion approaches in practical AI systems.

Abstract: Automatic emotion recognition has become increasingly important with the rise
of AI, especially in fields like healthcare, education, and automotive systems.
However, there is a lack of multimodal datasets, particularly involving body
motion and physiological signals, which limits progress in the field. To
address this, the MVRS dataset is introduced, featuring synchronized recordings
