from 13 participants aged 12 to 60 exposed to VR based emotional stimuli
(relaxation, fear, stress, sadness, joy). Data were collected using eye
tracking (via webcam in a VR headset), body motion (Kinect v2), and EMG and GSR
signals (Arduino UNO), all timestamp aligned. Participants followed a unified
protocol with consent and questionnaires. Features from each modality were
extracted, fused using early and late fusion techniques, and evaluated with
classifiers to confirm the datasets quality and emotion separability, making
MVRS a valuable contribution to multimodal affective computing.

</details>


### [326] [Benchmarking Large Language Models for Personalized Guidance in AI-Enhanced Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05346)
*Bo Yuan,Jiazi Hu*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: GPT-4o is generally preferred among evaluated LLMs for tutoring tasks; the study demonstrates the feasibility of LLMs as advanced teaching assistants and uses a structured evaluation framework.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address the lack of head-to-head evaluations of LLMs in authentic, personalized learning settings and to assess their ability to dissect quizzes, infer mastery, and provide targeted guidance.

Method: Empirical comparison of three state-of-the-art LLMs on a tutoring task with a dataset of 10-question mixed-format items (with correctness labels). Each model analyzes the quiz to identify knowledge components, infers the student's mastery profile, and generates targeted guidance. Gemini acts as a virtual judge to perform pairwise comparisons across accuracy, clarity, actionability, and appropriateness. Bradley-Terry model used to analyze results.

Result: GPT-4o generally preferred; produced feedback that is more informative and better structured than the others. DeepSeek-V3 and GLM-4.5 show intermittent strengths but lower consistency.

Conclusion: LLMs can be feasibly deployed as advanced teaching assistants for individualized support; the study provides methodological guidance for future empirical research on LLM-driven personalized learning.

Abstract: While Large Language Models (LLMs) are increasingly envisioned as intelligent
assistants for personalized learning, systematic head-to-head evaluations
within authentic learning scenarios remain limited. This study conducts an
empirical comparison of three state-of-the-art LLMs on a tutoring task that
simulates a realistic learning setting. Using a dataset comprising a student's
answers to ten questions of mixed formats with correctness labels, each LLM is
required to (i) analyze the quiz to identify underlying knowledge components,
(ii) infer the student's mastery profile, and (iii) generate targeted guidance
for improvement. To mitigate subjectivity and evaluator bias, we employ Gemini
as a virtual judge to perform pairwise comparisons along various dimensions:
accuracy, clarity, actionability, and appropriateness. Results analyzed via the
Bradley-Terry model indicate that GPT-4o is generally preferred, producing
feedback that is more informative and better structured than its counterparts,
while DeepSeek-V3 and GLM-4.5 demonstrate intermittent strengths but lower
consistency. These findings highlight the feasibility of deploying LLMs as
advanced teaching assistants for individualized support and provide
methodological guidance for future empirical research on LLM-driven
personalized learning.

</details>


### [327] [SasAgent: Multi-Agent AI System for Small-Angle Scattering Data Analysis](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05363)
*Lijie Ding,Changwoo Do*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: SasAgent is a multi-agent, LLM-driven system that automates small-angle scattering (SAS) data analysis by coordinating three specialized agents (SLD calculation, synthetic data generation, and experimental data fitting) using SasView tools, with a Gradio UI, demonstrating accurate SLDs, data generation, and fitting.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Automate and streamline SAS data analysis workflows by leveraging LLMs and existing SasView tooling to enable interactive, text-driven analysis with reduced manual effort.

Method: A coordinator agent interprets prompts and delegates tasks to three specialized agents. These agents use LLM-friendly tools (model data tool, RAG documentation tool, bump fitting tool, SLD calculator tool) derived from the SasView Python library. A Gradio-based UI provides accessibility.

Result: The system demonstrates the ability to interpret complex prompts, compute SLDs, generate accurate synthetic scattering data, and fit experimental datasets with high precision.

Conclusion: LLM-driven AI systems can streamline scientific workflows and automate SAS research, showcasing potential for broader automation in SAS analysis.

Abstract: We introduce SasAgent, a multi-agent AI system powered by large language
models (LLMs) that automates small-angle scattering (SAS) data analysis by
leveraging tools from the SasView software and enables user interaction via
text input. SasAgent features a coordinator agent that interprets user prompts
and delegates tasks to three specialized agents for scattering length density
(SLD) calculation, synthetic data generation, and experimental data fitting.
These agents utilize LLM-friendly tools to execute tasks efficiently. These
tools, including the model data tool, Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG)
documentation tool, bump fitting tool, and SLD calculator tool, are derived
from the SasView Python library. A user-friendly Gradio-based interface
enhances user accessibility. Through diverse examples, we demonstrate
SasAgent's ability to interpret complex prompts, calculate SLDs, generate
accurate scattering data, and fit experimental datasets with high precision.
This work showcases the potential of LLM-driven AI systems to streamline
scientific workflows and enhance automation in SAS research.

</details>


### [328] [Characterizing Fitness Landscape Structures in Prompt Engineering](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05375)
*Arend Hintze*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Prompt optimization landscapes differ by generation strategy: systematic prompts yield smooth autocorrelation; novelty-driven prompts produce rugged, hierarchical landscapes, with task-specific ruggedness across error types.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To move beyond black-box prompt search by characterizing the topology of prompt fitness landscapes in semantic embedding spaces, informing search strategies.

Method: Autocorrelation analysis in embedding spaces; experiments on error detection with two prompt-gen strategies: systematic enumeration (1,024 prompts) and novelty-driven diversification (1,000 prompts). Landscape topology assessed via autocorrelation patterns; task-specific analysis across 10 error categories.

Result: Two distinct landscape topologies: smooth decay for systematic prompts; non-monotonic, peak autocorrelation at intermediate semantic distances for novelty-driven prompts, indicating rugged, hierarchical landscapes. Ruggedness varies across error categories; provides empirical evidence of landscape complexity.

Conclusion: An empirical foundation showing landscape structure depends on generation strategy; implications for choosing prompt optimization methods and understanding search difficulty in prompt engineering.

Abstract: While prompt engineering has emerged as a crucial technique for optimizing
large language model performance, the underlying optimization landscape remains
poorly understood. Current approaches treat prompt optimization as a black-box
problem, applying sophisticated search algorithms without characterizing the
landscape topology they navigate. We present a systematic analysis of fitness
landscape structures in prompt engineering using autocorrelation analysis
across semantic embedding spaces. Through experiments on error detection tasks
with two distinct prompt generation strategies -- systematic enumeration (1,024
prompts) and novelty-driven diversification (1,000 prompts) -- we reveal
fundamentally different landscape topologies. Systematic prompt generation
yields smoothly decaying autocorrelation, while diversified generation exhibits
non-monotonic patterns with peak correlation at intermediate semantic
distances, indicating rugged, hierarchically structured landscapes.
Task-specific analysis across 10 error detection categories reveals varying
degrees of ruggedness across different error types. Our findings provide an
empirical foundation for understanding the complexity of optimization in prompt
engineering landscapes.

</details>


### [329] [Code Like Humans: A Multi-Agent Solution for Medical Coding](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05378)
*Andreas Motzfeldt,Joakim Edin,Casper L. Christensen,Christian Hardmeier,Lars Maaløe,Anna Rogers*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: A new agentic LLM-based framework, Code Like Humans, for medical coding that scales to ICD-10 (70k+ labels), achieving best-known performance on rare codes, with discriminative classifiers aiding high-frequency codes; also analyzes system blind spots.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Medical coding requires accurate, scalable mapping from unstructured clinical notes to ICD-10 codes; existing approaches struggle with rare codes and the full ICD-10 scale; there is a need for guideline-aligned AI that can handle many labels.

Method: An agentic framework that enforces official human-coding guidelines via prompts/decision logic in an LLM, scales to 70k+ ICD-10 codes, uses fine-tuned discriminative classifiers for high-frequency codes, and provides analysis of performance and undercoding blind spots.

Result: Achieves best performance to date on rare diagnosis codes; fine-tuned discriminative classifiers retain an advantage for high-frequency codes; capable of supporting the full ICD-10 system; identifies systematic undercoding blind spots.

Conclusion: Demonstrates feasibility and potential of guideline-aligned LLMs for large-scale medical coding; highlights need to address blind spots and calibrate for broader clinical deployment.

Abstract: In medical coding, experts map unstructured clinical notes to alphanumeric
codes for diagnoses and procedures. We introduce Code Like Humans: a new
agentic framework for medical coding with large language models. It implements
official coding guidelines for human experts, and it is the first solution that
can support the full ICD-10 coding system (+70K labels). It achieves the best
performance to date on rare diagnosis codes (fine-tuned discriminative
classifiers retain an advantage for high-frequency codes, to which they are
limited). Towards future work, we also contribute an analysis of system
performance and identify its `blind spots' (codes that are systematically
undercoded).

</details>


### [330] [Murphys Laws of AI Alignment: Why the Gap Always Wins](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05381)
*Madhava Gaikwad*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: This work reframes alignment failures in feedback-based learning as an Alignment Gap quantified via KL-tilting, and offers a taxonomy (Murphy’s Laws) and trade-offs (Alignment Trilemma) with practical levers (MAPS) to guide future design, rather than claiming impossibility or complete resolution.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Despite progress in RLHF and related methods, recurring failure patterns (reward hacking, sycophancy, annotator drift, misgeneralization) persist. A unifying conceptual framework is needed to diagnose, compare, and design around these structural issues in alignment research.

Method: Introduce a KL-tilting formalism to explain how optimization pressure drives divergence between proxy rewards and true human intent (Alignment Gap). Catalog failures as Murphy’s Laws of AI Alignment. Frame trade-offs via the Alignment Trilemma among optimization strength, value capture, and generalization. Propose the MAPS framework (Misspecification, Annotation, Pressure, Shift) as actionable design levers. Support with small-scale empirical illustrations.

Result: Provides a unifying perspective and design guidance rather than definitive impossibility results. Clarifies how feedback-based optimization can amplify misalignment, organizes failures into a coherent taxonomy, and offers practical levers (MAPS) and framing (Alignment Gap, Trilemma) to guide future work and experiments.

Conclusion: The paper reframes alignment debates around structural limits and trade-offs, offering a structured framework to diagnose and mitigate alignment failures and to guide future research and design in feedback-based alignment.

Abstract: Large language models are increasingly aligned to human preferences through
reinforcement learning from human feedback (RLHF) and related methods such as
Direct Preference Optimization (DPO), Constitutional AI, and RLAIF. While
effective, these methods exhibit recurring failure patterns i.e., reward
hacking, sycophancy, annotator drift, and misgeneralization. We introduce the
concept of the Alignment Gap, a unifying lens for understanding recurring
failures in feedback-based alignment. Using a KL-tilting formalism, we
illustrate why optimization pressure tends to amplify divergence between proxy
rewards and true human intent. We organize these failures into a catalogue of
Murphys Laws of AI Alignment, and propose the Alignment Trilemma as a way to
frame trade-offs among optimization strength, value capture, and
generalization. Small-scale empirical studies serve as illustrative support.
Finally, we propose the MAPS framework (Misspecification, Annotation, Pressure,
Shift) as practical design levers. Our contribution is not a definitive
impossibility theorem but a perspective that reframes alignment debates around
structural limits and trade-offs, offering clearer guidance for future design.

</details>


### [331] [From Image Generation to Infrastructure Design: a Multi-agent Pipeline for Street Design Generation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05469)
*Chenguang Wang,Xiang Yan,Yilong Dai,Ziyi Wang,Susu Xu*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: A multi-agent pipeline edits real street-view imagery to design bicycle facilities with context-aware generation and automated evaluation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Public engagement in street design is hampered by labor-intensive workflows and limited ability to meaningfully vary designs in complex street-view contexts; AI-based generative design should require less tailored data while enabling precise spatial control.

Method: A multi-agent framework that localizes lanes, optimizes prompts, generates bicycle-facility designs, and performs automated evaluation directly on real street-view imagery to synthesize realistic, contextually appropriate designs.

Result: Across diverse urban scenarios the system adapts to varying road geometries and environmental conditions, yielding visually coherent, instruction-compliant designs consistently.

Conclusion: This work lays a foundation for applying multi-agent pipelines to transportation infrastructure planning and facility design, enabling scalable, participatory AI-assisted design.

Abstract: Realistic visual renderings of street-design scenarios are essential for
public engagement in active transportation planning. Traditional approaches are
labor-intensive, hindering collective deliberation and collaborative
decision-making. While AI-assisted generative design shows transformative
potential by enabling rapid creation of design scenarios, existing generative
approaches typically require large amounts of domain-specific training data and
struggle to enable precise spatial variations of design/configuration in
complex street-view scenes. We introduce a multi-agent system that edits and
redesigns bicycle facilities directly on real-world street-view imagery. The
framework integrates lane localization, prompt optimization, design generation,
and automated evaluation to synthesize realistic, contextually appropriate
designs. Experiments across diverse urban scenarios demonstrate that the system
can adapt to varying road geometries and environmental conditions, consistently
yielding visually coherent and instruction-compliant results. This work
establishes a foundation for applying multi-agent pipelines to transportation
infrastructure planning and facility design.

</details>


### [332] [TreeGPT: A Novel Hybrid Architecture for Abstract Syntax Tree Processing with Global Parent-Child Aggregation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05550)
*Zixi Li*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: TreeGPT is a hybrid transformer-TreeFFN model for processing Abstract Syntax Trees (ASTs) using a Global Parent-Child Aggregation mechanism, achieving 96% accuracy on ARC Prize 2025 with only 1.5M parameters, surpassing transformers, Grok-4, and SOAR. Edge projection and gating are identified as key components.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address limitations of purely sequential transformers and pure graph neural networks in neural program synthesis by explicitly modeling hierarchical AST structure. The goal is to enable efficient, scalable, and accurate aggregation of information across the entire tree through a global parent-child mechanism.

Method: A hybrid architecture that combines self-attention with a Tree Feed-Forward Network (TreeFFN) and introduces Global Parent-Child Aggregation: h_i^{(t+1)} = sigma(h_i^{(0)} + W_pc * sum_{(p,c) in E_i} f(h_p^{(t)}, h_c^{(t)}) + b). Nodes update over T iterations by aggregating information from parent-child edges. Optional enhancements include gated aggregation with learnable edge weights, residual connections, and bidirectional (bottom-up/top-down) propagation. The method is evaluated on the ARC Prize 2025 dataset for visual reasoning and rule inference.

Result: On ARC Prize 2025, TreeGPT achieves 96% accuracy, outperforming transformers baselines (1.3%), Grok-4 (15.9%), and SOAR (52%) while using only 1.5M parameters. An ablation study indicates edge projection is the most critical component, with the combination of edge projection and gating yielding optimal performance.

Conclusion: Global parent-child aggregation combined with attention-based processing and TreeFFN effectively captures hierarchical AST structure for neural program synthesis. The approach delivers strong performance with a compact model, highlighting the importance of edge projection and gating in the aggregation mechanism.

Abstract: We introduce TreeGPT, a novel neural architecture that combines
transformer-based attention mechanisms with global parent-child aggregation for
processing Abstract Syntax Trees (ASTs) in neural program synthesis tasks.
Unlike traditional approaches that rely solely on sequential processing or
graph neural networks, TreeGPT employs a hybrid design that leverages both
self-attention for capturing local dependencies and a specialized Tree
Feed-Forward Network (TreeFFN) for modeling hierarchical tree structures
through iterative message passing.
  The core innovation lies in our Global Parent-Child Aggregation mechanism,
formalized as: $$h_i^{(t+1)} = \sigma \Big( h_i^{(0)} + W_{pc} \sum_{(p,c) \in
E_i} f(h_p^{(t)}, h_c^{(t)}) + b \Big)$$ where $h_i^{(t)}$ represents the
hidden state of node $i$ at iteration $t$, $E_i$ denotes all parent-child edges
involving node $i$, and $f(h_p, h_c)$ is an edge aggregation function. This
formulation enables each node to progressively aggregate information from the
entire tree structure through $T$ iterations.
  Our architecture integrates optional enhancements including gated aggregation
with learnable edge weights, residual connections for gradient stability, and
bidirectional propagation for capturing both bottom-up and top-down
dependencies. We evaluate TreeGPT on the ARC Prize 2025 dataset, a challenging
visual reasoning benchmark requiring abstract pattern recognition and rule
inference. Experimental results demonstrate that TreeGPT achieves 96\%
accuracy, significantly outperforming transformer baselines (1.3\%),
large-scale models like Grok-4 (15.9\%), and specialized program synthesis
methods like SOAR (52\%) while using only 1.5M parameters. Our comprehensive
ablation study reveals that edge projection is the most critical component,
with the combination of edge projection and gating achieving optimal
performance.

</details>


### [333] [OccVLA: Vision-Language-Action Model with Implicit 3D Occupancy Supervision](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05578)
*Ruixun Liu,Lingyu Kong,Derun Li,Hang Zhao*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: OccVLA integrates 3D occupancy into multimodal LLMs for autonomous driving by predicting occupancy as supervision from 2D inputs, enabling fine-grained 3D reasoning with no inference overhead.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Address the lack of robust 3D spatial understanding in vision-and-language models for autonomous driving, caused by scarce accessible 3D representations and degradation of 3D details in VLM1 pretraining.

Method: OccVLA treats dense 3D occupancy as both a predictive output and a supervisory signal learned from 2D visual inputs. Occupancy predictions are used as implicit reasoning and can be skipped at inference time without extra computation.

Result: Achieves state-of-the-art trajectory planning on the nuScenes benchmark and strong 3D VQA performance, offering a scalable, fully vision-based solution with interpretable occupancy as an auxiliary signal.

Conclusion: Integrating occupancy-based 3D representations into multimodal reasoning enhances 3D understanding in MLLMs for autonomous driving without increasing inference cost, enabling scalable vision-based perception and reasoning.

Abstract: Multimodal large language models (MLLMs) have shown strong vision-language
reasoning abilities but still lack robust 3D spatial understanding, which is
critical for autonomous driving. This limitation stems from two key challenges:
(1) the difficulty of constructing accessible yet effective 3D representations
without expensive manual annotations, and (2) the loss of fine-grained spatial
details in VLMs due to the absence of large-scale 3D vision-language
pretraining. To address these challenges, we propose OccVLA, a novel framework
that integrates 3D occupancy representations into a unified multimodal
reasoning process. Unlike prior approaches that rely on explicit 3D inputs,
OccVLA treats dense 3D occupancy as both a predictive output and a supervisory
signal, enabling the model to learn fine-grained spatial structures directly
from 2D visual inputs. The occupancy predictions are regarded as implicit
reasoning processes and can be skipped during inference without performance
degradation, thereby adding no extra computational overhead. OccVLA achieves
state-of-the-art results on the nuScenes benchmark for trajectory planning and
demonstrates superior performance on 3D visual question-answering tasks,
offering a scalable, interpretable, and fully vision-based solution for
autonomous driving.

</details>


### [334] [MSRFormer: Road Network Representation Learning using Multi-scale Feature Fusion of Heterogeneous Spatial Interactions](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05685)
*Jian Yang,Jiahui Wu,Li Fang,Hongchao Fan,Bianying Zhang,Huijie Zhao,Guangyi Yang,Rui Xin,Xiong You*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: MSRFormer introduces a multi-scale, flow-aware road network representation framework that combines spatial flow convolution, scale-aware interaction regions, and a graph transformer with residual fusion and contrastive learning. It captures heterogeneous, hierarchical road networks and long-range dependencies, achieving notable improvements over baselines, especially when using trajectory data.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Urban road networks are heterogeneous and hierarchical. GNNs that assume homogeneity and single-scale interactions struggle to learn effective representations. There is a need to model multi-scale spatial interactions, flow heterogeneity, and long-distance dependencies to improve road network analysis tasks.

Method: MSRFormer integrates spatial flow convolution to extract small-scale features from large trajectory datasets, identifies scale-dependent spatial interaction regions to capture network structure and flow heterogeneity, uses a graph transformer to capture cross-scale spatial dependencies, fuses features via residual connections, and applies contrastive learning to obtain the final road network representation. Validated on two real-world datasets, with trajectory data boosting performance, especially in complex networks.

Result: MSRFormer outperforms baseline methods on two road network analysis tasks, with up to 16% improvements over the strongest baseline. The gains are larger for tasks leveraging trajectory data and in more complex road network structures.

Conclusion: The framework offers a practical, task-agnostic approach to road network representation learning that emphasizes the interplay between scale effects and flow heterogeneity. It demonstrates the value of incorporating trajectory data and provides a basis for further exploration of multi-scale, flow-aware learning in road networks.

Abstract: Transforming road network data into vector representations using deep
learning has proven effective for road network analysis. However, urban road
networks' heterogeneous and hierarchical nature poses challenges for accurate
representation learning. Graph neural networks, which aggregate features from
neighboring nodes, often struggle due to their homogeneity assumption and focus
on a single structural scale. To address these issues, this paper presents
MSRFormer, a novel road network representation learning framework that
integrates multi-scale spatial interactions by addressing their flow
heterogeneity and long-distance dependencies. It uses spatial flow convolution
to extract small-scale features from large trajectory datasets, and identifies
scale-dependent spatial interaction regions to capture the spatial structure of
road networks and flow heterogeneity. By employing a graph transformer,
MSRFormer effectively captures complex spatial dependencies across multiple
scales. The spatial interaction features are fused using residual connections,
which are fed to a contrastive learning algorithm to derive the final road
network representation. Validation on two real-world datasets demonstrates that
MSRFormer outperforms baseline methods in two road network analysis tasks. The
performance gains of MSRFormer suggest the traffic-related task benefits more
from incorporating trajectory data, also resulting in greater improvements in
complex road network structures with up to 16% improvements compared to the
most competitive baseline method. This research provides a practical framework
for developing task-agnostic road network representation models and highlights
distinct association patterns of the interplay between scale effects and flow
heterogeneity of spatial interactions.

</details>


### [335] [Towards Meta-Cognitive Knowledge Editing for Multimodal LLMs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05714)
*Zhaoyu Fan,Kaihang Pan,Mingze Zhou,Bosheng Qin,Juncheng Li,Shengyu Zhang,Wenqiao Zhang,Siliang Tang,Fei Wu,Yueting Zhuang*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: CogEdit introduces a benchmark suite to evaluate meta-cognitive knowledge editing in multimodal LLMs across three levels (self-awareness, boundary generalization, and noise robustness), and proposes MIND, a framework for meta-cognitive Integrated Dynamic Knowledge Editing that uses a meta-knowledge memory, game-theoretic monitoring, and label refinement; results show superior performance over traditional cognitive editing methods on both standard and meta-cognitive tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Existing benchmarks mainly target cognitive-level edits and overlook meta-cognitive processes like self-awareness, controlled generalization, and handling uncertainty. There is a need to evaluate and enable meta-cognitive editing in MLLMs.

Method: 1) Propose CogEdit benchmark with three evaluation axes: Counterfactual-Driven Editing, Boundary Constraint Editing, Noise-Robust Editing. 2) Propose MIND framework that builds a meta-knowledge memory for self-awareness, employs game-theoretic interactions to monitor knowledge activation, and uses label refinement for noise-robust updates.

Result: Experiments show MIND significantly outperforms existing cognitive editing approaches and achieves strong performance on both traditional cognitive editing benchmarks and the proposed meta-cognitive benchmarks.

Conclusion: Meta-cognitive editing is feasible and beneficial for MLLMs. The CogEdit benchmark and MIND framework provide a comprehensive path to self-aware, robust, and well-generalized knowledge editing in multimodal models.

Abstract: Knowledge editing enables multimodal large language models (MLLMs) to
efficiently update outdated or incorrect information. However, existing
benchmarks primarily emphasize cognitive-level modifications while lacking a
focus on deeper meta-cognitive processes. To bridge this gap, we introduce
CogEdit, a novel benchmark designed to evaluate MLLMs' meta-cognitive knowledge
editing abilities across three levels: (1) Counterfactual-Driven Editing,
assessing self-awareness of knowledge correctness changes; (2) Boundary
Constraint Editing, ensuring appropriate generalization without unintended
interference; and (3) Noise-Robust Editing, promoting reflective evaluation of
uncertain information. To advance meta-cognitive editing, we propose MIND
(Meta-cognitive INtegrated Dynamic Knowledge Editing), a framework that
constructs a meta-knowledge memory for self-awareness, employs game-theoretic
interactions to monitor knowledge activation, and incorporates label refinement
for noise-robust updates. Extensive experiments show that MIND significantly
outperforms existing cognitive editing approaches, achieving strong performance
on both traditional and meta-cognitive knowledge editing benchmarks.

</details>


### [336] [Hyperbolic Large Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05757)
*Sarang Patil,Zeyong Zhang,Yiran Huang,Tengfei Ma,Mengjia Xu*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: A survey of how hyperbolic geometry can enhance LLMs for modeling hierarchical semantic relations. It classifies Hyperbolic LLM methods, outlines applications, and provides a resource hub.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Real-world data often exhibit non-Euclidean, tree-like, hierarchical structures. Hyperbolic space efficiently embeds such hierarchies, enabling better semantic entailment and multi-scale reasoning in LLMs.

Method: Proposes a taxonomy of Hyperbolic LLMs (HypLLMs) into four categories: (1) hyperbolic LLMs via exp/log maps; (2) hyperbolic fine-tuned models; (3) fully hyperbolic LLMs; and (4) hyperbolic state-space models. Surveys key techniques, applications, and datasets, and highlights future research directions, accompanied by a repository of papers, models, datasets, and code.

Result: Provides a comprehensive synthesis of recent HypLLM advances, clarifying methodological categories, mapping existing work, and identifying gaps and opportunities for multi-domain semantic representation and hierarchical reasoning.

Conclusion: Hyperbolic geometry offers a compelling latent space for LLMs to capture hierarchical and multi-scale structures; the surveyed work outlines a promising research direction and provides practical resources for researchers to advance this area.

Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have achieved remarkable success and
demonstrated superior performance across various tasks, including natural
language processing (NLP), weather forecasting, biological protein folding,
text generation, and solving mathematical problems. However, many real-world
data exhibit highly non-Euclidean latent hierarchical anatomy, such as protein
networks, transportation networks, financial networks, brain networks, and
linguistic structures or syntactic trees in natural languages. Effectively
learning intrinsic semantic entailment and hierarchical relationships from
these raw, unstructured input data using LLMs remains an underexplored area.
Due to its effectiveness in modeling tree-like hierarchical structures,
hyperbolic geometry -- a non-Euclidean space -- has rapidly gained popularity
as an expressive latent representation space for complex data modeling across
domains such as graphs, images, languages, and multi-modal data. Here, we
provide a comprehensive and contextual exposition of recent advancements in
LLMs that leverage hyperbolic geometry as a representation space to enhance
semantic representation learning and multi-scale reasoning. Specifically, the
paper presents a taxonomy of the principal techniques of Hyperbolic LLMs
(HypLLMs) in terms of four main categories: (1) hyperbolic LLMs through exp/log
maps; (2) hyperbolic fine-tuned models; (3) fully hyperbolic LLMs, and (4)
hyperbolic state-space models. We also explore crucial potential applications
and outline future research directions. A repository of key papers, models,
datasets, and code implementations is available at
https://github.com/sarangp2402/Hyperbolic-LLM-Models/tree/main.

</details>


### [337] [DRF: LLM-AGENT Dynamic Reputation Filtering Framework](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05764)
*Yuwei Lou,Hao Hu,Shaocong Ma,Zongfei Zhang,Liang Wang,Jidong Ge,Xianping Tao*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: A dynamic reputation filtering framework (DRF) for multi-agent LLM systems uses an interactive rating network, reputation scoring for honesty/capability, and an Upper Confidence Bound strategy to improve agent selection, boosting task quality and collaboration in logic and coding tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address difficulties in quantifying agent performance and assessing credibility in multi-agent LLM systems, enabling more reliable task completion and efficient collaboration.

Method: Introduce DRF with: (1) an interactive rating network to quantify agent performance; (2) a reputation scoring mechanism to measure honesty and capability; (3) an Upper Confidence Bound (UCB)-based strategy to improve agent selection efficiency.

Result: DRF significantly improves task completion quality and collaboration efficiency in logical reasoning and code-generation tasks on large-scale multi-agent tasks.

Conclusion: DRF provides a new approach for multi-agent systems to handle large-scale tasks by quantifying agent performance, assessing credibility, and guiding agent selection with UCB-based decisions.

Abstract: With the evolution of generative AI, multi - agent systems leveraging large -
language models(LLMs) have emerged as a powerful tool for complex tasks.
However, these systems face challenges in quantifying agent performance and
lack mechanisms to assess agent credibility. To address these issues, we
introduce DRF, a dynamic reputation filtering framework. DRF constructs an
interactive rating network to quantify agent performance, designs a reputation
scoring mechanism to measure agent honesty and capability, and integrates an
Upper Confidence Bound - based strategy to enhance agent selection efficiency.
Experiments show that DRF significantly improves task completion quality and
collaboration efficiency in logical reasoning and code - generation tasks,
offering a new approach for multi - agent systems to handle large - scale
tasks.

</details>


### [338] [Decision-Focused Learning Enhanced by Automated Feature Engineering for Energy Storage Optimisation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05772)
*Nasser Alkhulaifi,Ismail Gokay Dogan,Timothy R. Cargan,Alexander L. Bowler,Direnc Pekaslan,Nicholas J. Watson,Isaac Triguero*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: AFE-DFL improves BESS optimization under uncertainty by integrating prediction and optimization, outperforming traditional PTO; adding Automated Feature Engineering (AFE) yields substantial gains (22.9-56.5%) over the same models without AFE on real-world data.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Decision-Focused Learning (DFL) promises better downstream optimization by integrating prediction and optimization, but evidence has been limited to synthetic or small-scale problems. Real-world BESS contexts face data scarcity and greater variability, making PTO prone to error cascades.

Method: Propose an Automated Feature Engineering (AFE) enhanced DFL framework that forecasts electricity prices and demand while optimizing BESS operations to minimize costs. Evaluate on a novel real-world UK property dataset, comparing DFL (with and without AFE) against PTO (with and without AFE).

Result: DFL achieves lower operating costs than PTO on average. Incorporating AFE substantially boosts DFL performance, improving results by 22.9-56.5% compared with the same models without AFE.

Conclusion: Domain-specific AFE enhances DFL and reduces reliance on domain expertise for BESS optimization, delivering clear economic benefits. The findings support the practical viability of DFL in real-world energy management and imply broader applicability to systems facing data scarcity and parameter uncertainty.

Abstract: Decision-making under uncertainty in energy management is complicated by
unknown parameters hindering optimal strategies, particularly in Battery Energy
Storage System (BESS) operations. Predict-Then-Optimise (PTO) approaches treat
forecasting and optimisation as separate processes, allowing prediction errors
to cascade into suboptimal decisions as models minimise forecasting errors
rather than optimising downstream tasks. The emerging Decision-Focused Learning
(DFL) methods overcome this limitation by integrating prediction and
optimisation; however, they are relatively new and have been tested primarily
on synthetic datasets or small-scale problems, with limited evidence of their
practical viability. Real-world BESS applications present additional
challenges, including greater variability and data scarcity due to collection
constraints and operational limitations. Because of these challenges, this work
leverages Automated Feature Engineering (AFE) to extract richer representations
and improve the nascent approach of DFL. We propose an AFE-DFL framework
suitable for small datasets that forecasts electricity prices and demand while
optimising BESS operations to minimise costs. We validate its effectiveness on
a novel real-world UK property dataset. The evaluation compares DFL methods
against PTO, with and without AFE. The results show that, on average, DFL
yields lower operating costs than PTO and adding AFE further improves the
performance of DFL methods by 22.9-56.5% compared to the same models without
AFE. These findings provide empirical evidence for DFL's practical viability in
real-world settings, indicating that domain-specific AFE enhances DFL and
reduces reliance on domain expertise for BESS optimisation, yielding economic
benefits with broader implications for energy management systems facing similar
challenges.

</details>


### [339] [Chatbot To Help Patients Understand Their Health](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05818)
*Won Seok Jang,Hieu Tran,Manav Mistry,SaiKiran Gandluri,Yifan Zhang,Sharmin Sultana,Sunjae Kown,Yuan Zhang,Zonghai Yao,Hong Yu*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: A lightweight, two-stage trained chatbot (NoteAid-Chatbot) uses a learning-as-conversation approach with no labeled data to educate patients. It leverages a multi-agent LLM and PPO-based RL, trained on synthetic medical conversations and simulated discharge scenarios, achieving emergent patient-education behaviors and outperforming non-expert humans in a Turing-like evaluation.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Empower patients to actively participate in care and reduce the need for labeled data by showing that low-cost RL alignment can yield effective, domain-specific educational chatbots in healthcare.

Method: Two-stage training of a lightweight LLaMA 3.2 3B model: (1) supervised fine-tuning on synthetically generated medical conversation data using medical conversation strategies, (2) reinforcement learning using rewards derived from patient understanding assessments in simulated hospital discharge contexts; a multi-agent LLM framework with no explicit supervision for clarity/relevance; PPO-based reward modeling to guide multi-turn, educational dialogue.

Result: The chatbot exhibits emergent patient-education behaviors such as clarity, relevance, and structured dialogue; it handles multi-turn interactions and learns to incorporate diverse educational strategies without explicit supervision. A Turing-like test shows it can surpass non-expert humans in evaluation, demonstrating that simple PPO-based reward modeling can train lightweight, domain-specific chatbots for realistic conversations.

Conclusion: This work demonstrates the feasibility of applying low-cost PPO-based RL to realistic, open-ended conversational domains like healthcare education, supporting broader RL-based alignment methods and suggesting wide applicability beyond the study domain.

Abstract: Patients must possess the knowledge necessary to actively participate in
their care. We present NoteAid-Chatbot, a conversational AI that promotes
patient understanding via a novel 'learning as conversation' framework, built
on a multi-agent large language model (LLM) and reinforcement learning (RL)
setup without human-labeled data. NoteAid-Chatbot was built on a lightweight
LLaMA 3.2 3B model trained in two stages: initial supervised fine-tuning on
conversational data synthetically generated using medical conversation
strategies, followed by RL with rewards derived from patient understanding
assessments in simulated hospital discharge scenarios. Our evaluation, which
includes comprehensive human-aligned assessments and case studies, demonstrates
that NoteAid-Chatbot exhibits key emergent behaviors critical for patient
education, such as clarity, relevance, and structured dialogue, even though it
received no explicit supervision for these attributes. Our results show that
even simple Proximal Policy Optimization (PPO)-based reward modeling can
successfully train lightweight, domain-specific chatbots to handle multi-turn
interactions, incorporate diverse educational strategies, and meet nuanced
communication objectives. Our Turing test demonstrates that NoteAid-Chatbot
surpasses non-expert human. Although our current focus is on healthcare, the
framework we present illustrates the feasibility and promise of applying
low-cost, PPO-based RL to realistic, open-ended conversational domains,
broadening the applicability of RL-based alignment methods.

</details>


### [340] [MapAgent: A Hierarchical Agent for Geospatial Reasoning with Dynamic Map Tool Integration](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.05933)
*Md Hasebul Hasan,Mahir Labib Dihan,Mohammed Eunus Ali,Md Rizwan Parvez*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: MapAgent is a hierarchical, plug-and-play multi-agent framework for map-aware geospatial reasoning that decouples planning from execution and uses a dedicated map-tool agent to coordinate map APIs, achieving notable gains on diverse geospatial benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Geospatial tasks demand spatial reasoning, multi-hop planning, and real-time map interaction. Existing LLM agent frameworks often struggle with handling numerous similar geospatial APIs and can overwhelm the model with tool use. A decoupled, hierarchical design can reduce cognitive load and improve tool selection.

Method: A high-level planner decomposes queries into subgoals routed to specialized modules. A dedicated map-tool agent orchestrates map APIs in parallel to fetch geospatial data relevant to the query; simpler modules (solution generation, answer extraction) operate with minimal overhead. The framework is evaluated on four benchmarks (MapEval-Textual, MapEval-API, MapEval-Visual, MapQA) and is open-sourced.

Result: Substantial gains over state-of-the-art tool-augmented and agentic baselines on the four geospatial benchmarks.

Conclusion: MapAgent reduces cognitive load, improves tool selection accuracy, and enables precise coordination across similar APIs; the framework is open-source at the provided repository.

Abstract: Agentic AI has significantly extended the capabilities of large language
models (LLMs) by enabling complex reasoning and tool use. However, most
existing frameworks are tailored to domains such as mathematics, coding, or web
automation, and fall short on geospatial tasks that require spatial reasoning,
multi-hop planning, and real-time map interaction. To address these challenges,
we introduce MapAgent, a hierarchical multi-agent plug-and-play framework with
customized toolsets and agentic scaffolds for map-integrated geospatial
reasoning. Unlike existing flat agent-based approaches that treat tools
uniformly-often overwhelming the LLM when handling similar but subtly different
geospatial APIs-MapAgent decouples planning from execution. A high-level
planner decomposes complex queries into subgoals, which are routed to
specialized modules. For tool-heavy modules-such as map-based services-we then
design a dedicated map-tool agent that efficiently orchestrates related APIs
adaptively in parallel to effectively fetch geospatial data relevant for the
query, while simpler modules (e.g., solution generation or answer extraction)
operate without additional agent overhead. This hierarchical design reduces
cognitive load, improves tool selection accuracy, and enables precise
coordination across similar APIs. We evaluate MapAgent on four diverse
geospatial benchmarks-MapEval-Textual, MapEval-API, MapEval-Visual, and
MapQA-and demonstrate substantial gains over state-of-the-art tool-augmented
and agentic baselines. We open-source our framwork at
https://github.com/Hasebul/MapAgent.

</details>


### [341] [Rethinking Reasoning Quality in Large Language Models through Enhanced Chain-of-Thought via RL](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06024)
*Haoyang He,Zihua Rong,Kun Ji,Chenyang Li,Qing Huang,Chong Xia,Lan Yang,Honggang Zhang*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Introduces Dynamic Reasoning Efficiency Reward (DRER), a plug-and-play RL reward framework that directly incentivizes useful chain-of-thought (CoT) and stabilizes training via a dynamic length constraint; includes Logictree dataset; shows a 7B model attaining GPT-o3-mini level on Logictree with minimal training steps and a ~30% rise in CoT confidence; code released.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current task-specific reward signals often ignore the quality of reasoning within CoT and fail to probe genuine reasoning capacity or control reasoning depth, limiting generalization.

Method: Two-part approach: (1) Reasoning Quality Reward assigns credit to reasoning chains that increase the likelihood of the correct answer; (2) Dynamic Length Advantage decays the value of responses that deviate from a validation-derived length threshold; introduces Logictree as a dynamic deductive reasoning dataset for RL data and benchmarking; evaluates on Logictree and AIME24; reports a 7B model achieving GPT-o3-mini parity in 400 training steps.

Result: Demonstrates that DRER can shape CoT behavior effectively: a 7B model reaches GPT-o3-mini level on Logictree with limited steps; average confidence of CoT-augmented answers rises by about 30%; shows generalization across diverse logical reasoning datasets.

Conclusion: DRER provides a practical RL-based pathway to enhance formal reasoning in LLMs, with released code/data enabling reproducibility and broader evaluation; further work could explore scalability, robustness, and domain transfer.

Abstract: Reinforcement learning (RL) has recently become the dominant paradigm for
strengthening the reasoning abilities of large language models (LLMs). Yet the
rule-based reward functions commonly used on mathematical or programming
benchmarks assess only answer format and correctness, providing no signal as to
whether the induced Chain-of-Thought (CoT) actually improves the answer.
Furthermore, such task-specific training offers limited control over logical
depth and therefore may fail to reveal a model's genuine reasoning capacity. We
propose Dynamic Reasoning Efficiency Reward (DRER) -- a plug-and-play RL reward
framework that reshapes both reward and advantage signals. (i) A Reasoning
Quality Reward assigns fine-grained credit to those reasoning chains that
demonstrably raise the likelihood of the correct answer, directly incentivising
the trajectories with beneficial CoT tokens. (ii) A Dynamic Length Advantage
decays the advantage of responses whose length deviates from a
validation-derived threshold, stabilising training. To facilitate rigorous
assessment, we also release Logictree, a dynamically constructed deductive
reasoning dataset that functions both as RL training data and as a
comprehensive benchmark. Experiments confirm the effectiveness of DRER: our 7B
model attains GPT-o3-mini level performance on Logictree with 400 trianing
steps, while the average confidence of CoT-augmented answers rises by 30%. The
model further exhibits generalisation across diverse logical-reasoning
datasets, and the mathematical benchmark AIME24. These results illuminate how
RL shapes CoT behaviour and chart a practical path toward enhancing
formal-reasoning skills in large language models. All code and data are
available in repository https://github.com/Henryhe09/DRER.

</details>


### [342] [Reverse-Engineered Reasoning for Open-Ended Generation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06160)
*Haozhe Wang,Haoran Que,Qixin Xu,Minghao Liu,Wangchunshu Zhou,Jiazhan Feng,Wanjun Zhong,Wei Ye,Tong Yang,Wenhao Huang,Ge Zhang,Fangzhen Lin*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: A backward-engineering reasoning approach (REER) learns latent step-by-step reasoning from known-good solutions for open-ended generation, enabling gradient-free discovery and producing DeepWriting-20K data and a model (DeepWriter-8B) that rivals leading proprietary models on open-ended tasks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Open-ended creative generation remains hard for deep reasoning. RL has reward-signal issues and distillation is expensive and capped by teacher models. A backward, gradient-free approach to infer plausible reasoning sequences can leverage existing solutions at scale.

Method: Reverse-engineered reasoning (REER) constructs latent reasoning steps by starting from correct outcomes and inferring the steps that could have produced them. This gradient-free process scales to create DeepWriting-20K (20,000 trajectories) and trains DeepWriter-8B on this data to perform open-ended tasks.

Result: DeepWriter-8B surpasses strong open-source baselines and is competitive with, and occasionally superior to, leading proprietary models like GPT-4o and Claude 3.5 on open-ended tasks.

Conclusion: REER offers a novel paradigm for deep reasoning in open-ended generation, enabling scalable, reward-free discovery of reasoning steps, and providing an open dataset and a competitive model that broadens access beyond proprietary systems.

Abstract: While the ``deep reasoning'' paradigm has spurred significant advances in
verifiable domains like mathematics, its application to open-ended, creative
generation remains a critical challenge. The two dominant methods for
instilling reasoning -- reinforcement learning (RL) and instruction
distillation -- falter in this area; RL struggles with the absence of clear
reward signals and high-quality reward models, while distillation is
prohibitively expensive and capped by the teacher model's capabilities. To
overcome these limitations, we introduce REverse-Engineered Reasoning (REER), a
new paradigm that fundamentally shifts the approach. Instead of building a
reasoning process ``forwards'' through trial-and-error or imitation, REER works
``backwards'' from known-good solutions to computationally discover the latent,
step-by-step deep reasoning process that could have produced them. Using this
scalable, gradient-free approach, we curate and open-source DeepWriting-20K, a
large-scale dataset of 20,000 deep reasoning trajectories for open-ended tasks.
Our model, DeepWriter-8B, trained on this data, not only surpasses strong
open-source baselines but also achieves performance competitive with, and at
times superior to, leading proprietary models like GPT-4o and Claude 3.5.

</details>


### [343] [From Long to Short: LLMs Excel at Trimming Own Reasoning Chains](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06174)
*Wei Han,Geng Zhan,Sicheng Yu,Chenyu Wang,Bryan Hooi*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Efficient Dynamic Inference Trimming (EDIT) trims LRMs' reasoning paths at test time by constraint-guided generation to balance brevity and correctness, improving readability and efficiency without sacrificing accuracy.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Large reasoning models often achieve high performance via extended reasoning traces but suffer from overthinking, leading to overly long, less interpretable outputs. There is a need to balance correctness and conciseness at test time.

Method: Introduce EDIT (Efficient Dynamic Inference Trimming): a constraint-guided generation framework that jointly tracks output length and answer distributions under varying constraints to identify and output the shortest correct reasoning paths.

Result: Extensive experiments across diverse models and datasets show that EDIT substantially improves reasoning efficiency, producing concise yet informative outputs, with improved readability and user experience while maintaining accuracy.

Conclusion: Balancing multiple generation objectives at test time is feasible; EDIT provides a practical, retraining-free approach to generate compact, correct reasoning traces, enhancing user experience and interpretability.

Abstract: O1/R1 style large reasoning models (LRMs) signal a substantial leap forward
over conventional instruction-following LLMs. By applying test-time scaling to
generate extended reasoning paths, they establish many SOTAs across a wide
range of complex reasoning tasks. However, recent studies show that LRMs are
prone to suffer from overthinking -- the tendency to overcomplicate simple
problems, leading to excessive strategy switching and long, convoluted
reasoning traces that hinder their interpretability. To mitigate this issue, we
conduct a systematic investigation into the reasoning efficiency of a broad set
of LRMs and uncover a common dilemma: the difficulty in balancing multiple
generation objectives such as correctness and brevity. Based on this discovery,
we propose a test-time scaling method, EDIT (Efficient Dynamic Inference
Trimming), which efficiently guides LRMs to identify the shortest correct
reasoning paths at test time. EDIT employs constraint-guided generation while
jointly tracking length and answer distributions under varying constraints,
allowing it to select responses that strike an optimal balance between
conciseness and correctness. Extensive experiments across diverse models and
datasets show that EDIT substantially enhance the reasoning efficiency,
producing compact yet informative outputs that improve readability and user
experience.

</details>


### [344] [PillagerBench: Benchmarking LLM-Based Agents in Competitive Minecraft Team Environments](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06235)
*Olivier Schipper,Yudi Zhang,Yali Du,Mykola Pechenizkiy,Meng Fang*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Introduces PillagerBench for real-time competitive multi-agent evaluation in Minecraft and TactiCrafter, an LLM-based team-mate system; shows competitive performance and self-play learning; open-sourced.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Bridges the gap where LLM agents excel at cooperative/strategic tasks but are underexplored in competitive multi-agent environments; provides a fair, reproducible benchmark and tools to study multi-agent coordination and adaptation.

Method: PillagerBench offers an extensible API, multi-round testing, and rule-based built-in opponents to enable fair comparisons in team-vs-team scenarios. TactiCrafter is an LLM-based multi-agent system that uses human-readable tactics, learns causal dependencies, and adapts to opponent strategies, with self-play to improve and evolve strategies. The evaluation includes baseline comparisons and analyses of learning dynamics across episodes, with the project open-sourced for community use.

Result: TactiCrafter outperforms baseline approaches, demonstrating adaptive learning through self-play. The study analyzes the learning process and strategic evolution over multiple game episodes. PillagerBench is open-sourced to encourage further research.

Conclusion: PillagerBench provides a principled, reproducible platform for evaluating competitive multi-agent AI; TactiCrafter advances LLM-driven teamwork and strategic adaptation in adversarial settings; the work and tools are released to the research community.

Abstract: LLM-based agents have shown promise in various cooperative and strategic
reasoning tasks, but their effectiveness in competitive multi-agent
environments remains underexplored. To address this gap, we introduce
PillagerBench, a novel framework for evaluating multi-agent systems in
real-time competitive team-vs-team scenarios in Minecraft. It provides an
extensible API, multi-round testing, and rule-based built-in opponents for
fair, reproducible comparisons. We also propose TactiCrafter, an LLM-based
multi-agent system that facilitates teamwork through human-readable tactics,
learns causal dependencies, and adapts to opponent strategies. Our evaluation
demonstrates that TactiCrafter outperforms baseline approaches and showcases
adaptive learning through self-play. Additionally, we analyze its learning
process and strategic evolution over multiple game episodes. To encourage
further research, we have open-sourced PillagerBench, fostering advancements in
multi-agent AI for competitive environments.

</details>


### [345] [Proof2Silicon: Prompt Repair for Verified Code and Hardware Generation via Reinforcement Learning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06239)
*Manvi Jha,Jiaxin Wan,Deming Chen*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Introduces Proof2Silicon, an end-to-end framework that combines PREFACE's RL-based prompt repair with automatic Dafny-to-C translation and Vivado HLS to synthesize hardware from natural-language specs, achieving up to 72% end-to-end RTL synthesis success on a 100-task benchmark, and improving Dafny verification by up to 21%.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Formal verification is essential for hardware and safety-critical domains, but LLM-generated code frequently fails verification. A model-agnostic, scalable pipeline from natural language to silicon is needed without costly fine-tuning.

Method: Leverages PREFACE's verifier-driven RL to iteratively optimize prompts to produce correct Dafny code; translates verified Dafny to high-level C using Dafny's Python backend and PyLog; uses Vivado HLS to synthesize RTL.

Result: On a 100-task benchmark, PREFACE's RL-guided prompt optimization improved Dafny verification success rates across diverse LLMs by up to 21%. Proof2Silicon achieved an end-to-end hardware synthesis success rate of up to 72%, generating RTL designs through Vivado HLS.

Conclusion: Demonstrates a robust, scalable pipeline for LLM-driven, formally verified hardware synthesis, bridging natural-language specifications and silicon realization.

Abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated impressive capabilities in
automated code generation but frequently produce code that fails formal
verification, an essential requirement for hardware and safety-critical
domains. To overcome this fundamental limitation, we previously proposed
PREFACE, a model-agnostic framework based on reinforcement learning (RL) that
iteratively repairs the prompts provided to frozen LLMs, systematically
steering them toward generating formally verifiable Dafny code without costly
fine-tuning. This work presents Proof2Silicon, a novel end-to-end synthesis
framework that embeds the previously proposed PREFACE flow to enable the
generation of correctness-by-construction hardware directly from natural
language specifications. Proof2Silicon operates by: (1) leveraging PREFACE's
verifier-driven RL agent to optimize prompt generation iteratively, ensuring
Dafny code correctness; (2) automatically translating verified Dafny programs
into synthesizable high-level C using Dafny's Python backend and PyLog; and (3)
employing Vivado HLS to produce RTL implementations. Evaluated rigorously on a
challenging 100-task benchmark, PREFACE's RL-guided prompt optimization
consistently improved Dafny verification success rates across diverse LLMs by
up to 21%. Crucially, Proof2Silicon achieved an end-to-end hardware synthesis
success rate of up to 72%, generating RTL designs through Vivado HLS synthesis
flows. These results demonstrate a robust, scalable, and automated pipeline for
LLM-driven, formally verified hardware synthesis, bridging natural-language
specification and silicon realization.

</details>


### [346] [REMI: A Novel Causal Schema Memory Architecture for Personalized Lifestyle Recommendation Agents](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06269)
*Vishal Raman,Vijai Aravindh R,Abhijith Ragav*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Remi introduces a memory-augmented, causal reasoning architecture (CSM) for personalized, explainable multimodal lifestyle agents, integrating a personal causal graph, causal reasoning, and schema-based planning orchestrated by an LLM to deliver tailored, explainable recommendations.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Current personalized AI assistants struggle to integrate complex personal data and causal knowledge, yielding generic, opaque advice. There is a need for explainable, context-aware personalization that respects user life events, habits, and external knowledge.

Method: Proposes REMI: a Causal Schema Memory architecture with a personal causal knowledge graph, a causal reasoning engine, and a schema-based planning module for a multimodal lifestyle agent. A Large Language Model orchestrates components to perform goal-directed causal traversals enriched with external knowledge and hypothetical reasoning, retrieving adaptable plan schemas to generate tailored action plans. Introduces evaluation metrics (Personalization Salience Score and Causal Reasoning Accuracy) and a system design outline.

Result: CSM-based agents produced more context-aware, user-aligned recommendations than baseline LLM agents, demonstrating improved personalization and explainability.

Conclusion: The work presents a novel memory-augmented, causal-reasoning framework for personalized agents, advancing transparent and trustworthy AI lifestyle assistants through structured memory, reasoning, and planning.

Abstract: Personalized AI assistants often struggle to incorporate complex personal
data and causal knowledge, leading to generic advice that lacks explanatory
power. We propose REMI, a Causal Schema Memory architecture for a multimodal
lifestyle agent that integrates a personal causal knowledge graph, a causal
reasoning engine, and a schema based planning module. The idea is to deliver
explainable, personalized recommendations in domains like fashion, personal
wellness, and lifestyle planning. Our architecture uses a personal causal graph
of the user's life events and habits, performs goal directed causal traversals
enriched with external knowledge and hypothetical reasoning, and retrieves
adaptable plan schemas to generate tailored action plans. A Large Language
Model orchestrates these components, producing answers with transparent causal
explanations. We outline the CSM system design and introduce new evaluation
metrics for personalization and explainability, including Personalization
Salience Score and Causal Reasoning Accuracy, to rigorously assess its
performance. Results indicate that CSM based agents can provide more context
aware, user aligned recommendations compared to baseline LLM agents. This work
demonstrates a novel approach to memory augmented, causal reasoning in
personalized agents, advancing the development of transparent and trustworthy
AI lifestyle assistants.

</details>


### [347] [TableMind: An Autonomous Programmatic Agent for Tool-Augmented Table Reasoning](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06278)
*Chuang Jiang,Mingyue Cheng,Xiaoyu Tao,Qingyang Mao,Jie Ouyang,Qi Liu*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: TableMind is an autonomous, tool-augmented table reasoning agent that writes and executes data-analysis code in a sandbox, uses planning and self-reflection, and is trained via supervised and reinforcement fine-tuning with RAPO, achieving state-of-the-art results on benchmarks.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To address the limitations of purely text-based LLMs in numeric-heavy table reasoning and the rigid, imitation-based patterns of existing tool-enabled systems.

Method: A two-stage fine-tuning paradigm: (1) supervised fine-tuning on high-quality reasoning trajectories to learn effective tool usage and planning; (2) reinforcement fine-tuning using Rank-Aware Policy Optimization (RAPO) which increases the update weight of high-quality trajectories when their output probabilities are lower than those of low-quality ones. The model autonomously performs multi-turn tool invocation and writes/executes data-analysis code in a secure sandbox, with planning and self-reflection to adapt strategies.

Result: Extensive experiments on mainstream benchmarks show TableMind achieves superior performance compared to competitive baselines, with substantial gains in reasoning accuracy and computational precision.

Conclusion: Demonstrates that autonomous tool usage, sandboxed code execution, and RAPO-based training can significantly improve table reasoning in LLM-powered agents, pointing to a promising direction for data-analysis AI systems.

Abstract: Table reasoning is crucial for leveraging structured data in domains such as
finance, healthcare, and scientific research. While large language models
(LLMs) show promise in multi-step reasoning, purely text-based methods often
struggle with the complex numerical computations and fine-grained operations
inherently required in this task. Tool-integrated reasoning improves
computational accuracy via explicit code execution, yet existing systems
frequently rely on rigid patterns, supervised imitation, and lack true
autonomous adaptability. In this paper, we present TableMind, an LLM-driven
table reasoning agent that (i) autonomously performs multi-turn tool
invocation, (ii) writes and executes data-analyzing code in a secure sandbox
environment for data analysis and precise numerical reasoning, and (iii)
exhibits high-level capabilities such as planning and self-reflection to adapt
strategies. To realize these capabilities, we adopt a two-stage fine-tuning
paradigm built on top of a powerful pre-trained language model: supervised
fine-tuning on high-quality reasoning trajectories to establish effective tool
usage patterns, followed by reinforcement fine-tuning to optimize
multi-objective strategies. In particular, we propose Rank-Aware Policy
Optimization (RAPO), which increases the update weight of high-quality
trajectories when their output probabilities are lower than those of
low-quality ones, thereby guiding the model more consistently toward better and
more accurate answers. Extensive experiments on several mainstream benchmarks
demonstrate that TableMind achieves superior performance compared to
competitive baselines, yielding substantial gains in both reasoning accuracy
and computational precision.

</details>


### [348] [SFR-DeepResearch: Towards Effective Reinforcement Learning for Autonomously Reasoning Single Agents](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06283)
*Xuan-Phi Nguyen,Shrey Pandit,Revanth Gangi Reddy,Austin Xu,Silvio Savarese,Caiming Xiong,Shafiq Joty*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Autonomous single-agent RL for deep research (DR) with minimal web crawling and Python tool integration; synthetic-data RL recipe; best model SFR-DR-20B reaches 28.7% on Humanity's Last Exam, with additional analyses.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Advance agentic AI by enabling autonomous, interleaved reasoning and tool-use in a single agent for Deep Research tasks, avoiding rigid multi-agent workflows and heavy external tooling.

Method: Propose a simple continual reinforcement learning (RL) recipe trained entirely on synthetic data, applied to multiple open-source LLMs, focusing on reasoning-optimized behavior with minimal web access and Python tool integration.

Result: Through this RL recipe, the authors report a best variant SFR-DR-20B achieving up to 28.7% on Humanity's Last Exam, plus targeted analysis experiments to illuminate the approach.

Conclusion: Shows that continual RL with a synthetic-data recipe can improve reasoning-enabled autonomous agents for DR, even with limited web crawling and tool integration, and highlights areas for further insight-driven experimentation.

Abstract: Equipping large language models (LLMs) with complex, interleaved reasoning
and tool-use capabilities has become a key focus in agentic AI research,
especially with recent advances in reasoning-oriented (``thinking'') models.
Such capabilities are key to unlocking a number of important applications. One
such application is Deep Research (DR), which requires extensive search and
reasoning over many sources. Our work in this paper focuses on the development
of native Autonomous Single-Agent models for DR featuring minimal web crawling
and Python tool integration. Unlike multi-agent systems, where agents take up
pre-defined roles and are told what to do at each step in a static workflow, an
autonomous single-agent determines its next action dynamically based on
context, without manual directive. While prior work has proposed training
recipes for base or instruction-tuned LLMs, we focus on continual reinforcement
learning (RL) of reasoning-optimized models to further enhance agentic skills
while preserving reasoning ability. Towards this end, we propose a simple RL
recipe with entirely synthetic data, which we apply to various open-source
LLMs. Our best variant SFR-DR-20B achieves up to 28.7% on Humanity's Last Exam
benchmark. In addition, we conduct key analysis experiments to provide more
insights into our methodologies.

</details>


### [349] [From Implicit Exploration to Structured Reasoning: Leveraging Guideline and Refinement for LLMs](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06284)
*Jiaxiang Chen,Zhuo Wang,Mingxi Zou,Zhucong Li,Zhijian Zhou,Song Wang,Zenglin Xu*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Structured reasoning with stepwise guidelines and refinement improves LLMs' reasoning stability, generalization, and cross-domain transfer, outperforming strong baselines and matching supervised fine-tuning in scalability.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To combat unstable, unguided reasoning paths caused by implicit exploration, which leads to error accumulation, poor error correction, and limited learning from past experience in LLMs.

Method: Extract structured reasoning patterns from successful trajectories and failure signals; during inference, follow step-by-step guidelines with post-step refinement to correct errors and stabilize reasoning; evaluate on BBH and four benchmarks (GSM8K, MATH-500, MBPP, HumanEval) to assess generalization and cross-domain transfer.

Result: The approach consistently outperforms strong baselines across diverse reasoning tasks, yielding improved stability and generalization. Guidelines transfer across domains and model collaborations, with performance matching or surpassing supervised fine-tuning in effectiveness and scalability.

Conclusion: Structured, guideline-driven reasoning with iterative refinement offers a scalable, transferable framework that improves robustness and generalization of LLMs, and can rival supervised fine-tuning.

Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) have advanced general-purpose reasoning, showing
strong performance across diverse tasks. However, existing methods often rely
on implicit exploration, where the model follows stochastic and unguided
reasoning paths-like walking without a map. This leads to unstable reasoning
paths, lack of error correction, and limited learning from past experience. To
address these issues, we propose a framework that shifts from implicit
exploration to structured reasoning through guideline and refinement. First, we
extract structured reasoning patterns from successful trajectories and
reflective signals from failures. During inference, the model follows these
guidelines step-by-step, with refinement applied after each step to correct
errors and stabilize the reasoning process. Experiments on BBH and four
additional benchmarks (GSM8K, MATH-500, MBPP, HumanEval) show that our method
consistently outperforms strong baselines across diverse reasoning tasks.
Structured reasoning with stepwise execution and refinement improves stability
and generalization, while guidelines transfer well across domains and flexibly
support cross-model collaboration, matching or surpassing supervised
fine-tuning in effectiveness and scalability.

</details>


### [350] [Can AI Make Energy Retrofit Decisions? An Evaluation of Large Language Models](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06307)
*Lei Shu,Dong Zhao*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: LLMs can assist residential retrofit decisions with moderate accuracy, especially for technical CO2-reduction goals, but show low cross-model agreement and limited handling of sociotechnical context; interpretation and consistency require improvement.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: To test whether large language models can generalize across diverse residential contexts and provide practitioner-friendly retrofit recommendations for CO2 reduction and payback minimization, addressing gaps in generalizability and interpretability.

Method: Evaluate seven LLMs (ChatGPT, DeepSeek, Gemini, Grok, Llama, Claude; with others implied by text) on a dataset of 400 homes across 49 US states, for two objectives (technical CO2 reduction and sociotechnical payback minimization). Assess four dimensions—accuracy, consistency, sensitivity, and reasoning—without fine-tuning.

Result: LLMs produced effective recommendations in many cases, with top-1 match up to 54.5% and top-5 up to 92.8% without fine-tuning. Technical objective yielded stronger performance than sociotechnical. Agreement across models was low; higher-performing models tended to diverge. Models were sensitive to location and building geometry but less so to technology and occupant behavior. Most models used step-by-step engineering-style reasoning, which was often superficial and lacked deep contextual awareness.

Conclusion: LLMs show promise as decision-support tools for energy retrofit planning but require improvements in accuracy, cross-model consistency, and richer handling of local context and economic trade-offs to be reliable in practice.

Abstract: Conventional approaches to building energy retrofit decision making suffer
from limited generalizability and low interpretability, hindering adoption in
diverse residential contexts. With the growth of Smart and Connected
Communities, generative AI, especially large language models (LLMs), may help
by processing contextual information and producing practitioner readable
recommendations. We evaluate seven LLMs (ChatGPT, DeepSeek, Gemini, Grok,
Llama, and Claude) on residential retrofit decisions under two objectives:
maximizing CO2 reduction (technical) and minimizing payback period
(sociotechnical). Performance is assessed on four dimensions: accuracy,
consistency, sensitivity, and reasoning, using a dataset of 400 homes across 49
US states. LLMs generate effective recommendations in many cases, reaching up
to 54.5 percent top 1 match and 92.8 percent within top 5 without fine tuning.
Performance is stronger for the technical objective, while sociotechnical
decisions are limited by economic trade offs and local context. Agreement
across models is low, and higher performing models tend to diverge from others.
LLMs are sensitive to location and building geometry but less sensitive to
technology and occupant behavior. Most models show step by step, engineering
style reasoning, but it is often simplified and lacks deeper contextual
awareness. Overall, LLMs are promising assistants for energy retrofit decision
making, but improvements in accuracy, consistency, and context handling are
needed for reliable practice.

</details>


### [351] [Large Language Models as Virtual Survey Respondents: Evaluating Sociodemographic Response Generation](https://arxiv.org/abs/2509.06337)
*Jianpeng Zhao,Chenyu Yuan,Weiming Luo,Haoling Xie,Guangwei Zhang,Steven Jige Quan,Zixuan Yuan,Pengyang Wang,Denghui Zhang*

Main category: cs.AI

TL;DR: Proposes LLM-based simulation of survey respondents using PAS (partial attribute simulation) and FAS (full attribute simulation) to create scalable, demographically coherent synthetic data; introduces LLM-S^3 benchmark across 11 real datasets; evaluates multiple LLMs, analyzes context/prompt effects, and highlights both potential and limitations of this approach.


<details>
  <summary>Details</summary>
Motivation: Traditional surveys are costly, time-consuming, and limited in scale. Generating synthetic, demographically coherent responses with LLMs offers a scalable alternative for sociological research and policy evaluation, enabling large-scale testing and privacy-preserving data generation.

Method: Introduce two simulation settings: PAS (predict missing attributes from partial profiles) and FAS (generate full synthetic datasets under zero-context and context-enhanced conditions). Build LLM-S^3 benchmark across 11 real-world datasets in four sociological domains. Evaluate multiple mainstream LLMs (GPT-3.5/4 Turbo, LLaMA 3.0/3.1-8B), analyze prediction performance, failure modes, and the impact of context and prompt design on fidelity.

Result: LLMs exhibit consistent trends in predicting attributes and generating responses, but reveal notable failure modes. Context and prompt design significantly influence simulation fidelity; model choice also affects outcomes. The study demonstrates potential for scalable, cost-efficient survey simulations and provides a dataset/benchmark for future research.

Conclusion: LLM-driven survey simulations can provide a rigorous, scalable foundation for sociological research and policy evaluation, but require careful prompt engineering and awareness of biases and limitations. The work offers public code and data to support broader adoption and ongoing benchmarking.

Abstract: Questionnaire-based surveys are foundational to social science research and
public policymaking, yet traditional survey methods remain costly,
time-consuming, and often limited in scale. This paper explores a new paradigm:
simulating virtual survey respondents using Large Language Models (LLMs). We
introduce two novel simulation settings, namely Partial Attribute Simulation
(PAS) and Full Attribute Simulation (FAS), to systematically evaluate the
ability of LLMs to generate accurate and demographically coherent responses. In
PAS, the model predicts missing attributes based on partial respondent
profiles, whereas FAS involves generating complete synthetic datasets under
both zero-context and context-enhanced conditions. We curate a comprehensive
